content:
Posted: January 6, 2015
												I have this game. I LOVE this game.However, I cannot rate this positive at all.UPlay may be a joke, but it is a sufferable joke. The real problem is much scarier than that.----------SolidShield.----------What is SolidShield?SolidShield is a software DRM engine that was built for corporate applications, NOT computer games. In the business world, people only upgrade computers once every few years. By the time they upgrade a couple of times, the software is obsolete and has been superseded by a later version.Many gamers are completely different. A lot of us format our machines at least once a year, sometimes more often than that. A lot of us change our hardware semi-regularly as well, particularly video cards, hard disk drives and memory.This is a huge problem, you see, because all of these changes change the hardware fingerprint that SolidShield uses to 'protect' its software payload. It's akin to the Windows activation system with the very major difference that it it is extremely hyperactive, and very intrusive.According to Ubisoft, who has said in the past that the PC gaming market is terrible, we are never allowed to change our hardware configurations. If we do, we are obligated to buy a new copy.Ubisoft says piracy has caused them to require this ridiculous DRM system, which isn't suitable for games at all.I counter that the existence of SolidShield in this product is causing people to prefer pirating this game to buying it. After all, if you pirate it, you'll actually be able to install it when you feel like playing it in two years' time.I've never before seen a company that shows such a disdain for its customers. If it were up to me, I'd remove ALL DRM from Anno 2070, and give it away for free (or a lot less than its $60 price tag) as an apology to all of us for having to put up with this travesty.Until TAGES SolidShield is COMPLETELY REMOVED from this product, I cannot see how anyone could possibly rate it positively.

												FIXING UPLAY:UPVOTE THIS SO EVERYONE KNOWSThe reason Uplay crashes when you try to launch from Steam is because Uplay does not install properly when the install is queued/prompted by Steam itself. INSTEAD, download and install the standalone Uplay launcher.THEN, run the new standalone Uplay install and log in with your account. NOW, you can launch the game from steam as usual as long as Uplay is running and you are logged in.

content:
Posted: December 26, 2014
												Good game, but Uplay is♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥me off.Actual Review:Anno 2070 is an amazing resource management sim. It's very fun to slowly develop your colony into a thriving city with somewhat complex supply lines leading to other colonies.However, that's all well and good until you go to 'war' with the available factions. The combat is just awful, mostly because only air/naval units are available.  And even those are really limited to fight with. (2 aircraft, roughly 4 attack vessels)The game is a really good concept, but for me after a few hours of gameplay I've maxed out my cities and all that's left is to fully eradicate my 'opponents'. Note opponents being barely true as everyone is just trying to survive. There never really is a reason to attack someone unless you struggle to maintain relations with them.The graphics are beautiful however, and the OST is somewhat interesting. uPlay is of course absolutely horrid, most likely it will take you about an hour to get the game working, that's if uPlay decides to deny you entry to the game you just paid for.I can't recommend this as late game there really isn't anything to do.

number of helpful: 2,186 of 2,807 people (78%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 5, 2013
												Anno 2070 is a very good game! When compared to older Anno games they've really taken some bold moves and they do work well. However, I am NOT RECOMMENDING this very GOOD GAME. Related designs (the developer) has done nothing wrong, Ubisoft (the publisher) does a lot of things wrong. I will tell you a bit about the game, but also WARN you about Ubisoft and their pushy ways. I wish someone told me before I bought this game, because I wouldn't have bought it! Please read along!A few years ago I was playing CivCity Rome. Off course I had heard of Anno, but untill then I had never played it. Then I tried Anno 1404 and I was instantly sold. Anno is a citybuilding game that is always set in a specific era. Instead of needing power and water, your citizens would like to have food and goods that you need to create for them. You build your city (or cities) on a map consisting of a bunch of islands that each have their own resources which you will need to create the goods you people want. When their wishes have been met, they grow a level. This causes the house to grow and support more people but it also generates more taxes for each citizen living there. Anno always goes very deep, you have to manage the fleet of ships carrying the goods around, time them, have the right amounts in stock etc, and sometimes when I'm about 24hrs into one sandbox game, it starts to feel like a lot of work! You must keep the production going, sell excess goods, don't go bankrupt, build that monument, manage trade routs,,,Anno comes in many flavors, just pick your favorite age and go! The latest installments are the most consistently playing ones, and with this new Anno 2070 they really made the game a lot more accessible to new players and old players alike, when it comes to the amounts of resources in a map for instance. I have a few minor points of critisism about some of the made choices though. And for me, the futuristic theme is ok, but the style is a bit bland for my taste. For instance, in Anno 1404 the palet of colors was more vibrant on my led-tv for instance. I also like seeing dozens and dozens of wooden sail ships being processed at a big massive harbor, rectangular electric ships just aren't the same. When it comes to graphics in general, this Anno is really good looking with the later effects though. I still prefer 1404, but it's a matter of taste. The action (yes, there is also warfare, limited islands and resources mean war! sometimes) is still not really spectacular and really... I don't like it. I like the building and trading! I have not played this Anno a lot or a long time, but it plays familiar enough to judge that it is a good Anno. Related Design does not screw up their beloved Anno I think! Anno games are generally good, this one is no exception... however I personally still prefer Anno 1404, it also comes without Uplay, the reason I'm not recommending this game!I would score the game 8/10 if it weren't for the game's publisher Ubisoft. I would really like to warn you about them! Really annoying buggers they are!Usually here on Steam, when you buy a game it downloads and you can play it. No worries, no fuss. Sometimes there is some online DRM, annoying and pointless but ok... Sometimes it's an online game, understandable that they want you to create a seperate account with them. But then comes along Ubisoft and their pushy Uplay "services". I know one thing, it's no DRM. When you buy a Ubisoft game here on Steam, as soon as you have paid for the game and you have downloaded it, it takes you away from Steam, pushes you to create an account at Uplay (which is Ubisoft's marketplace/Social Media), that is being published publicly. So in other words: you're in Department store A, you buy product X and as you put it in a bag to take home with you a salesperson from Department store B comes along and forces you to create a public membership with their store, while you were in the first store to begin with!Afterwards, you can look in your settings to get your profile to be blocked from the public again if you want to, but as far as I'm concerned the damage has already been done. Who do they think they are, Facebook?!?  When I accepted my fate and tried to apply for Uplay, it was impossible due to server problems! When I got tired of waiting to create my public humiliation, I went looking for fora. It seems ever since it's creation, Uplay has been plagued by downtime. When I waited these weeks in a row to create an acount and get confirmation I actually bought it, Uplay already existed over a year! And it also serves no further purpose. It does not autopatch the game, it just 'checks' if it's you and if you're allowed to play the game. Yes, what Steam already does. It annoys you with 'unlockable goodies' for games as you play (stuff that already was in the game and screenshots(!), but blocked because of idk, so you had something to unlock online), you can start finding your friends again, it needs to be constantly online while you play the game. Also it downloaded the game again as soon as I managed to create an account.Look at it this way. Valve is singlehanded carrying the PC-gaming sector by itself. It saved PC-Gaming and has achieved Cult-status. I mean, come on. Well over 60 Million people choose to be here on Steam. Ubisoft is just pushing their own store upon unsuspecting people walking around in this store! And then publicly humiliating them with their social media crap. They are trying to ply away the customers and public from Steam. If you have read this review, and then still buy any Ubisoft game... you clearly do not share this view of Steam, and I wish you a good day. To those that agree with me: if you have a game in your steam library that requires this Uplay crap, please write a review about it!When we look at EA, we can see that they have Origin as their store. When I buy an EA game here on Steam "(like Command and Conquer or the Sims), EA does not push me into an Origin account. We can all hate EA for a lot of reasons (for me it's Red Alert 3, C&C4 and that city game that came between simcity 4&5), but I give them credit for that! The games that do require Origin (Fifa, SW:TOR, Battlefield and Simcity) are not for sale here.I can accept another marketplace that digitally delivers games and software. No problem, competition is very healthy! But I cannot understand why Valve allows these practices. I mean, go ahead and try this in real life. Try to lure people from a Department store into another and I bet security is kicking you out! It's just common decency! I am not going to buy another Ubisoft game untill they either close Uplay entirely or stop pushing it with their games! That's 100% certain. I would probably have bought something there eventually, but not after this, I'm done with Ubisoft.Anno, to me, is a singleplayer game! I have played a very few games of Anno 1404 with a friend, but not a lot of people feel like going for a 24hr game in multiplayer. Still, with this whole Uplay non-sense it does not play offline! There is no reason to force something as intrusive as Uplay down our throat with a game like Anno. After that short period of being very angry with Uplay and Ubisoft I decided to delete the local content and delete Uplay. The whole attitude of Ubisoft with their Uplay causes me to score the game with 3/10.Ubisoft, please change your ways! If you don't trust Valve and Steam in their sales, don't sell your games here! Stop pushing your complete store/social media like this!!! Related Designs, please ask Ubisoft to change their ways, or go find a new publisher, I am not buying the next Anno as long as Uplay is still on it. I'm also not playing Assassins Creed 3 or 4 or Far Cry 3!I have created a group about Uplay, please join if you agree: http://steamcommunity.com/groups/boycot-ubi

number of helpful: 320 of 415 people (77%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 7, 2013
												Anno 2070 is a very relaxing, and an incredibly in depth RTS. I call it an RTS, but it is an economy focused RTS, and can be played entirely without any combat or war what so ever. The focus of the game is on building your society up and seeing to your peoples needs. The single player features a story driven campaign which serves as a good starting point to learning the basics of game play. There is quite a steep learning curve to this game, but luckily there are a lot of resources online to aid new players. Also there are some really in depth guides hear on Steam that can help out in a variety of areas. Don't be put off by the massive amount of information involved in this game, you can learn how things work, and why you do it is very satisfying.Graphically Anno 2070 is demanding, and you'll want a high end card to get the best out of the graphics. But it looks great, for sure one of the better looking stratagy games out there. This game is probably more like a city building game with a strong emphasis on economy, and supply chains. So if your into that, you'll really enjoy this. The pace of the game can be slow a steady. If your looking to build up and make everything work, you need to take your time. So the game, once you get the hang of it, is very relaxing. If you have any interest in this sort of thing at all, you should pick it up. And hey the developers even removed the always online DRM, so you can play offline :3 SUCK IT sim city!

content:
Posted: July 4, 2015
												A great strategy game!!! Try to get it on sale like I did, its totally worth it for 8 or 10 bucksIMO : 9/10 Don't trust the negative reviews from people who can't apply a manual patch to play a game, read a simple tutorial, or just use their brains to download an update.A "short" tutorial if this is your first install or if you never used Uplay before, like in my case.1 - Install the game like any regular Steam game2 - Run the game, let the autopatcher do its thing.3 - After autopatching, the game will try to run the Uplay client so you can log in/create a Uplay account, which will be    linked to your Steam Account.4 - The Uplay client WILL CRASH, yes we all know it, UPLAY SUCKS, but this happens because the uplay client in the game is outdated5 - Go to https://uplay.ubi.com/ and download their latest client. Install it. Run it, and Log In/Register for the first time.6 - Close the client completely (even from the taskbar).7 - Go to Steam, lunch the game, and voilá  the Uplay client will work, log in, link your Uplay account with your Steam account. And for an easy access, let Uplay remember your login data so you only have to click play on Steam, and get right into Anno 2070.Thats it, enjoy!

content:
Posted: July 23, 2015
												TLDR - I find this game both relaxing and challenging. Take UPlay out of the picture and this game comes highly recommended!It saddens me that there are so many negative reviews for this wonderful game, and all of them are due to the draconian implementation of Uplay. I've been lucky enough to not have any problems with Uplay or the DRM, so I will speak only to the game itself.In the new, wet future, you are charged with rebuilding society and wrestling the dwindling resources from what is left of the waterlogged planet. Maps consist of several islands, both above and below water. Your goal is settle a colony and grow it accordingly to meet your citizens needs to work your way up to the tech level needed to satisfy the mission objectives. You start each map with a single ship, and enough supplies to get your first colony going. There are 2 major factions: "ecos" and industrialists, and the third faction, techs, are available to both. You can also start building with the opposite factions buildings after you have reached a certain level of citizens. Each faction has several tiers of development, with the highest tiers requiring an insane amount of scarce resources/factory combines to get the finished products needed to satisfy demand.  Each map has different objectives, and you are given a lot of freedom in how you want to meet your goals. Do I want to spam out a lot of low end housing and industries, or work my way up the chain to produce more lucrative products? Either approach, or a combination of the two works - but your citizens get increasingly needy and harder to please the further up the tech trees you go. Random disasters and events (some scripted) also crop up to keep things interesting. It's pretty easy to stay on top of things and zip through some of the earlier missions, where you only need to deal with a few different resources and citizens needs. The later missions, and especially the expansion ones, will have you scrambling for dozens of hours to keep up with your multi-island society of thousands of citizens. It is incredibly rewarding to finally beat one of these after whittling away at it for close to a week!Important to note: There is some combat, but the focus here is supply & demand, logistics, and keeping your balance out of the red. If you like RTS games, or lots of action, you probably will not have a good time here. One thing I really like with this game, and wish was the case more often, is that it does not hold your hand every step of the way. It runs you through the basics, theres a database/help module, and the many different types of alerts warn you when something major needs your attention. Systems are there to automate trading, both at each island depot themselves, and trade routes with ships. There are tons of technologies to research, and even more to unlock through discovery/rewards - however many of these that you will need to complete mission objectives are quite well hidden. This part could probably use more in-game explanation, as I had to search online several times to find out how to get what I needed.This is definitely one of those games that makes you lose time and sleep - be careful playing if you have to be up early the next morning!

number of helpful: 54 of 59 people (92%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: June 8, 2016
(NOTE: Anno 2070 was released during the dark days of uPlay's always-on DRM. Some people have had terrible troubles with it, and others none whatsoever. In 70+ hours I have had no issues with uPlay, but I understand that others have. If always-on DRM is a dealbreaker for you, feel free to ignore this game and this review. Otherwise, read on.)The Anno series made a name for itself with supply-chain-based building and beautiful historical cityscapes. 2070 took things in a new direction, at least aesthetically, setting your constructions in the near-ish future. Global warming has settled the debate over itself by flooding the entire planet, and you are tasked with helping humanity resettle on the few habitable islands left. It's an unusually somber game that manages both a striking beauty and extremely satisfying building.Unlike your SimCities or Tropicos where money is your limiting factor, Anno 2070 challenges you to provide goods to your citizens to both build with and subsist off of. Every building requires building materials like concrete, steel, and tools before it can pop into existence. Your citizens likewise need quotas of food, beverage, luxury, and entertainment to expand their numbers. There is money, paid as taxes by your citizens and used as upkeep for your industries, but it's generally an afterthought once your initial settlement is built. Your main concern will be building supply chains in the right proportions to keep your cities growing.The result of this balance is that you're building two kinds of settlements in parallel, residences and industries. The catch is that you're doing this on limited island space, and your industries can have dire effects on their surroundings. Islands have an eco-balance rating that can boost happiness and production if positive, and tank your agriculture and cause disasters if negative. Each island also has its own particular resources, so you'll almost never get by building on one island. There's a robust convoy and trading system for you to automate deliveries with, as well as fleets of charming ships to build and explore with. Get far enough in and you get submarines and the ability to build underwater industries, too.There's a 12-mission story mode that serves as an extended tutorial for the game, along with another dozen scenarios, an infinite mode, rotating event missions, and multiplayer modes. For each of these you can choose one of two factions to start as, the filthy capitalist Global Trust or the crunchy hippy Eden Initiative. Both have very different needs and industries to fulfil them, which lead to very different play styles and looks to your cities. Late game progression unlocks a third faction of scientists to grow in parallel, and very late game you can even unlock the opposing faction to build as. You get an enormous amount of freedom in how you build, trade, and expand, which helps keep each map interesting as you progress.On top of the faction and building options, there are NPCs to trade with, missions to complete for bonuses, upgrades to research, and military options to explore. It's a huge game with a lot to like, but not without a few stumbles. The aforementioned military options are actually pretty awkward and unfun to use, leaving conquest as the last option you want to explore. Research produces random results so it can take far too long to get the upgrades you want. And beyond the mechanics, the story and voice acting elements are half♥♥♥♥♥♥♥at best and add very little to the experience.These are really minor quibbles about an otherwise spectacular game, though. The look and feel of Anno 2070 is second to none, with intensely-detailed buildings and landscapes that produce some of the most picturesque creations of any city builder. The challenges of aligning production chains is never too great but are still extremely gratifying to overcome. Spending a dozen hours on a single random map is not out of the question, resulting in a breathtaking sprawl of future cities, industrial hellscapes, and ecological paradises. Anno 2070 is easily one of the most engaging builders I've played, and its few faults are hardly enough to keep me from sinking dozens upon dozens of hours in it.

content:
Posted: November 15, 2014
												Anno 2070 offers the perfect synergy of RTS, City Building and Trading. I recommend the complete edition because the Deep Sea expansion adds a layer of extra depth to the tech trees.In Anno 2070, the size of your city is limited only by the size of your island--and there are some really BIG islands. If for some reason you aren't satisfied with your island, build some nukes, launch them, watch the pretty mushroom clouds and then move into your newly acquired glass parking lot (island). Don't feel like remediating nuclear radiation from your newly conquered paradise? Try sabotaging your enemies' main food source--destroy an oil tanker off the coast of an enemy island (preferably next to their fish hatcheries) and while he/she scrambles to clean up the oil, harass the cleanup crew with fast attack boats or helicopters and then send in your attack fleet. Even better, with the Deep Sea expansion, you can create tsunamis to wipe out your enemies' coastal holdings by destroying strategically placed geothermal power plants. After all, your citizens are worth more than your enemies' citizens, especially if your enemy happens to be the Eden faction... those hippie tree-hugging ♥♥♥♥s! Pick the Tycoons and use the power of coal and nuclear energy to crush the little Eco ♥♥♥♥♥! There's no Captain Planet to help them against your rain of nuclear fire! Crush them and their tree covered islands and pave over everything with concrete!Anno 2070 is not your typical city builder. As I explained earlier, this game is more of a hybrid City Builder, RTS and Trade Sim. Unlike traditional city builders, Anno 2070 has warfare. If warfare isn't your thing, you can play a peaceful game or you can eliminate your enemies through economic policy (hostile takeover). A hostile takeover is not as intricate as it sounds because all it involves is buying out enemy island shares until you have greater than 50% but, it adds another unique aspect to Anno 2070 game-play.Another feature that sets Anno 2070 apart from other city builders is that you, the player, have 100% control over everything that is constructed. Compared to traditional city builders where the AI constructs buildings after the player zones an area for residential/commercial/industrial--Anno 2070 gives the player COMPLETE control over all structures: construction, destruction and placement. This is the perfect feature of the anal-retentive City-Building fanatic because it allows the control freak to CONTROL!Placing buildings in Anno 2070 is almost like playing a puzzle game. Its always good to maximize space so when you're building in Anno 2070, be prepared to destroy and rebuild. I have over 200 hours in my current continuous game and I've rebuilt each of my major cities 3 times. I also razed and rebuilt the entire power grid across all 29 of my islands (largest map size). The reason for the rebuilding is pretty simple--I keep thinking of better and more efficient ways build, produce goods and house my citizens. My 3 largest cities started with max populations of: 29,000, 29,500 and 34,000 and each of them barely had enough power to keep on the lights. Now, those same islands boast populations of 34,500, 37,500 and 40,500 and each island has 1000+ excess power to share with the power grid.Honestly, this game is a blast! The only reason Anno 2070 doesn't have 'Overwhelmingly Positive' reviews is because people hate on the Uplay DRM. I agree that its annoying but, its no reason to avoid one of the best city builder/rts hybrids of all-time.EDIT: I noticed a number of people complaining that Uplay doesn't work for Anno 2070. Since I hadn't played in a few weeks I decided to boot it up and see if there was a problem. Uplay works just fine. The Steam version of Uplay is outdated. You need to update Uplay and everything works just fine.The fix for this is so simple its mind boggling how many people fail to see it when its mentioned in numerous threads within the community hub. I know the Steam fan-boy knee-jerk reaction is to hate/blame any third party DRM so I guess I shouldn't be so surprised.EDIT 10/17/2015: I see the reviews for this game keep slipping BUT not because the game-play is bad. The reviews are slipping because a bunch of ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥Steam fan-boys hate Uplay DRM. Sorry boys but, Uplay works just fine and has done ZERO to inhibit my Anno 2070 gaming experience.UPDATE 11/24/2016: Anno 2070 is still the best City Builder on Steam but, it doesn't matter because the Steam fanboys hate Uplay which, means, according to the fanboys, that Anno 2070 is a bad game.

												I love playing this game. However, there's a very big problem with trying to play it. Shortly after acquiring the game, I got a new graphics card so I could attempt to run this on max graphics. However, I didn't realize that a "SolidShield" function would block me from playing the game. In addition to this, the game likes to crash. In my 70 odd hours of playing, the most I could play consecutively was maybe an hour and a half to two hours. My 70 hour campaign looks like a 40 hour campaign because of all the time I lost from crashing.There's one other outstanding problem with this game - the online play is awful.Back when I bought this game (quite a while ago), when you invited your friends (lets say you're inviting 3), only 1 could get in and the other two would error out and not be able to join. The chances of getting all 3 players in were very slim, and if you wanted to save and come back to the game later, you'd have to go through the cumbersome process all over again.There is an online DRM for this game that many seem to complain about, and I don't blame them. Having a game, specifically this one where you're in it for hours not interacting with others, is redundant. Ubisoft's stance on piracy and their expensive games have lead to this online DRM for practically every one of their games nowadays. If Ubisoft fixes crashing bugs and if you don't upgrade your computer hardware while wanting to play this game, I'd recommend it. Unfortunetly, the bugs have been present for a long while and I doubt they'll be fixed, so I'm inclined to write this game a nevative review.

number of helpful: 60 of 81 people (74%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 27, 2013
												It seems that most people not recommending this game are actually doing so on the basis of its 4th Party DRM; while archaic and utterly infuriating, being that Steam is already 3rd Party DRM, it does not reflect on the game itself.Anno 2070 is a beautiful open world city-building game with many different strategy aspects intertwined. Think of it like a far more advanced, far more stable, version of Sim City, with missions, singleplayer, NPCs, combat, and trading. Not to mention underwater city building.You can choose from 2 factions in game - An ecologist faction and a trade faction, each one with its advantages and disadvantages. As the environment plays a fairly key role in the game, your decisions as to how your islands develop and the pollution they produce can seriously affect end-game production, as more and more buildings are required to cope with the diminished returns of crops and livestock. However, pollution is necessary for supplies and income to be produced en masse; you, the player, must decide on how you choose to build up your city(s)Anno 2070's soundtrack is nice, without being too overbearing; it's certainly more mellow than other games, but for good reason. It's a nice listen, and I never play the game with music set to off.The game's graphics still look beautiful, even for a game that is 2 years old. The lighting and shadow effects are phenomenal, with water rendering that doesn't much detract from my FPS. What isn't shown in the screenshots is the underwater portions of the game, in that you can build supply depots and other research facilities under the sea. I strongly suggest if you're interested in that sort of thing you look up a video on it, it's rather amazing.Overall, the game is fun, very fun, enough to warrant a solid 8.5/10 from me; its seemingly laidback start to any game belies a hidden undertone of complexity not seen in most city building games such as this one.

number of helpful: 57 of 84 people (68%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 28, 2013
												Anno2070 is an economic game with Tier based progress system and basic elements of combat.The game has decent Video, Music and Interface settings. At highest settings with "i5-2500K @ 3.30GHz", "GeForce GTX 560 Ti" on 1920x1080 I have significant frame rate drop, but nothing unplayable. At just high settings it looks fine and works excellent.You have key bindings for the most useful actions, but any nondefault settings are stored on server, which means you have to reconfigure them for each offline session.Game launches via Uplay client. It is weird to see 2 game clients while playing Anno2070.The story is about the future with rised level of sea. The gameplay is based around island colonization (including underwater plateaus), building cities and product chains.You have 3 playable factions: Tycoons (or Global Trust - industrial conglomerate), Eco ( or Edem Initiative - global environment organisation) and Tech (or S.A.A.T - faction of scientists). There are third parties you may interact with during missions. There are aggresive parties, parties that are good for trade relationship, some may colonize islands. You may declare a war or do thier quests and gain reputation which gives access to different functions.Ingame progress is usually the next one: setup Tier1 residences, goods and construstion material production; evolve to Tier2, setup Tier2 residences, goods and construstion material production and so on till Tier4. The difficulty rises with Tier progression because productions may require resources from different islands, you have to extend productions of previous Tiers and do not forget to upgrade residences, and everything requiers certain mount of construction materials at certain place. AFAIK there is no way to tell how much goods does population need and how much production you should build in order to support it. There is no even ingame indication how much ihabitances, let say, Tea plantation may support. You have to use some wiki information and demand calculator for it.Even so it seems very tence, at practis it takes a huge amount of time to reach late state of the game. Pure rush to Tier4 can take 1-1.5 hours.Tech faction has interesting ability to research stuff (surprise!). It can give you items to boost production, extend raw matherial deposits, upgrades for your Ark etc.Ark is basically your cross-mission storage for goods and upgrades which is available from the beginning of the mission. In some situations Ark functionality is partially unavailable.There are natural disasters like Acid rains and Tornados. The last one can be very devastating. Your Nuclear Power Station can even explode and cause Nuclear Fallout if you are not careful.The Combat system is presented by ships, aircrafts and submarines with their strengths and weaknesses. For the late game there are also nuclear missiles and power shields available.The game also offers achievement system and Career progress with some unlocks like titles, skins for your avatar, Ark, some useful buildings and researches for Ark upgrade.There are daily quests and World Events to help your Career progress. World Event offers new Easy, Medium and Hard missions chain with unlocks that depends on type of Event.The game has Campaign, Continous mission, Single Missions and Domination mode.- Campaign is basically a big tutorial, has generic plot with its silly moments, but is ok, gives you a feeling of being involved in saving the world... again ;)- Continous mission is a mission created by player with wide variety of customization like third parties, amount of resources, win conditions etc. You may also make it as multiplayer by inviting people.- Single Missions are basically predefined Continous missions. Some of them can bring a real challange like "Power Games", so if you beat it you are somewhat prepared for the Domination mode.- Domination mode is where currently all peolpe are playing. It is a passive team multiplayer. You have map with different missions. Domination conflict has its length and time limit per day. If you don't spend all your day limit, it will transfer to the next day. You compete in achieving scores with specific goals like achieve Balance value, energy production, trade balance etc. You cannot meet neither your competitor nor teammate directly in mission. Once you get more scores than your opponent, you dominate mission and receive bonus scores. The winner is a team with the most scores at the end of conflict.The problem with this mode is that most conflicts have 12 hours/day setting and usually the winner is not the skilled one but the one who spent the most its time. Also there is some domination rating, which AFAIK affects nothing. So unless you play versus skilled players (which are usually attracted by 1 hour/day setting) purely for fun, it quickly becomes boring.The music is awesome! For 200+ hours of gaming I didn't get bored. It is very thematic and atmospheric.Anno 2070 has fair Business model which does not break game balance. It offers bonus contents which otherwise are available by compliting specific World Event or getting specific achievement.If you like complex economy management, sick multitasking, strategic planing and step-by-step growth with Tier unlock, this is definitely for you. If you find yourself in situation when game says you "Dude, you have been playing for 6 hours! Stop it!", then you know this is your game!

												I only have 3 words to say :Don't Buy It.Even if it was thrown to you as a gift, don't use it, stay away like it's an infectious plague.Now, here is the reason why :I will not extend myself on the game, as it is probably nicier and more fun than I could even imagine. And it pain me that I could not play it.BUT to play this game you have to install UPLAY and bend over to what ever decision Ubisoft make. And don't get me wrong. I don't mind a 'nicely done DRM that treat the customer right'. But I don't support DRM done wrong that consider every single buyer to be 'potential pirate'.The fact that Ubisoft want every of their players connected constantly is only the proof they are completely out of their mind. They have imposed real bad DRM over the years (the destructive Starforce for example) and they have pushed the whole system over the edge.Mixing a limit of 3 activation for a game, with the need to be constantly online is just.... how to say.... feeling like I need to pee in the check tube every time I connect to my computer and have the police of the town authorizing me to move around with an electronic bracer and a tailing car. To emphasis this, when I added the game in my wishlist, the page was not 'clearly' indicating the 3rd party and 3 activation limits.But when a friend offered the game to me, for my birthday, I first though "nice, will finally try it", before finding out it was asking for Uplay.Having had my share of problem with Uplay with Assassin's Creed (preventing me from playing through the first, and even killing any desire I could have to try to play to the second and 3rd that I bought), I felt forced to install it nonetheless as it was a 'gift'. The only way to show them the light, is to vote with your wallet.Exert your right to put bad companies out of buisness with your wallet.

number of helpful: 23 of 28 people (82%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: September 4, 2016
												I really don't get why so many people seem to hate Anno 2070. I really don't. And trust me, my play-time here on steam is nowhere NEAR accurately representative of how much time I've ACTUALLY spent playing it, so I've had more than enough time to explore this game.Anyway... as I was saying. I won't go so far as to say that Anno 2070 is perfect, but frankly, it does a lot of things so göddämn right that I can't help but wonder just WHY people hate it so much. I guess, and this really is petty even by MY standards, it's because you need Uplay to play it. A very VERY small price to pay in my opinion, since you already bought it on steam, now didn't you, ya daft bastärd?! Or maybe you didn't. I dunno. Either way...Graphics-wise, the game may be similar to 1404, its predecessor, but aside from a few VERY shallow similarities, that's the only things they really have in common. Let's first take a look at the resource system. In 1404, it was REALLY arbitrary and kinda silly how resources worked. For starters, how the flippety fûck-balls on shït-toast does it make ANY kinda sense that you can replenish a copper mine by paying money? And I'm not talking about some roundabout thing either. You literally just click on the mine, click a "replenish" button or something, and PRESTO!! Mine's full of shït to extract.Nah, in 2070, it's a bit more sensically designed. If your island is running low on copper, you get a laboratory to hook you up with a drill-thing-item-gadget-thing which digs the mine(s) deeper and thusly uncovers new deposits of that brownish stuff. Which makes a whole lotta more sense than just throwing an arbitrary sum of money down your mineshaft which then MAGICALLY transforms into clusters of copper ore.But I digress... the game's been upgraded in terms of, well, pretty much everything, really. Instead of there being only two playable factions like in 1404, there are now THREE playable factions!! Okay, so that's maybe not that huge of a change, but since the Orientals in 1404 were barely more than a vestigial "resource outpost" type thing, I'd say the change is a bit more than just a cosmetic upgrade.The very well-established contrast between the factions makes for an interesting setup as well. Will you play as the E.I., or Eden Initiative, a bunch of tree-hugging hippies, which're also eco-terrorists with a penchant for mischief "in the name of mother earth"? Or will you favour the hard-hitting, fast-talking, no-nonsense G.T., or Global Trust, a heartlessly huge and hugely heartless mega-corporation, for whom pure profits outweigh all else?Joining these two morally ambiguous groups of lunatics are the S.A.A.T., a faction comprised almost entirely of engineers, scientists and other "scholarly types" of varying backgrounds. But they're depicted as a sort of aloof, "science above all" bunch of technocrats, who'd forego both a positive eco-balance AND a positive bank-balance if it meant they'd get their hands on some sweet new tech.So with all that in mind, the game is WAY less "black & white", what with all the morally questionable characters in it. And on that note, there are WAY more NPC dudes (and dudettes) in 2070 as well! Trenchcoat is my personal favourite; a sort of shady black market dealer who's refurbished an old aircraft carrier to use for shipping and dealing his questionable merchandise. Fun guy.Which reminds me of something that I REALLY appreciate about 2070 compared to 1404. Now, as those of you who've played 1404 knows, you could customize your flag/crest/emblem/whateveryacallit, your player colour and your portrait in the game, but these things were all acquired by buying them with some arbitrary bullshït "gems" you got for achieving stuff in the game. "Plant 100 flowerbeds!" and get 10 stinkin' gems. Nevermind the fact that you needed 200 or so of the fûckin' things to get a new portrait!Anyway, back on topic. In 2070, ALL customization items are unlocked by doing specific achievements; some easy, some hard, and some bloody fûckin' impossible. But that only made their associated unlocks all the sweeter! If you could dïck around and do a whole bunch-a easy-peasy-lemon-squeezy achievements and scrounge together some gems or whatever to just BUY the Vadim Sokov portrait, it wouldn't be at all special. But no, in 2070, ya gotta EARN your stuff!Which I obviously like. Achievements are all fun 'n' such on their own, but I find them to be WAY more interesting and compelling to go for when you get some kinda REWARD for 'em.Oh yeah, and there's a political aspect in 2070 now. D'ya remember those things in 1404, those unlocks you could spend your Honour Points on to unlock some vague benefits per game? Well, now there's a different thing available: faction progression. By doing daily quests, voting, and partaking in events, you can gain points with the three major factions, E.I., G.T., and S.A.A.T., which in turn awards you with various cool stuff.These include (but are not limited to): player profile customization items, various tech unlocks, and new arks to use. Oh yeah, that's something new to the series: arks. They're this sorta... base-thingamajig, that you can use to store goods (if you're kinda thick, since things can't be used when in the ark's storage), and order emergency shipments of goods as well. Anything and everything stored within the ark will be available in other missions as well, so it's sorta like a mobile player storage bank thing.Furthermore, if your last command ship (basic military unit) gets destroyed, you can order a new one at your ark for a hefty sum of credits, but no resource cost. Another benefit that replaced the attainments in 1404 is the Ark Upgrades, which is a collection of various items which gives you small but powerful (and GLOBAL) power-ups/boosts, such as lower maintenance costs on ALL units in the sector, or higher productivity for ALL farms in the sector. There are even ones, incredibly powerful but also hard-as-hell to get, that makes your cities IMMUNE to disease, fire or even crime!But anyway... moving on. I honestly don't know if 1404 had a co-op mode for multiplayer games, but if it didn't, then that's also an awesome new feature in 2070. How it works is that you actually DO NOT play as a faction each and then co-operate, each player controlling their own team, but rather that you and 1 (or more) other player(s) share control over the same team in the game. Needless to say, this is awesome for when you wanna teach your newbie friend how to NOT ♥♥♥♥♥ up in the game, without having to stand around behind 'em the whole damn time, pointing at the screen like you're trying to teach your 89 year old grandma how to do even basic computer stuff. Stupid old people.Where was I... oh, right. Yeah. Multiplayer! You can play with up to 8 distinct players/teams/factions/whateveryacallit in multiplayer now, so it can get pretty damn hectic if you let it, and with the added benefit of co-op, you can have 2-3 newbie players teaming up against 1 seasoned veteran without unbalancing the game too much, units-wise.Anyway, I think I'll be done rambling now, but if you're one of those lazy shïtwads who can't read, what... 12 lousy li'l paragraphs of text? Well then, fûck you and your laziness! That said, aside from Uplay, there is no reason WHATSOEVER not to give Anno 2070 a try. It's cheap, it's fun, it's moderately addictive, it's highly replayable and it's definitely worth a measly ten bucks/euros/whatever barbarian currencies are used elsewhere. 8.8/10

content:
Posted: April 30, 2016
												I purchased this game in 2011. I have never been able to launch it (I can get into the main menu). I have tried numerous times in five years. Ubisoft DRM stops me everytime. You can see I have 3.5 hours of time in-game. That's time spent attempting to connect to Ubisoft's servers, and also time the game (at the main menu) has been minimized while I've been troubleshooting. Nothing. Numerous support tickets over the years have not even yielded a single response. I have one open now that's been unanswered for a few hours shy of a week. Worse, I am not an exception to these issues. 62% of ~7000 reviews are positive, and quickly scanning the negative reviews shows that a large number of paying customers share this problem. That's at least 2500 customers that Ubisoft has basically written off over the years, and it doesn't even include the customers who don't own the game on Steam or haven't given it a thumbs up/thumbs down. That's bad. I wouldn't chance this if I were you.Edit: For anyone that's curious, after ten days I finally received a response from Ubisoft support. I was told I need to activate the game on Steam. In fairness, I'm not sure I made it perfectly clear in the support ticket that the game is installed on Steam, so I messaged them back. We'll see where it goes. It is worth noting I think the ticket classification which is essentially "key is already in use" corresponds with an error message you get in-game that tells you all the same. This is why I didn't specify in the ticket, as I thought it was obvious. If I was having an issue activating a game on Steam, I certainly would be contacting Steam. Ubisoft's prescribed steps don't even seem to work, as the Steam Product Activator doesn't recognize the CD key string as a valid string. Indeed, given the sheer number of reviews complaining about having the exact same problem I am having, you'd think Ubisoft would... well...

content:
Posted: February 1, 2014
												Anno 2070 is a complex game it takes a RTS (real time strategy) to a new level.  But if you love building cities, having limited resources, and limited land this game is for you.  Took me more then a few restarts to get a feel for this game but its so beautiful when it all comes together.  Its all about making do with what your granted and balancing it with the environment, and keeping your citizens happy with supply and demand so they can improve so you can improve.   Also lets not forget about the trade because that island next you more then likely has something you want be it rice, sugar, oil you get the idea.  This game is a must for any true die hard RTS gamer or even the casual RTS gamer but don't get your panties in a bunch cause you fail.  You need patience and understanding and the willingness to scrap your game and start over to achieve greatness in this game.

content:
Posted: September 11, 2016
												Most of the negative reviews are for the uplay, not the game itself.So if you are not having any issue with uplay, just ignore it.The game itself is actually pretty good and looks beautiful.A rather complex city builder game with lots of things to handle/manage: economy, military, technology, and a little bit of diplomacy.IMO the main asset of the game is its economy, how you handle your goods, production, trade between island, your city/island planning.Creating a whole chain of production and how to distribute it.In a nutshell it's like logictic simulator.There are a 2 big factions that approach things differently, so you have to choose where you gonna start. One is "go green" kind of people and the other is "max productivity" kind people, each got its own advantages.And 1 more faction to expand your tech (science faction), both previous faction will gain access to this in mid game.----The campaign mission is doing a poor job at explaining the game and make it looks like a bad city builder game for starter.At first I drop this game because of the mission.But after trying to go on the skrimish/free sandbox mode, I change my mind.After you begin to understand how the game works, it's getting better and better.And afterward playing the missions are becoming a lot more fun to do, it gives you challenges and objectives.There are world events & world leader vote too. Not too important, but definitely add value to the game.----I'll recommend this game to those who love city builder games which have goods production in it, like caesar, civcity rome, banished, etc.I won't reccomend this if you only like city builder games which only have public services building in it, like simcity, cities skylines, etc.

number of helpful: 28 of 43 people (65%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 8, 2014
												This game reminds me of Caeser, Pharoah, and the other economy-based city-builders of the 90's and early 2000's. I haven't played any other Anno games so I cannot comment on if this is a good or bad Anno game, but I've really enjoyed it. You have to build a city while managing a bunch of different resources, which are used to upgrade your city and advance up the technology chain. You can only get certain resources from some islands, so you need to either expand your empire or trade with other players. It's a little complex, and it can get very overwhelming in the late game when you are dealing with many islands and every resource, but it's really satisftying when everything clicks into place and you have a functioning chain of islands.The big downside is the Uplay DRM. It's actually problem-free for me, but I can't deny that it is utterly useless. It runs in the background for no real reason, and you need to sign up for a Uplay account. If you're lucky like I am, that's all the  interaction you'll need to do with Uplay. I know some people have an avalanche of problems, so your mileage may vary.Get the Deep Sea expansion, because it adds a whole new faction to the game and it feels incomplete without it.I'm not sure if the campaign really goes anywhere, and the bulk of the game seems to be based around the sandbox-esque continuous game mode. So, if you're looking for goals and missions, you might want to look elsewhere. If you like managing cities and supply lines, and micromanagement is your game, you'll probably have a great time here.

number of helpful: 45 of 75 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 14, 2014
												Anno 2070 is a hybrid resource management, city building sim and RTS by Ubisoft. Using futuristic technology, you must build a city to complete various goals while balancing the favor of three factions.The main campaign for Anno 2070 revolves around a rogue A.I. and the steps that you must take to protect your people while solving the puzzle of how to defeat it. The story is told through in game events as you complete quests, and through pre and post mission cutscenes. While story can be somewhat secondary in these types of games, I found it rather compelling and was definitely interested in what would happen next.For the campaign mode, you will be designing your city so that you can complete certain goals given to you by one of three factions, which are representative of business, technology and environment. Towards later missions you will be balancing the needs of multiple factions, whose unique buildings or abilities you will need to complete your quests. Since your city is persistent through multiple levels, this can create some issues while you are planning. You may spend one whole mission optimizing your city for the tech faction, only to find out later that you will need high level buildings from the business faction to continue. Your cities are mostly built on islands, and square footage is at a premium, so this can be problematic. Luckily for the most part there is not much of a penalty for having to tear down a building to place something new in its place, but still you can find yourself having spent hours designing a city perfectly just to find out later you have to tear it down.Game balance is done very well. You will need to provide your citizens with certain goods, depending on what faction they are from, and most of these goods can be manufactured in your buildings. You will need to balance your cash, power supply and ecobalance to complete each mission, and luckily there are generally ways to increase each if you are patient.Graphics are top notch, as our sound effects and voice acting. A lot of effort was put into the creation of this game, and it shows.After completing the main storyline, there is still plenty to accomplish. There are council votes which you can participate in, and will give you bonuses to certain factions. There are many scenarios to play through. The main story can take you upwards of 20 hours or more to complete, and if you still want more to do, more is available.Overall, I would completely recommend Anno 2070. It has that one more turn mentality that can keep you hooked for hours at a time. There is so much to do even after the main campaign that you will definitely get your money's worth. Anno 2070 is highly polished, well balanced, and very, very entertaining.Score: A-

number of helpful: 44 of 74 people (59%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 26, 2014
												Beautiful, Smooth, and Enjoyable. Unlike other strategy games like Civilization, Meridian: New World, Starcraft, etc, this game focues on more realistic ideals. Economy, Citizens, Resources, and the Environment are the main aspects. Now you may say that this game sounds like any other, but it focuses on these aspects greatly. You can't just build a mine on a resource and expect it to instantly be accessible and have the resource flowing to your city. Time el facto is one thing, it takes time for resources to go from point a to point b. Citizens have needs and there are different demographics for citizens. They level up as you fulfill there desires earning you more technology and resources. The economy is based on your tax income and expenses. Unit maintenance, citizen's needs, tax rates, and trade all affect tax income. The important part is the environment. Disasters, cities, units, and resources are affected by how polluted or clean the environment is. Great game, Co-op is good, everything is good.

												Both the game as an entertainment piece and as a product should be reviewed and considered when deciding whether or not to give money to the people who made it.In this case, they will treat you like you are a thief by default with a broken 3rd party DRM. You can end up locked out of your game and having to go through to a customer support nightmare to prove you own this legitimately. Surprisingly, this is a problem a pirate will never have. Which begs the question: why did they put this DRM in the first place?The game is all right, but as with much of what they publish, not worth having to deal with Ubisoft.Overzealous publishers need to either remove their games from Steam to avoid two pieces of DRM conflicting or to remove theirs and trust Steam (which is light years ahead in my opinion).If you're really keen on this game I'd suggest getting it directly on Uplay or elsewhere.

number of helpful: 13 of 17 people (76%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 27, 2016
												This is not a bad game if you can manage to launch it.When you install the game, do not launch it. If you do, uPlay will crash on start. Go to the uPlay site and create an account if you don't already have one. Add the game to your account from the uPlay web site. Download the uPlay launcher from the web site and install it on top of the one included in the Steam version. If you don't follow these steps, uPlay will repeatedly crash and you won't be able to play at all.The single player missions are tough and actually require strategy and a grasp of the economy. You will run out of money and you will try many different strategies to scrape together the cash you need to continue. This is essentially a city builder with a great deal of micromanagement, not a war game.As you progress, game elements and enhancements can be unlocked with points earned. An internal voting system exists for everyone playing through uPlay to elect factions which provide various buffs. Unfortunately, uPlay's internal achievements and points system don't allow for Steam cards or achievements.If you can get past the extremely frustrating nuisance that is uPlay and manage the steep learning curve, you will enjoy the game.

content:
Posted: February 11
												I really wanted to get into this series of games, I've been watching a lot of YouTube tutorials/reviews because I like to be an informed buyer and know what I'm doing once it's started up. No where did I see anything that foreshadowed the hell I was about to endure. After buying and installing the game I was prompted to install a third party launcher called Uplay, alright that's fine, I've had to install these before so it's not much of an issue. After entering the CD key on Steam to activate the download I was asked to provide the key again for Uplay, okay cool. After launching the game I was ONCE AGAIN prompted to enter the key, however, there was a message. In the area where I was supposed to enter the key it said, "No SolidShield." This is where the issues begin. After entering my key for the THIRD TIME, I was told it was already in use by another Uplay member. I don't understand this, I'm logged into Steam, I'm logged into Uplay, both of them have the game activated using the key provided through steam but I still can't play?You'll see I have 4 hours on record, the entire 4 hours come from me troubleshooting. I never got past the login screen. I'm starting to hate how Ubisoft won't let me skip their logo, (I just wanna get to the log-in screen to verify that Ubisoft is trash and it won't let me play, cause let's face it, after 4 hours of forums and support pages, even a ticket to Ubisoft, it's not gonna work).Here's a list of everything I've tried from first to last, as best I can remember.> Running Anno 2070 from Steam.> Running Anno 2070 from Uplay.> Running Anno5.exe as Administrator.> Running Anno5.exe as Administrator in compatibility mode.> Running Uplay.exe as Administrator.Somewhere I read having the Uplay and SolidShield folders in Program Files will cause issues.> Reinstalled Anno 2070, Uplay and SolidShield to my Desktop.> Continued to get "No SolidShield." > Uninstalled and reinstalled SolidShield.> Continued to get "No SolidShield."> Uninstalled Anno 2070 from Steam and downloaded directly from Uplay.> Continued to get "No SolidShield."I've been all over the Steam forums, Ubisoft forums, even some lesser known forums, trying to find an answer. There are countless threads of people having the same issue, one customer I saw had been waiting over two weeks for a response to his ticket. Some customers aren't getting responses at all. Some people posted in 2015 and followed up late 2016 just to inform others that their game still doesn't work and they haven't found a fix.TL;DR - I'm envious of those who get to enjoy these games, they look amazing, but I will never make another purchase from Ubisoft. This is ridiculous, completely unprofessional. I'd expect this from an early access developer and wouldn't be angry, but this is a major international developer with studios in 18 different countries. Pathetic.

number of helpful: 16 of 23 people (70%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 23, 2015
												I don't know how to review Anno 2070.  The game isn't for everyone.  It's a complex logistics chain simulator, in essence.  The game focuses very little on 'city-building', in actuality.  The primary focus that consumes the game is production chain management.  You have limited space, and multiple islands, and you have to get raw resource A polished into finished good B, and then get B delivered to the particular population that is demanding the good.The game has many other elements, including building cities.   It has a lot of beautification and aesthetic items you can add.  It's the best of the Anno series I've played thus far.Essentially, if you like making a well-oiled machine and watching the beautiful results of said machine, you'll like this game.  If you don't like managing supply chains and trade routes, you won't like this game.I adore this game.

number of helpful: 15 of 22 people (68%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 25
												The game is top notch. One of my favorites. I was initially skeptical about buying this game due to the barrage of negative reviews regarding Uplay. But then, getting the complete edition in $2 is a steal for a game of this caliber. So I went ahead and bought the game. Although I was fearful that the DRM would screw this one for me, but to my delight nothing of this sort happened. The installation went smooth. No issues with Uplay launcher, CD-keys or anything for that matter. I suppose all you need is a really good internet connection so that everything goes uninterrupted. I agree that it took around 20-30 minutes to initialize the game at first run. But it was worth the wait and now I am running the game smooth as butter. For all the fans of city building games, this is definitely a must have. Notes :- I will explain how the installation went for me, for the reason it might help the first timers and also those who are facing issues.1. Downloaded and installed the game on Steam. Copied the CD-key for future use.2. Uplay took a while to download, logged in with my account.3. The game was not in my Uplay library. So instead of activating a key in Uplay, I simply ran the game from Steam. Now a popup appeared telling me that the game will be linked to this Uplay account.4. The autopatcher downloaded a lot of files, updating the game to the latest patch.5. Ran the game. A pop up appeared again with "No SolidShield" written in the box. I just erased the text and typed the CD key in the given format (xxxx-xxxx-xxxx-xxxx).6. Voila! The game is activated and good to go.

content:
Posted: July 4, 2015
												I'm starting this review off by saying that as a newcomer to the Anno series, I really enjoyed this game. The production chain building and shipping from island to island is well done and is quite fun. It also offers a surprising amount of replayability. Also unlike some other old Ubisoft titles (Endwar springs to mind) the serverside portion of the game (voting on events, timed missions, ect) is still running and offers a good shakeup. Its worth noting that I haven't tried the domination multiplayer gamemode, but it looks like it is very good. I unfortunatly can't comment on the graphics because every computer I've run this game on is a potatoe, but thats my problem.Onto what caused so many people to vote this game down, the DRM. I personally haven't had any trouble with it but I installed Uplay before hand because of other games, so I don't speak for the majority of the playerbase aparently. The elephant in the room, Tages, almost never caused me problems and when it did it was understandable. The only time I ran into an issue was when I was messing about with VM's and I only ran into the problem on the 5th VM try. All it took to fix it was talking to ubisoft support to get it sorted out, and I haven't had a problem since.All in all, near perfect game (the combat is very obviously not the focus of gameplay or design work) with a little bit of annoyance related to DRM, but nothing that even got me close to upset. I'd recomend this game at anything up to $45, as the amount of enjoyment you can get out of it is amazing.

number of helpful: 15 of 23 people (65%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 28, 2013
												Anno 2070 is very much like it's predecessors, however, the polished look and feel of the interface, nicely balanced units, and cross building between the various careers (factions), and coupled with that ever so slight appeal of future tech and possible future make it shine all on it's own.For those who don't know, the Anno series is a city builder / real-time strategy game, leaning a bit more heavily on the builder aspects. Managing the needs of your sector and cities within can sometimes be a juggling act in itself. If you're looking for the pace and speed of say Command & Conquer or Starcraft. This isn't for you. If liked those games, and also liked things like SimCity or other builders I think you'll enjoy this.The amazing emmersive soundtrack, and top notch voice work, splended visuals, and solid gameplay really add up to an enjoyable experience be it for a quick daily mission game or, whole evening dive into continuous play. With multiple game modes, multiplayer drop-in, world-events, user interactions through elections and making choses, advancing up your career ladder. The Anno 2070 is a game that could keep you busy for months.

number of helpful: 8 of 10 people (80%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 20, 2015
												When there are so many great features in Anno 2070, why am I saying "Not Recommended"? I'm a lover of older city builder / production chain games. Unfortunately in Anno 2070, the campaign got in my way: instead of having time to learn the ropes, experiment, and calculate building production, I was almost immediately forced into a time-critical deficit situation. For me, at least, it took out the parts I find fun about city builders. There are lots of other ways to play Anno 2070, so I imagine it will work better for other styles of play. Certainly, with the three types of economies, the multiplayer features, and the frequent "event" chapters, there is a lot to do. But for me, I found the introduction frustrating enough that it's been hard to enjoy any of the rest of it, even with 30 hours to get used to it.

content:
Posted: July 6, 2016
												The reviews are NOT over-sensationalizing uPlay; it's the most needlessly complicated registration system out there that can prevent you from ever playing the game. I should know because I just got off the phone with Ubisoft customer support after being locked out of an account I tried to create. Not only does your account get banned, but you IP address will get banned so that you can't play the game, cannot log into your account for support or  cannot log-in to ubisoft for chat help or even see their 'help' section. I had to browse through steam forums to find a local number to call because the 888 (toll free) number I found on the forum redirects you to the support website (which doesn't work unless you log in.) It just says that 'You broke the internet.' Not very funny, Ubisoft.I had a u-play account, but I wasn't sure what password I used. Not only that, but I wasn't sure which of my emails I used. After my third attempt at the combo, everything became banned for a minimum of 2 hours to an alleged max of 24 hours. So don't plan anything around playing a game from ubiSoft.This is the first time I ever had to leave a review for a game I haven't had a chance to play. The antiquated system and poor planning that this company uses to prevent account phishing and pirating is helping no  one - not the consumers and NOT the company. It's alienating gamers and turning people off from playing their games. Read through other comments about U PLAY and please be advised that these are not just highly-dramatized gripes. People legitimately cannot get access through U Play. The customer support cannot unlock your account, help you register your new game or even tell you how long it will take before you are able to log in. And try to log in again too soon... BAM, block timer reset. 0 stars out of 100.

content:
Posted: January 30, 2015
												I was really impressed with my first impression... The single player campagin starts as the corporate tycoons exploiting the earths resources, you can see the beautiful environment slowly fade and erode into nothingness. An island that once was inhabited by deer and bears becomes barren and the beautiful seascape of whales and dolphins becomes empty... This is until the game introduces the environmentally friendly faction which attempts to establish a balance with nature, with a slower production rate, yet sustainable resource consumption rate. So far the game seems incredible, until they introduce the second campaign... there are so many random events with litttle to no explaination of solving them... such as poison fish, special build technologies, or most frustratingly telling you oil is available and buildable until a special event occurs. For a tutorial based campagin, all this game does, is confuse me... After roughly 10 hours I am confused and annoyed.

content:
Posted: January 1
												Deep and intricate city builder/supply chain manager game. The learning curve is a bit steep at first, but once you get the hang of it it'll be second nature.  I hadn't played it in almost a year and I came back to it with zero need for a refresher course.  It is fantastic, beautiful, relaxing, and once you know where everything is - intuitive.  As with any Ubisoft game it is tied to Uplay, but this is something I've learned to accept.  I had given this game a negative review long ago because of the Uplay attachment, but mostly because at the time it also had a limit of downloads, making it essentially a rental rather than a purchase.  Yesterday when I downloaded it again I saw no mention of this limit.  Kudos Uplay.  At it's regular price it is a steal, and I wholeheartedly recommend it if you are looking for an intricate builder/manager game with minimal combat [if you're playing outside of the campaign, combat becomes entirely optional].  Would definitely recommend looking up some tutorials on youtube though.

content:
Posted: April 17, 2016
												I don't usually like to write reviews. When I write them, its hard to put my thoughts into words because my understanding of a game is almost always different than another person's understanding. Nonetheless, I need to write a review for Anno 2070 because i've spent enough time with this game to put my thoughts into words. TL;DR is at the bottom if you want it.I'll start with what most people consider the deal-breaker with Anno 2070, which is Ubisoft and their toadies Blue Byte and Related Design. Ubisoft, in their *infinite* knowledge, decided to shoehorn in their UPlay DRM for what seems to be no reason. In fact, all it does is break the game for some and make another hoop to jump through for others. Either way, its annoying. But reviews on Steam aren't gonna stop them, so I won't drag on about them.But I will drag on about Blue Byte and Related Design. If these guys weren't owned by Ubisoft, I can make a safe bet that if these guys were runned by a more consumer-friendly company, than we wouldn't see issues like losing integral parts of the game overtime or having to jump through hoops to get the game running. But the problem is that these developers are too afraid of telling Ubisoft to shove-it, so we end up with all these issues in their games. I know that both of these developers can produce very amazing games, but because they can't be self aware we end up with carcasses of games overtime.Enough about the people, let's get to the game. It is basically the mammoth of the Anno 2070 franchise. More factions, more AI competitors, more goods, more everything! This was my first Anno game, and although it was a little overwhelming at first, I got the hang of it after a while. This game is luckily very well polished, and has been updated overtime to make a better experience. The soundtrack, graphics, and mechanics are all top notch. I couldn't have asked for anything more. I'm not gonna get into the gameplay, but once you look on YouTube or you play the campaign it'll become easy to get the hang of. I do want to warn you though that certain features are just plain different from when the older videos were made or when the campaign was made. As of writing this review for the game I am in the works of creating an updated tutorial/let's play for anyone who wants to get into this game now. That may be available at some point.Let's just address some new things before I end this review. The DLC is certainly worth it, and expands the game so much you can't resist. It will make your life easier. However, the only DLC you may want is the Deep Ocean expansion. The rest is just little cosmetics or things that will be a minor benefactor in the end. As for the current state of the game, they removed the 'World Events' system, which is a little bit of a pain, but you'll probably still be okay. The best part of Anno 2070, in my opinion, is the experience building and nuturing a whole civilization. That won't ever be going away, so if you wish to share that experience, then this game is certainly for you.TL;DR: Although Ubisoft and their Toadies are a pain, the actual game is a breath-taking experience that will be a staple of the city builder for a long time.

number of helpful: 10 of 14 people (71%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 23
												This has to be one of my favorite games of all time - I've played it every now and again for years now. Anno 2070 is a city builder/management game. The management game is stronger than the city builder, which is good because I prefer to look at graphs and optimize workflows rather than make traffic flow properly or design something pretty. But that's just me.The soundtrack is wonderful. I listen to it on my own periodically and I have for the past couple of years since I heard it for the first time. I would say that playing Anno 2070 is a thoroughly peaceful experience which tests the mind's puzzle solving and planning abilities rather than reflexes. But it's also really beautiful.It's like cities skylines with less traffic, or roller coaster tycoon with more management and less design. If you like games like those you'll probably like this one, too.

content:
Posted: November 25, 2016
												Though it might not be as visually charming as Anno 1404 (also known as Dawn of Discovery for some people), Anno 2070 is still lovely in its futuristic way. I've had a lot of fun playing this with my husband, both of us cooperatively building our "empire" together. The production chains are always fun to figure out, and trying to get things running as efficiently and effectively as possible is very satisfying. It's one of those games where you think to yourself, "ok, I'm going to play this for 10 more minutes" and then look up and realize that was 2 hours ago. Having to go through Uplay is a bit of an inconvenience, but I don't let that detract from the fun of the game.

Posted: January 3, 2014
												Anno is an RTS god type game that combines the fun of You need a Budget with a game for the UI.  This game is a challenging RTS game, it is NOT a fun RTS game.  Is a challenge fun, of course we love challenges as gamers.  The only challenge is fitting all that stuff onto tiny islands, take away the islands, and there is no challenge.  See that picture for the store page with the boat?  That boat is not in the game, and I never had the fun feeling of waving to anyone in this game.  Because in this game you can't click the little people and see their needs, even roller coaster tycoon games going back 10 years let us click the little people.  The Coconut Queen would be displeased by all this whining from these people wanting more sushi or cell phones, each person wanting like 10 cell phones made me call them Annitches.  Skip this game get Tropico, its super fun caring for little Tropicans as El Presidente, or for a real challenge take on Civ.Buncha Annitches... On that note, play me out Jay-Z in the key of 99 Problems, starting at, "I aint tryin to see no highway chase with Jake"I aint tryin to see all my time go to waste,Plus I got the DLC to make sure I dont wait,So I... played til the game told me, take a break, Son, do you know what I'm stopping you for??Cuz, this sucks, and its boring, and it really does blow,Do I look like I'm havin any fun, I dont know.This game is real long so you should grab some snacks,Well, this aint worth 55 and it aint worth four, Thought I'd play a game, thought I'd have some fun, I'm a fan'a god games, I know alot of you are.Bought this game on steam so I know its legit,Well do you mind letting the game make sure about it?For DRM theres Uplay, with TAGES, on toppa Steam, with over 35 install steps, its justa bad dream.Well, isnt this game full of crap,Everyones a pirate or somethin,Buying games to steal them or something.Well, there aint no tutorials, the game gives no hints,So get used to googling to find tips and tricks.Well, we'll see how smart you are if the day ever comes.Two thousand seventy problems, and this game's number one,If you buy this game, you'll be wishin you bought a gun,Two thousand seventy problems, and this game's number one.Im seriously not joking, Anno aint no fun,Your gonna have a bad time, I feel bad for you son,Don't buy Anno 2070, it sucked, deleted, done...Rating:  2/10  Value:  $2.99
