content:
Posted: July 2, 2015
												Starting up the game is a trial itself. I spent around half an hour just to get it running. And even then, it was riddled with crashes (5 crashes in under 20 min)If anyone is interested in how to get it running at least once:First, I had to enter the key, and wait for the uplay installer to update the recently downloaded game.Then uplay started crashing, had to enter go to the Anno 2070 installation folder, right click the game.exe and set it to win xp compatibility mode. The game will refuse to launch through steam as it will crash on startup, you must open it directly through the game folder game.exe.After setting up the uplay account, which again asked for the key, I was able to start the game.I thought my troubles would end there, however.... The game crashed 4 times in the first campaign mission (3 of which were during the last cinematic, and the fact that Anno doesn't seem to have an auto-save is even more irritating). I inicially thought it was a problem in only the first campaign mission, but the second mission crashed 2 minutes in, I gave up playing after that.Although I played for an extremely limited amount of time, I have to say. Anno 2070 would have been a great game if it were playable, I've seen many early access titles more stable than this game.

number of helpful: 19 of 32 people (59%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 19, 2014
												The climate has changed, sea levels have risen… What a great time for a strategy game! Anno 2070 is a futuristic real-time strategy game focused on city management and colonization. The game provides a good campaign that deals with the kind-of-steep learning curve. Harvest resources, explore new land and waters, engage in diplomacy and much more.The gameplay is very smooth and well made, the graphics and sound quality is excellent. There are global community votes that actually effect how the game is played, I found this to be a nice little feature to include. Developing your cities takes time, this does get tedious during certain moments of the game, but usually you can find something to do while you wait for whatever it is you're doing.Anno 2070 is a great strategy game and has me going for several hours at a time, even though the game asks me to take a break every hour I find it hard to put down!

content:
Posted: January 20, 2016
												3 Stars - An immersive build game, that can be a pleasure to play.When I first got into this game I fell straight into it. Well build and beautiful I enjoyed mining the varied resources and searching through the tech trees to build my ultimate city and expand.However over time the immersion was lost. The game can be quite slow and the end game was unrewarding. After a reasonable play time I found that many objectives offered too little for too much. Multiplayer attempts failed to work well, and too often the map just seemed to run out, leaving goals unmanageable.Overall, if this is your style of game you will get a lot out of your first 30 odd hours of playtime but by 60 expect the cracks to start to appear.Pros - ImmersiveWell designed resource and tech combinationsVarying approachesPrettyCons - Lack End Game visionCan be slow paced Multiplayer is not worth your time

number of helpful: 8 of 11 people (73%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: October 27, 2016
												I was very hesitant to play this game, seeing the steam reviews are at 62 percent.   I shouldn't have been. Anno 2070 is a very unique and amazing game.  It's an economy simulator, a bit similar to Simcity, with minor Civilization elements (mostly in combat).   However the important difference in this game is that combat is more of a last resort, not a constant need in the game.  In fact in the campaign there's really three missions with any combat, and two that require combat, and only one with more than a minute of necessary combat.The focus on the game is more development of a city/civilization.  There's two major paths in the game.  You can go with the "Ecos" or the "Tycoons" and let me stop here and say the first thing I thought was it's going to be a story about "the hippies freaks" versus "the capitalist swine"....Well it's not.  There is just two forms of civilization.  Ecos try to stay in balance with nature, not abusing it but growing food.  Tycoons tend to be more destructive to nature, but get some items far easier (while others have to be grown which is harmed by their production).  Tycoon sound like an easier option, but neither is particularly overly balanced.  Tycoons are easier to play at the beginning because they can just create the equivalent to strip mines.   But Ecos can consistently stay in the race because once they're set up they keep getting benefits.   The ecological impact of Tycoons are (mostly) non permanent.  They can destroy a strip mine and get back the negative ecology effects too.  So experimenting or completely redesigning the world is acceptable, and in fact I like that feature of the game. As for the Story, again I thought "Man vs Nature" was going to be core.  And I was completely wrong.  There was one point in the story where you chose between the two, and the only thing that did was decide which type of building you got.  There was no great conflict between the two, and the conflict came from an outside group.   The campaign story was great in my opinion.  The story kept progressing at a good pace, but what was great is the game teaches you how to build your cities for about half of the story.  The downside is that when the game doesn't teach you something (and there's a lot of small spaces), you either need to check the internet or read massive data logs and hope it's explained.   I had a problem in campaign Chapter 3, Mission 3, where I couldn't figure out what's wrong.  There was an oil spill that was killing my fish production.  Low fish production meant people weren't getting fish that was harming my taxes.  The game gently mentioned the oil spill was a problem, but this was the end of the game, there was no way to know how to fix the oil spill (which involved a number of unintuitive steps)  and because I didn't do that my money was just bleeding out.  There also was not a second mention of "maybe you should fix the oil".    This type of lack of information almost made me give up until someone online said "you have to clean up the oil spill" and laid out the steps.  A lot of annoying steps, and they had to be done early because without the money for the steps, you are doomed. So the coolest part of the campaign though is it's nine or ten mission over three Chapters.  Each mission has a small story arc but your buildings persist in between missions, when a new chapter begins you do start over.   But if you have a really good layout, you keep it after building the mission.  This is both a strength and a negative.  It means you start to feel for the cities you're building, and your decisions and layouts will matters, so you can't just push for the final goal, but rather should build a good city. The downside is if you've screwed up your city and just barely win, you are left with a screwed up city.  Such as in Chapter 3 Mission 3.  I had a real problem, and now had to deal with it.  Of course I could go back to playing mission 2, and fix the problems (I don't know if that was possible but imagine you have a huge negative balance and finish the mission).  But with the later missions taking hours, I don't know if I ever wanted to go back and replay one of those missions. The other side is I don't think there's ever a "lose" condition in the campaign.  However, you can create layouts that are so grossly ineffective that they are like a "lose" condition.   If you go more then 5k in the red, that might be so bad you'll never climb out of it.  When it's that low, you can't buy things, and some of the ways out will be to buy items.  You can instead destroy objects, and build objects that don't cost the credits the game requires.  But you will lose the ability to build roads, a crucial piece of development (if you aren't connected by a road, your building won't work)  The difference between a working configuration and a grossly ineffective configuration isn't that big.  Being unable to get enough resources, will start to lose the player money fast, and the game can sometimes over upgrade and create these problems itself with no player interaction.  A city with a 1000 credit income can quickly become a city with a deficit without player interaction.  That really sucks.   There's ways to mitigate this, but the player is never really told to watch out for this, and the tools to mitigate this are weak. Overall though if you avoid a few pitfalls, the campaign is a delight, the story is pretty good, and the gameplay is great.  The final chapter of the campaign seems to remove the hands and just let the player play the game, giving abstract goals (build X on the third tier of development) and let the player have to get through the first 2 tiers themselves.   At that point the player has already done all that development so it should be easy, though time consuming. Once you move away from the campaign, things get a little murkier.  There are a number of single missions, and they are all in-depth.   The issue is these are single missions and they are LONG.   Probably taking a couple hours or so due to the length of the supply chains involved in the early ones.  Later ones I'm sure take even longer. This isn't a negative necessarily, but what worked well in the campaign (build a city and keep it for the next mission) is gone here.  If you spend two hours and beat the first single mission, that's gone.   with at least 12 missions that means you're going to be building 12 cities. Some of this stuff is just UI.  I'd love to have "planned" my city, and then let the game build it over time.  I also wouldn't mind better balance sheets, or more helpful hints when things go wrong.   When building a city, if you don't have the "pieces" you're out of luck, and have to wait for the city to generate (or trade) for the pieces. Trade is also a little wonky.  If you have two cities on two different islands, they have their own commerce.  That makes sense.  The problem is that you have to build supply chains for EVERYTHING.  And to do that, you have to select one island, then the other, load a good on one island and then off load it at the other.  You need to manually build every trade route and that takes a decent amount of time, and then even more before the route really becomes effective. The final thing I'd like to talk about is the piece I played with the least.  Apparently the game has a persistent player, that is in all games.  Your "base", the ARK is the same between maps, and what this means is you can store goods on one map and take them to another.  This is HUGE of course.  It also is given upgrades, and you can keep those as you change maps.   I'm at the character limit so I should wrap this up even though I have more.  Overall Anno 2070 is pretty damn good.  I didn't have any of the issues with uPlay that others have had, and I'd recommend this game for people who want something that's a cross between Civilization and SimCity.   It's quirky but it's solid.

content:
Posted: June 18, 2014
												So much to do with hours of fun. Many empires to build and enemies to defeat. Oh did I mention underwater Bases too? Game is detailed on all levels from economy, trading, diplomacy, etc. Combat though can be a bit weak, but makes up for it in natural disasters, like oil spills (if you have oil rigs or someone else does) Tsunamis’ if you have the proper DLC, and various infections that can poison your empires food supply.Having to counter those disasters can take a while if you’re not prepared for it. Still getting into the game myself, and must say the game is a great buy. I would definitely recommend it, especially if you have friends to play with. On that note, This review is based solely off of the game itself. No DRM negative review because DRM and UPlay sucks. I could care less, as I already had a Uplay account and the game was easily linked with no problems.

content:
Posted: September 27, 2015
Anno 2070 – Complete Edition is a strategy city building simulator. Decades after the global warming that melted the polar caps and changed the face of the Earth, you are put in charge of an Ark: an aquatic base of operation that travels the seas to establish new settlements on oceanic islands, managing economy, resource exploitation and relations with other factions. This review includes all DLCs and the Deep Ocean expansion set.Pros: This is a great addition to the Anno series, this time taking place in the fairly-near future without going too sci-fi (that's for Anno 2205 to do). Like past iterations of the franchise, you start with a limited amount of resources and must build industries with to make more building material. Citizen classes are upgraded by providing commodities, and the quantity of citizens you have of each various classes will unlock more buildings and options. The game looks great, factions are easily recognizable and the islands are gorgeous. You can play a continuous free-mode game or pick from a large selection of mission challenges. You also have a campaign mode which is a great gradual introduction to the evolving selection of buildings and to the factions you can side with. You pick between the economically-strong Global Trust or the ecologically-sustaining Eden Initiative factions, and can also ally yourself to the scientific and underwater-expert S.A.A.T. faction. The Uplay community is actually made use of for something else than serving as a DRM: the various factions will regularly put up proposals players can vote on, there are online elections to pick a governing faction that will offer changing bonuses, and the game downloads a temporary "mission-of-the-day" Daily Event.Cons: The game doesn't have an actual tutorial, so even the introductory campaign will leave you wondering whether the next step is a building, an option, or an upgrade. Combat was obviously not the focus of the game which makes PvP multiplayer games hard to win. Although all three factions have different buildings and citizen needs, they ultimately are the same thing with different name on them: Global Trust has Distilleries while Eden Initiative has Tea Plantations, S.A.A.T. has a production chain for Carbon while Global Trust has one for Concrete, etc. The material or commodities a faction can't make itself are material it simply doesn't make use of or commodities its citizen doesn't care for, so there is little need to trade with other factions.Verdict: ★★★★☆ - Next on your listThis is a great city builder! Like other games of the Anno series, it's very different to manage building material and citizens commodities than the usual complexities of budget, taxes and municipal services. If you enjoyed past games of the franchise, or simply want to try a different formula than the other City Builders out there, I strongly recommend giving Anno 2070 – Complete Edition a try!P.S.: The included Uplay appears to be broken for many people, so you must manually download the latest version (which you can do here[ubi.li]) or the game may not work at all. That's too bad for what is essentially a good game.—————————————————————————This was just my opinion.If you found this review helpful, please consider giving it a thumbs up, and feel free to check out more of my (purely opinionated) reviews.

content:
Posted: October 27, 2015
												I love the predecessor games AD 1701 and AD 1401, but this one isn't good. Preachy environmentalism and forcedly-corrupt capitalism turned a great franchise into a downer.  AD 1701 has a fun, happy, Caribbean feel to it. AD 1401 is super complex but awesome mechanically, with a West-meets-East setting.  They are both impeccably polite and perfectly British.2070 has none of the charm of its earlier games and makes no real improvements to playability or mechanics.  Let's hope the next Anno game is better.

content:
Posted: January 3, 2014
												I'm sure this game will be/is fantastic IF you can get the mandatory online play part to work.Just purchased yesterday. I have spent 30 minutes so far navigating the jargon of Ubisoft, and I am NOT pleased with my experience.I even have an excellent gaming PC and fantastic internet ability, but the company is crap for requiring always-online server play. It nullifies the experience, especially when Ubisoft seems unable to actually provide the type of networking they need.It's all bull and I won't buy another of their games EVER again. They were even keen to make me use another form because I happen to be several months under the age of 18, which I completely understand, but it would be nice if the website they directed me to was actually available.The poor planning behind what looks like a beautiful experience has made me less keen to enjoy it. I'm glad I paid only $13 instead of the rediculous $50 price of the regular bundle. What baffoons these developers are! I'd even go as far to say it's worse than the launch of SimCity 2013. And that's saying something. Long rant short: great game, I love what I see, however, if your computer and ISP aren't up to the challenge, abandon all hope of getting to enjoy it. Meanwhile, I'm going to try again to actually play.

content:
Posted: December 26, 2013
												Literally, a ground-breaking concept of SimCity and Online multiplaying. Not only you can play multiplayers: players vote decisions that affect everyone else's decision and some aspects of gameplay. Truly, it's inspiring and a remarkable game for anyone who likes either good strategy or good micro-manegement.Literalmente, uma experiência conceitual autêntica de SimCity e jogos multiplayer. Não simplesmente por poder jogar multiplayer: jogadores votam em decisões que afetam as decisões e parte do jogo de todos os outros jogadores. Realmente, é inspirador, marcante, empolgante e com muito conteúdo pra ser jogado por muito tempo - bom para qualquer um que goste de estratégia ou de micro-gerenciamento.

number of helpful: 5 of 6 people (83%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 5, 2016
												This is the best economic simulation game I've played so far! It's very detailed and realistic. I love how futuristic it is, the graphics still amazes me. Also the soundtrack is just perfect - almost every piece of it! There are 3 factions you can choose to play: Ecos, Tycoons and Techs and all of them are equally cool and well done and I like playing each of them. When you choose Ecos, your island looks just stunning - all the greenery, chirping birds, clear water, peaceful setting. On the other hand, when you choose to play Tycoons, your island gradually gets polluted and you can really see the process. Eventually, there are acid rains, oil spills on the ocean's surface, typhoons devastating neighboring islands. Techs can be unlocked after reaching a specific level of development on the island. This game has really a lot to offer in the single player mode, but man, the online multiplayer mode is what keeps you awake all night long! You can play a cooperation, you can be enemies, you can have either separate islands or manage one island together, set trade routes with your ships, declare wars between each other or NPCs, build airports, fleets, underwater facilities and many more! If you wanna try, clear your schedule at least for 5 hours!

number of helpful: 6 of 8 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 26, 2013
												The older Anno games are superior in every way except graphics, and the graphics on this one are so overdone that this game, an RTS, over-stressed my video card more than any other game I own, which includes all CryEngine games. The initial experience is that it patches the patcher to patch the updater which updates the initial installation of uPlay garbage that Ubisoft inflicts upon you in order that you might eventually be allowed to play the game. After 5 patching screens, I get the UPlay program open, and still no way to play the actual game. Had to kill uPlay with task manager and restart, and finally got uPlay to acknowledge that, yes, I have the right to run the game. Thank you. Can I play now? No, actually, I need to put up with in-game ad for ANNO online, and a request to go fill out a survey about my ANNO playing experience on Survey Monkey. Really, guys? Are you serious?!When you do get to play, I find it to be too much story, too many distractions from game-characters, and campaign scenarios that are uneven in quality. For example, where you need to just build a city that produces so much fish, and then the scenario is over. Weak. It is also uneven in hand-holding, where I found it irritating to be told exactly what to do next, and then suddenly run into a situation where I had no idea of what to do to get some stat up to the critical level for the hokey scenario to finish.As a game, it isn't terrible. If your video card is less than three years old, you might be OK on that front, though my dual-GPU card was definitely stressed to the point of an early heat-death... that was on the lowest settings, to be clear. On my new system, at the time of writing this, it works very quietly on the lowest settings. Now that I've reloaded it on my new system, I will probably enjoy it more, but my earlier experience has soured me on Ubisoft, and ANNO 2070, certainly.It is, underneath the hokey storlline, an ANNO game in the end. But for me, I just cannot get over having to put up with the idiocy that is uPlay. I've promised myself to never pay money for a UbiSoft game again, due to that crap.It's pretty. Underneath a butt-load of flourishes, bells, and overdone whistles, it is an ANNO game. But, I recommend dropping back to a previous ANNO and playing that instead.

number of helpful: 7 of 10 people (70%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 26, 2013
												This is a beautiful game, easy to pick up and with a user-friendly interface. But set against the backdrop of its predecessors, I can't recommend it. Every time I opened it up I was left feeling saddened by the missed opportunity.There is a built-in conflict described between the eco-focused and development-focused factions, but this conflict isn't enforced by the game's resource exploitation models and tech trees. They took it halfway there with an eco-damage mechanic, but the two factions should have been forced to adopt diametrically opposed progress conditions, rather than the carbon copy mechanics we see here. An example: both sides possess the same number of housing tech levels, with the same mechanic for evolving them (population numbers plus availability of secondary goods). Since there is very little crossover of secondary goods, there is no tension between eco and development factions when reaching the highest goal - the ecos don't care about lobsters and champagne, and there's enough rice farms to go around. Instead, we should have seen the developers require huge numbers of tightly-packed houses to advance, coupled with a flourishing economy; and the ecos requiring a low number of big-footprint houses coupled with minimal environmental impact. This means that the factions would always find it hard to coexist at the top development levels, and it'd always occur to one or the other that things would be so much simpler if the other's stuff would just start blowing up.Which leads to the second problem. The tactical and strategic combat wasn't thought through very well at all. Put simply, you don't make rock-paper-scissors work better by restricting the number of choices players have. All three flavours of combat units - air, land, sea - should be available, and the balance between them should be a determining strategic factor. Strengths versus weaknesses. Instead we have a world with NO land-based forces except for the occasional (and limited) turret, restricted air availability, and a poor tech advancement tree.A caveat on the last: there is actually a brilliant research and development tree available via the scientist faction. Unfortunately, it doesn't have the impact on gameplay that it deserves. There is no need to pursue a technological race with your adversary, since it's far more efficient to just spam out more low-tech units.Makes me sad, considering how brilliant parts of this game are. Lost opportunity. Then again, maybe I should just get off my♥♥♥♥♥♥and learn modding, since the game is well supported in this area.

content:
Posted: December 28, 2013
												1.  I'm not sure what Uplay is or what it does, but I don't like having it forced on me.  If it offers me something worthwhile, then I'll opt in.  Not giving me a choice simply shows that you have no confidence that I'd opt in if given the choice.  If you have no confidence in what your own software offers the consumer, then why should I?2.  Between all the patching and updating and trying to figure out what Uplay was and why it wouldn't just let me play the game and registering and being told I couldn't play in offline mode, it took me about 45min to get to the game's main menu.3.  The game felt eco-preachy right off the bat.  This isn't what I'm looking for in a game.4.  If the game has a tutorial of any sort, I couldn't find it.  I figured it must be built into the campaign, but that didn't seem to be the case either.  Instead of a mission walking me through the game mechanics, I'm given some terse orders and vague goals with no clue as to how to reach them.5.  I was feeling plenty grumpy by this point and remembered I have a number of other games waiting for my time in my Steam library.  So I decided to go play them instead.  I doubt I'll be back.  You only get one chance to make a good first impression, Ubisoft.

number of helpful: 8 of 12 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 24, 2013
												I don't recommend this game for only one reason - Anno 1404, its predacessor, is SO much better.This entry in the series is a technical advance, but it has taken the organic feel of 1404 and sterilised it, losing a lot in the process. Much of the appeal of the original was finding your own solution to a very broad set of objectives, but 2070 adds a campaign that provides a rigid structure to the missions that feels far too constrained, and it has thrown in additional mechanics that serve only to restrict how you can build and interact with the world.If you enjoy these kinds of management games, I'd recommend picking up 1404 plus its expansion, Venice, before even considering Anno 2070.

content:
Posted: February 15, 2014
												My mind is twisted about this game. Sure, it looks fantastic and at first glance has a lot of depth. After I bought it I was very excited of finally calling it my own. But that's where the trouble started. The Ubisoft launcher is a catastrophy to put it mildly. It took hours for countless updates to install and I had to enter my serials three times. Needless to say that my excitement about the game shrank considerably. The whole point of buying games on steam for me is to avoid all the nasty installation procedures, click a button and more or less start playing. The only good news here is, that after going through the hellfire of the initial installation the launcher is less agonizing. Still it may take 10 Minutes to just launch the game. Big fail.When you can FINALLY start to play you're pretty much on your own in a world you know only little about. There's a campaign mode which I tried to start with. Quickly I ran into trouble just because I couldn't figure out what to do in order to fulfill the goals. The game doesn't teach you at all. I abandoned the campaign mode and went for the sandbox. Youtube videos on how to play the game helped me to make some progress and pretty soon I settled on a bunch of islands doing great. The game became fun! Big plus ... But that was about all I got. The game just became stale. There was nothing left to do. So the few moments of excitement went away and now I can't be bothered to turn the game on again. What a shame, but this game is honestly one of the most boring and repeatative games I have ever played. Despite it's beauty and appearant depth, there just isn't much of a challenge left to it once you've played for a few hours.So I'm sorry to say that I can't recommend this great but utterly boring game. The ubisoft launcher alone kinda kills it to begin with, but the gameplay just didn't manage to excite me enough to forget about this.

number of helpful: 9 of 14 people (64%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 5, 2015
												Before i begine. I WILL NOT COUNT ANY ISSUES WITH U-PLAY AS ISSUES WITH THIS GAME! (those who do downvote and ruin a great game based on issues with the drm system that isnt THIS games fault.) All in All, this is a fun game. Its full of a rather LARGE number of things to do if you get the final, complete version. has quite a bit of gameplay mechanics to learn and enjoy, and so long as your patient, can give  you plenty of challenges to enjoy. the learning curve isnt overwhelming but there is one to it, but as with any city builder/resource management game, thats to be expected. all in alll i give this gameGraphics:9/10 (a few issues here and there with graphical bugs but mostly perfection)Sound 10/10 (the music is beautiful, with decent sound effects and good quality to sound placement (and a few funny things from your dwellers if you zoom in on them)Story 7/10 (This game lacks somewhat in the story department. It does have a story but nothing grand or utterly new. As you would expect, Nature, Money, Science, Take a choice and the story follows.)Gui/Controles 8/10 (the controles feel pretty natural for a game of this type, though there where some issues finding things in the GUI at first. The controles and keys can be remapped in game which is a plus and once you learn the basic locations of things, it gets really easy)Overall 8.5/10 (Go and play this game. you will enjoy it)*side note* I have never experianced ANY issues ever with uplay. I have, however, Seen plenty of issues both here and with friends, dealing with the DRM system crashing. I recommend you download uplay from ubisoft and make sure that, not only can you run it, but that you find out what is causing the crash in the first place (most of the issues and solutions can be found online, with a short google search. The game issue i found with friends is that it wasnt installed using Admin mode or run under admin mode with windows 7 and up)

content:
Posted: February 14, 2014
												Hear me out when I say that this is a WONDERFUL game, but you really shouldn't purchase it unless you enjoy downloading separate gaming clients in order to play your games. Before you can even start the game, you're required to download Ubisoft's own "UPlay" client and make an account solely for that service. That isn't the end of it, though. As additional obstacles, you'll also need to log in to the game through UPlay, then once more in-game. It's a real shame that so much is required of you to play such a great game. In an effort to convince Ubisoft that this sort of purchasing model is both unnecessary and undesirable, I'll never buy another Ubisoft game through Steam (unless I hear that things have changed). On a final note, I'll say that this is the only Steam purchase I've ever regretted, and my Steam library consists of 70+ games. *Just a fair warning.

												I bought this game through Steam, a fine and trusted resource...or so I thought. In order to play the game, after downloading, I had to sit through about 40 minutes of patches, including a forced membership with Ubisoft's useless 'Uplay', followed by patches for Uplay, followed by downloading the game again, through Ubisoft's sad little robotic clone of Steam. I don't even know if this is a good game or not, but if their choice in publisher is any indication of it's makers' good judgement and professionalism, then I have my doubts. I will never buy another title with the word 'Uplay' anywhere near it. Ubisoft might as well be on that list as well. This kind of abuse of a captive consumer makes pirating seem attractive, and justified. I believe in paying people for their hard work, but I work hard for my money too, and this waste of time feels like theft to me.

number of helpful: 4 of 5 people (80%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 19, 2016
												Don't buy this on Steam.  Just don't.  Buy it elsewhere, because it's usable there.  Anno 2070 is essentially the block before Simcity 2014, by a different AAA publisher.  Always online DRM, launching through Uplay, and really-sketchy Steam integration makes this game impossible to recommend for the majority of audiences that want to play it for the first time.A few notes before the game critique:You can still resolve issues with Uplay by installing Uplay before downloading and activating this game through Steam.  There's some manual patching you need to do, but that does put off a large portion of the audience.  Pick it up if you're willing to put in the effort to get it working; as of late 2015, Ubisoft hasn't addressed any of the fundamental problems with getting it runningMake sure you have a machine you'll play through the entire game with, because this Steam version acts as one copy.  I can't play this copy anymore because I upgraded to Windows 10; and thus my previous machine (which I can't go back to) has this copy on it.  Make sure you've got it on a medium that Ubisoft trusts you to have it with, be it on Uplay originally or a physical copy.This is not the game for you if you don't have great internet.  If you lose access to Uplay servers, you could forfeit your current work even on the single-player campaign.The ProsAnno 2070 is a gorgeous addition to the series that adds a lot of addicting features.  Citizen management, faction alliances and tech research all feel much more interwoven than in previous titles, and given the futuristic asthetic, it seems pretty coherent.Though I don't think it was executed as well as it could have been, the story mode was very immersive and I found the real-world themes of industry vs environmentalism to be very engaging.  There's different styles you can set things up to appeal to the masses and obviously multitudes of methods to accomplish those means, which I found very encouraging for me to find my own solutions to problems I had (usually) brought upon myself.The ConsAs a first time player, this was really, really hard for me to get into.  I actually went back and played Anno 1503 to sort of understand what the game was asking for and to acquire a general feel for how it's played.  Thereafter, though I like the very high-tech and modern feel of the game, I don't think the intro or tutorial to the game were well done at all.  Having gone through it's predacessors, I struggled re-learning the specifics of new units and buildings, as well as having the map  awareness or sense of scale to do quests at apropriate times.  It's a very challenging game, and it mostly leaves itself for the player to figure out.My VerdictAnno 2070 is a game you likely won't play, and will regret not doing so.  Though it's built on the previous titles quite a bit, I don't think it inhibited my progress at any point and kept me coming back for more.  I ended up "sinking" many more hours in this installment than I did in 1503, and hope to play 2205 soon.8.25/10However in the current setup on Steam/Uplay, I do not recommend purchasing this game for the sake of your future playing it.  Anno isn't a game to be played for 5-10 hours and then put down - heavens no.  This is something that I find rivals Age of Empires, and you might end up sinking well over a hundred hours into it.  If you lose your copy (like I did) you would have been better off buying it somewhere else.

Posted: March 15, 2015
												After beginning the download, it is now approaching 2 hours of just trying to get the game to start. First problem that really causes things to stick is that to play this, you must go through steam to go through Ubisoft's game portal UPlay. But the UPlay component that downloads from steam does not work. Do not use google to look for the Uplay log in because when you get to that security thing where you have to enter words or numbers in their picture (or spoken in the verbal challenge) , no matter how correct you answer, it responds as being wrong all the time. Instead you actually have to open your google or windows explorer and go to the Ubisoft Website and download the UPlay software from there. Then, running the Ubisoft site downloaded UPlay, set up your Ubisoft account. Then you can go to steam to launch Anno 2070 which just launches the Ubisoft environment where you again direct the Play of the game. Then there is another download for add-on updates, which adds to the length of time required of the start of play. Anyone seeking to obtain and play this game, perhaps getting the CD of this one might be easer. I can't recommend this game based on this as I have not even had the opportunity to play Yet. Look to other review for the actual game review because determining to buy the game should be based on quality of play. This is my first steam review so I don't know if I can edit this later as actual play experience occurs.

												I have to say this is the worst instance I have seen of failing to grasp the concept of Steam integration. This game is a mess of patchers. Once the UPlay download completed the patcher launched once again and patched.Finally I get ingame only to find that any DLC owned is mandatory and not downloaded by default, so the game quits and reopens the patcher, downloads the DLC, reopens the game, sees another missing DLC, and downloads that. TEN TIMES.As such, I have yet to even reach the main menu and cannot review the gameplay at this time.

number of helpful: 5 of 7 people (71%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 16, 2016
												This game, first and foremost, is the most expansive, intricate city-builder I have ever played.  The number of structures, units, etc. is stunning.  There are three different, largely unique buildings tracks, each with their own style and appearance.  The fun part is mastering each and then using them together.  While the diplomacy and combat are somewhat rudimentary, they are adequate and add a further level of complexity to already intricate gameplay.  Moreover, it is a gorgeous game.  You will play this game for one hundred hours and still be amazed by it.The problem, of course, is getting past the first 5-10 hours.  This game has a very large learning curve and has almost no tutorial. What tutorial exists is a very bad one.  I believe this is why this game has received bad reviews in the past.Overall, I would recommend this game highly, if you have the endurance to learn its gameplay.  And I am writing this having not even purchased a single DLC.  I can’t wait to do so.

number of helpful: 5 of 7 people (71%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 13, 2014
												When i seen Anno 2070 on the steam sale, i was pretty happy. It appears to follow the path of the previous anno games which where great fun (even the one on the DS). However, i have not actually had the chance to play anno 2070 yet, due to the amount of time it took to update the game itself after download (expected). As i was greeted with the request for a serial key, i had to remind myself that it wasnt 2006 and that i did buy this game on steam (supposed to stop this), but ok, its only a few clicks ill roll with it. As i progressed though this, i was then greeted with a SECOND digital distrobution platform.. uplay. Hold on, did i not buy this game on steam? no uplay, uplay why are you updating.. ok ill wait. About 30 mins later, i was bored and lost a large chunk of my playtime for that session. A few days later i thought, hey uplay will be updated, ill give this another blast... uplay was not fully updated and took another 30 mins or so to get me updated. A which point i was greeted with a login screen within uplay... WHY is this game forcing me to sign into two platforms? TLDR: The game has a dual digital distribution, requireing two online accounts to use. Why? no idea. I will add, that i have not yet actually managed to play the game.

number of helpful: 5 of 7 people (71%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 20, 2016
												For those of us looking for a top notch economic simulator with a focus on strategic city building, Anno 2070 will scratch that itch and then some.  You'll be expanding accross a number of islands (and viable plots of ocean floor) on each map that produce and grow independently from one another which makes creating trade routes imperative if you hope to make them prosper in the long run.  A fun campaign injects a story and special objectives into the game, but the large number of maps available keeps Anno 2070 playable for a long time after that.Your colonies themselves have a lot of customization available as you would imagine with a city builder.  Three different population types are available each with their own unique perks that they can offer.  There are the money-obsessed, capitalism-loving Tycoons, the beauty and clean living Ecos, and the science fanatics known as the Techs.  Each has several tiers of classes to unlock within them as long as you meet their ever-growing list of demands.  Workers may not ask for much but executives will require a significant, continued supply of resources that will take some commitment to produce.Creating and maintaining trade routes requires a level of micromanagement but when you hit that sweet spot and start shipping the near-perfect quantity of a resource from your single colony that produces it to all of your colonies that use it to produce more advanced goods you feel an incredible sense of accomplishment.  Watching the economy thrive and grow after having built it from the ground up is fantastic feeling.I recommend this game to anyone and everyone who enjoys city builders and economy simulators.  This is easily one of the best ones that I have played.  Few games of the genre manage to reach the depth of Anno 2070 (pun intended?) and I still start the game up from time to time even having completed the campaign quite some time ago.

number of helpful: 7 of 11 people (64%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 16, 2015
												An incredibly intense city-building game with plenty of complex interactions.So, very first impression, yes this is an Ubisoft game, and yes that means using Uplay, and yes Uplay is a terrible client, but that should absolutely not prevent you from enjoying this fantastic creation of a game.Next impression I get is of Anno 2070's high aesthetics. The interface, setting, art, and music are all very appealing and I'd say downright immersive. Although this does bring my first real complaint that the interface did sacrifice a moderate amount of utilitarian value for the sake of aesthetics. Really what this boils down to is an extra button press or two to select the proper category of building, and also not as much information as I'd like to be displayed on the screen at all times. And then comes the initial campaign. Initially I was annoyed with the moving my boat back and forth to transport arbitrary quest objects, but later on I came to realize how important it was getting those basic mechanics mastered beforehand, before having to manage multi-island economies. In hindsight, the gradual pacing of the introduction of game mechanics was well done, even if it might not seem so at first.And then finally the meat and potatoes. For each game, the map is spread out across several different islands. Each island has ~3 different fertilities which allow for the production of their respective agricultural products. There are also a limited number of mineral nodes for other types of resources. As you develop your city, your people will want for goods far in excess of what their home island can produce. This is the key base point around where all the emergent interactions come from. You'll need to colonize other islands in order to have a more diverse selection of resources, and then you'll have to weight the pros/cons of refining those resources prior to or after shipping them, and then you'll have to setup trade routes in order to move the goods around to where they need to go, but in order to do that, you need to be able to build additional ships to throw at it. And all of this just falls under what I describe as the first order of complexity.The second order of complexity, is that when you're expanding, you're not only introducing demands for new forms of goods, but you're also increasing the quantity of demand for lower forms. This base principle creates this order of emergent complexity - resource balancing. You need to constantly be mindful of actions that you take introducing resource imbalances, and figuring out a solution to correct them. There is a ratio of resource gathering, to manufacturing, to demand, but it's never perfect and usually up to you to diagnose it before your people let you know by being upset. Proper management of imports/exports with other parties in the game can smooth out these resource imbalances as well.So now you've been on the same map for a dozen hours, and you've finally gotten your starting faction up to the highest level of development? Well there's 2 other factions that you unlock as you play, and they both have their own completely different resource trees. So all that balancing you were doing? Now you need to do that x3 across the same islands. And one of those factions, the Techs, have many dozens of different researches to do in late game to assist in optimizing your economy even further.Summed up,  what all of this means is that when you're playing, you're never ever waiting for your city to grow - you're constantly juggling half a dozen things at once for hours on end, and it's not even mundane. Deciding on optimal building placement, managing resource imbalances - these are not cognitively simple tasks.By the way, there's also a military aspect. There are other players in the world who can do the same sort of things you do, and you can declare war on them and blow their stuff up. Myself and many other Anno players haven't really fully plunged the depths of this, though, since the resource management can be cognitively taxing enough without this as well. Which also brings me to mention that there's also multiplayer support, but it's a very special kind of person who wants to throw human players into this mix.tl;dr, game is complex enough that I've put in over 50 hours and I'm still not all that comfortable with all the content that is presented to me.

I had to create an account with Uplay, which was inconvenient and I didn't want another account just to play this game.Then, after Uplay opened, I couldn't figure out how to start the game, so I quit Uplay, and clicked Play Game from Steam again.Then finally, Uplay launched, but it had to auto update. Then it asked me to add the game to my Uplay account. I already bought the game on Steam, why do I need to register it a 2nd time?Then again, nothing happened, Uplay was just sitting there, and I quit it. Then I clicked Play Game from Steam again. This time Uplay launched, then the game launched. Once in the game, it asked me for the product key, which I had to cut and paste from Steam. It told me that the game would be registered against my Uplay account, but haven't I already done that?Then, I had to create a profile in the game. The game then told me that it was installing some addons (???) and had to download them and restart. I clicked Okay, and the game promptly crashed ("Anno 2070 has stopped working").I launched it from Steam again, which told me the game was already running. I found some weird updater GUI running minimised with some EULA agreement. Then on my (slow) internet connection, it took 1 hour to update (god knows what it was updating, don't I already have the game via Steam!?).Finally, I could launch the game and play it.I feel like I'm doing the work of the QA/Testing staff. What the ♥♥♥♥?

number of helpful: 8 of 13 people (62%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 26, 2014
												I was recommended this game by a friend of mine recently as I've been playing a lot of strategy/citybuilders. So far, I'm enjoying the scenario mode, I haven't played endless, MP or the individual missions but the only glaring issue I've found so far is lack of a real tutorial. The game prefers to throw information at you on an "as and when" basis, whereas I'm the kind of person who'd like a thorough run through of all the basics before I dive in. Still, that's nothing that would put me off as I'm a fairly fast learner, but I'm aware that there are those out there who might be put off by the level of complexity with just an in-game "manual" to refer to.The gameplay is what you'd expect from games of this type, functional point and click with plenty of micromanagement. I loved how simple it is to manage your resources and trade networks and to quickly sell off any of your stockpiled surplus to make a few quick dollars, I've never been very good at budgeting so that was quite a help when my depots started to fill up.Graphically, it's absolutely gorgeous to look at with some absolutey beautiful levels of detail (the fat guys working the sugar beet production plantation made me giggle a bit) on structures, vehicles, NPCs and landscape, the underwater areas have fish, rays, jellyfish and other marine creatures which makes exploration something very enjoyable.It sounds lovely too, a nice, non-intrusive score which nevertheless conveys the atmosphere of the game very well and the change of track from over- to underwater was a nice little touch. The NPCS voice actors are well chosen for their roles with my only criticism there being of Dr. Salman Devi.. where are you from, Davi?!I'd definitely give this a thumbs up to anyone familiar with strategy, citybuilding and suchlike. There are a wide range of expansions to keep you busy once you've cracked the game too which should push its longevity, definitely worth the money!

												I have bought Anno maybe around... 2014 now ?Since then I have played it for a few 100 hours and it's still enjoyable.When I bought the game originally , I wasn't aware of the DRM system Ubisoft used.I have used my key twice by now. In about 3 years.Let me get this straight.Ubisoft are plain scumbags for this method by treating you like a pirate.It's bad , it impacts the game but only on the long term.From the reviews I have read , people complain about changing their computer Specs often.I don't really mind that people like performance , but I never had these problems.I don't see why you would require to wipe out your Hard Drive often. Or why you would need to change your GPU or CPU often. I don't agree at all with Ubisoft's system. It's awful and shouldn't exist for such a great game.But 3 keys activation is enough , if you know how to be reasonable with a computer.So in the end , do I still recommend the game.Yes , absolutely , it's really great.Do I recommend using Uplay over Steam ? No because Steam is significantly better.It's acceptable though (their customer service is also far better).But what I'm warning you is that people make a bigger fuss about it than necessary. Considering Ubisoft won't even change.Simply be aware of what you buy , and make sure you're not getting ♥♥♥♥ed over.

content:
Posted: December 24, 2014
												Despite having an annoying piece of broken bloatware that comes with it, the game itself is great. If you can manage your way past the firewall that is U-Play (fix explained in the last paragraph), you get a real-time near-future game that touches on city-building, resource management, and military actions.The simulations runs smoothly (so long as a few certain buildings stay in one piece, that is) and cities can grow and adapt depending on the play style of the player: both of the starting factions provide very different gameplay. Players can choose to be city designers, researchers, or military powers and win victories set by the match host.Although most of the game's missions are difficult at first sight, the campagin and single-player missions follow a plot line that is understandable and memorable. In addition, the game well incorperates "today's global challanges" with daily senate/council votes, world events (generally a mini-campaign that refreshes every month or so.), and lots of cool little features most people don't notices until later.My only complaints about this game are down to two things. Firstly, one of the game's earliest production chains, tools, requires the very resource it creates to build it. In general, the player has to store some aboard the Ark (an inter-game storage system) or order some in-game from the Ark's delivery system to start this production. Repairing U-Play:Secondly, the U-don't-play service that comes with the game is just... upsetting: it's buggy, it's slow, and serves no extra purpose over using plain Steam. Aditionally, it will almost always crash on and machines that aren't Windows XP SP2. That said, if your game does fail to start: right click on the game in your library and browse local content. First, right click Anno5.exe and view Properties. Next, navagate to the Compatability tab and set the game to run in compatability mode for Windows XP Service Pack 2 and have it run as administrator. Steam will show that the game launched then immediately closed: give it a moment for U-Play to start and the game to launch shortly after.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 27, 2014
												I bought this game about a year and a half ago during the steam summer sale of 2013. I enjoyed the game at first, and learned about U-Play.... If I enjoyed it then why did I not recommend the game? I don't reccomend the game because I think that the core gameplay is dis-functional, and it's mostly notices after various games. This is a long review but in-depth. Read on for more info.Engine:Let me start out by saying that ever time, before i launch the game, i have to validate the game files or else the game crashes randomly. I looked it up and this is a known engine bug that existed in the last Anno games as well. Ubisoft must not have thought that the game-breaking bug needed to be fixed. (Remind you of any recent Ubisoftness)-Pros/Cons:+ It CAN work----- Bad Engine-- CrashesGeneral Gameplay:Let me start out by noting there are two player factions which change looks and core gameplay. Power production and even the resources you need to get to the new tiers change. I only have played with the Tycoons since they are my style but they both look fun. I've never taken the time to play extensively with the Initative. More details can be found below on each aspect of gameplay.++ Diversity- Resources:The gameplay is supply chain and resource production. You build your iron mines, smelt it into steel, and then produce tools from the steel. Managing the buildings, citizens, supply and demand, food, and fleet can be a challenge at times. If you are into micro managing things than you're probably going to like the gameplay.-Pros/Cons: ~Meh+- Supply chain+- Management-Economy:The problems arise in balance however. You start out with little money, barely enough to get your island under control and produce more. Often the money ammount is so low i cannot get the revenue i need, even through trading, to keep my island running smoothly, so that has made me loose many times. The money will make you loose more often than a war.-Pros/Cons: ~OH MY GOD HELP ME!!!!--- Horrible economic start, you start behind-- You'll keep encountering money issues until the late game+ More citizens = more taxes = more money- Diplomacy-War:Speaking of war, war is bad. The AI start with a fully developed Island and fleet, not you however. This screws with the balance. Ships can really only start to be made in the mid-game, and AI has a fleet in the beggining. Even when you get the materials to make ships (supply chain) you can not make much ships. If by this point you have done something horrible, like building a building that makes the AI mad at you (more on this in a little bit), it's game over. Ships are so hard to build at the start i've only ever had one game where I could even produce ships, but I only ever made two because of the budget (money issues again). Im not sure how well balances war is if everyone has ships, i've never had more than one attacking ship.-Pros/Cons: ~Dunno, I'VE NEVER BEEN ABLE TO WAGE WAR!----- Horribly unbalanced, game ruining-- AI always ahead-- Hard to make any fleet to defend-- money needed to do anything cool with a fleet++ no excessive micro managing during battles-Diplomacy:If you ever try and use diplocy you will be mad. Diplomacy isn't like civ where your trading resouces, it's just you paying the AI for services, like delaying another AI, not expanding, ect.. The prices are steep so you'll most likely never have the money you need to do what you want done until the end game (more spending). If you're in the end game I don't see why you would nbeed their services though. As I mentioned earlier, the only actual diplomacy is where you do something that pisses the AI off and they send you a threat. You have two options, follow through with the demands or declare war. YAY for options.... If you actually have a fleet by the time you receive the threat you might be able to fight.-Pros/Cons: ~Never used-- Useless+-- AI Threats!! Example: I needed oil to start a new production line and get to the next tier, so I expanded and build oil wells. Then I receive a threat from the oil baron AI, "Destroy all your oil wells and production or declare war." I couldn't destroy my oil without consequences and didn't have the money to just buy his oil (More economy issues, again) so I was forced to declare war. I thought it would't be that bad and he'd just leave me alone mostly, but he charged in with high level warships and leveled my main island...Island colonization:I actually liked this gameplay aspect. You can colonize other islands and produce good that can't be grown on your main island (depending on the island). Then you can create an automated trade route to exchange resources. The only problem is that you need a cargo ship, so one will always be busy. If you want to trade also you'll need at least two cargo ships or to stop the transport temporarily. If you need two ships you'd better be able to build the second one, so you'll need money (wow, more money needed. Cargo ships are the easiest ships to make though). If you chose to repurpose the main ship then it can stop the production chain which can cause unhappy citizens and then tax problems leading to a ruined economy in the long run (...). -Pros/Cons: ~I Enjoyed it++ Different islands+ You can intercept transports to ruin a players economy (works both ways)+ Underwater islands (This is more late game so i've never been able to use them)- Could maybe use even more island diversityGraphics:Now since im over with the gameplay let go into graphics. Not too bad actually. Futuristic looking, of course, so sleek building and interesting vehicles. Good graphics overall.Pros/Cons: ~Good++ Futuristic+ Nice looking islandsSound:It's been a while since I've played and I mostly forget the sounds of the game, but I don't remember anything annoying me so thats a big plus. All i remember is that I liked itPros/Cons: ~?++ Nothing annoying+ It worksThe Verdict:Buy this game if the gameplay is your style, you could enjoy it more than me.-For me though 5/10.

content:
Posted: February 26, 2014
												No. Just, no.This game is gorgeous. It has a fun atmoshpere. It promises cool city building with a focus on trading, resource management and tech. It is blindingly tedious and complicated. And not the challenging kind of complicated, the, "What in the holy heck does the game want me to do to advance?!!!" kind of complicated. This game is so frustrating becaue it really is the most beautiful and polished turd on the market for the building sim genre. You will love it for an hour, and then struggle to find enjoyment the next 8 or so before you finally realize this game has nothing to offer beyond tedious resource grinding for ever-decreasing gains. I want to like this game so hard. The premise, the gloss, even parts of the gameplay, but I just cannot recommend it. Especially after Steam and Uplay had a battle on my hard drive and installed it twice (only game thats ever done that). But that actually worked out for the best, because now when my friends ask, "How is ANNO 2070?" I can honestly reply, "It's so bad I deleted it twice!" EUIV, Civ V, SimCity, even CitiesXL (which has no trading) will offer a better experience. tl;dr: A very pretty, very polished trading sim with terrible gameplay mechanics and incredibly low replay value.

number of helpful: 4 of 6 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 30, 2014
												A disappointing sequel to Anno 1404 (Dawn of Discovery) which, in my opinion, doesn't add enough to the previous game to be justified.  Features such as the underwater islands are an interesting touch, but there is little that you can actually do with them.  Everything else about the game is just Anno 1404 with a few new building types and new names for everything.  I'm all for sequels to good games sticking with the format that works, but they have to add enough content to justify their price tag, and this one didn't.As if to add insult to injury, the game also REQUIRES Ubisoft's UPlay launcher to start the game, which REQUIRES you to have a UPlay account (yet another username and password) and be always connected to the internet.  Aside from the fact that I object to this type of publisher account where it adds no value to the game for the consumer, but the software itself is unreliable and often fails to connect or crashes before I can even play the game.  Not to mention that this is on top of the existing TAGES DRM which imposes the 3 machine activation limit that was present in Anno 1404.All in all, I would recommend people play Anno 1404 (with the Venice expansion pack) instead and save themselves the heavy price tag and immense frustration for a game that adds little to the fantastic Anno series.

number of helpful: 4 of 6 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 14, 2014
												This is one of the best strategy games I've played. Got the complete edition on sale and got my friends to get it also and it has been really fun. It has a lot of neat elements to it and is complex enough to stay interesting and not be overly complicated to the point where it's not fun. The graphics are really nice in my opinion, especially when you go underwater and build cool stuff on underwater plateaus. It's really fun with 4 players but you can play with more if you're willing to co-op with another person, bringing the count up to 8 players.The factions in the game are very different so the gameplay really changes with each, but late game you are able to unlock all of the other factions which is cool too. My main complaint about the factions is that if you pick the Eco faction and you are playing against an agressive tycoon, you likely won't be able to defend yourself for a while so you have to figure out other ways to protect your islands.I really like this game, give it a try!

												I found a fix for the "Uplay has stopped working" bug, but its still bad.insanely slow paced, even when you go at double speed, %100 online, and other players influence your world. on the topic of other players, multiplayer is a boring affair where combat barely happens and some modes dont even put you on the same map(s).i played for 2 days. then uninstalled it. dont even get me started on the $44 of dlc, all of the content that should be included is held by DLC paywalls.Functionality: 1/10 It actually starts.Computer Performance: 3/10 Rather heavy.Gameplay: 2/10 Enjoyable for a few hours, then becomes tedious.Graphics: 6/10 Looks beutiful when its not lagging.Sound: 6/10 Sounds are smooth and good.Reliabilty: 3/10 If you can get it to run, works fine but occasionally freezes on windows 7 64-bit.Bugs: 3/10 Gamebreaking.DLC: 1/10 Uneccesary paywalling off content that should be in the game.Overall: 4/10 Rushed to the shelves to fill ubisoft's pockets. Would not recommend.

number of helpful: 5 of 8 people (63%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 14, 2013
												back when SETTLERS was a thing age of empire was eating the market... building + management of the buildings and not the units was confusing for all the AOE players...then anno came after... and it all changed...anno is a game where you gotta think 10 game hours before you do anything... take off your age of empire spectacles and enter a game were you NEED to manage over 50 ressources ... at the same time... youll need to produce spices ( if your island has that ressource unlocked ..because each island on the map has different ''seeds'' that limits what you can exploit off that island)  and meat to make hamburgers for your tycoons and satisfy 1 need out of the 7 they suggest... 1 need can be 3 goods to manage... and theres combat too on top of that...because theres so much into building a warship ..you will need to use it wisely because loosing it can hurt you big time.your main goal is to lvl up your citizen houses by meeting their needs... a new house lvl means new goods to produce.producing a good is tedious because you need to manage your power and the eco value.. because an industrialized island will poduce lots of polluant and the soil will acidify and it will lower the rate of production... theres 2 main races will both a different needs and goods and a different approach to the game.... one is the spiritual entity of greenpeace and the other is japan with all the technology and the pollutiontheres also a 3rd race called the techs with a new good tree and a whole different purpuse.. at a high lvl you can research new buildings or items that can affect an island or a shipon a continuous map you CAN go out and build all 3 race buildings ( like in starcraft 1 if you were the protoss and got a dark archon and mind controlled a drone or a suv )this game is so big ... theres dozens of feature... like the vote for a senate ( like i said theres 3 races and 1 of them gets elected at the world concil) feature that affects directly how the game runs because each senators give you ''buffs'' you can activateif you arent sold when i said this game was civilization with more ressources management and a faster pace...nothing can and you are dead inside

content:
Posted: January 31, 2014
												Game is great. "Uplay" is terrible.Here some steps I made to make game running:1. Installed the game in steam.2. Pushed the "Play now" button.3. Some stuff started to setup, including "Uplay"... waiting for it to finish... Ooops, looks like it was an old version of uplay and its updating now... So much popup windows... miserable waiting and suffering.... wasting tons of time... aaaaand done at last!4. Tryin to get in Uplay. Recovering password for Uplay. I actually forget that I used uplay in past. Game serial number copy-pasting...5. Uplay opened, but "My games" list is empty! How should I play???6. Trying to restart the game. Clicking X button in right-upper corner of Uplay window. Pressing "Play now" in steam again. Noooooooooo, its not working! It says that game is already running. Whaat? Looks like uplay is still running. Trying to switch to window with uplay. But it does not exist!!! No Uplay application is running. There is only a uplay process in memory, so I had to kill it in bad way, like crushing you know. Some casual users don't know how to end process, so it should not be that way, Ubisoft. Actually you should not end any process at all to start the game. We are trying to START, not to END.7. Pushed the "Play now" button in steam again.8. At last uplay started, and its even showing Anno 2070 at "My games" page! Great success!9. Pushed the "Play" button in Uplay window.10. It works!!! But asking to enter serial number again. I've done it before, why do you ask it again?! Ok, paste it with facepalm.11. Popup message. You know, you just activated an addon for that game! So you have to download it now. And of course the game will now be ended and the updater will start working... WHAAAAAAAAT??? Ubisoft, let me play please!!! Today, preferable... Okay, updating...12. Starting the game again. Popup window "please take a part in our survey". Too much popups, I mean it... I know its not mandatory, but let's do what the game wants right now - let's go through the survey... And the second question is about how you rate Anno 2070. Guys I’ve been in main menu only, how may I rate it? 5 of 10 is ok for you? There are more obviously illogical questions about game concepts, which I could not know from being in main menu. At the end of survey they say thanks and site language turns into german. Danke, auf wiedersehen!13. Okay, lets play. Or not, because there is one more popup window. It describes anno online (different game) and has "play now" button. Seems like they want to distract me from playing anno 2070 at all costs!14. Finally we are able to push buttons in main menu like play scenario etc. I feel violated. And not in a good way. And I paid for that.

number of helpful: 6 of 10 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 1, 2015
												First off.... Uplay.I know, I know, it's a pain in the♥♥♥♥♥ but it's mostly because Steam doesn't bother to update it (with good reason). The updates made by the launcher itself dont work, which means that you just have to download uplay off of Ubisoft. A 3 minute effort for hours of fun with a really nice game.Dont listen to the negative reviews my friends, please, Uplay isn't that much of a hassle, and definitely shouldn't hinder your decision to buy.Anno Anno Anno.I loved the game. It's just hilariously fun to build up your island as a tycoon or tech and then decide you want to nuke everyone else. Loved those aspects of it. City building is fun and difficult, ensuring an interesting experience, and campaign seems quite entertaining too. The lore, which I have not really gone into much lately, is interesting on the surface, and I especially like the conflict between Tech, Tycoon, and Eco.Combat is interesting, with each faction sporting strengths and weaknesses, and I LOVE the whole submarine side of it, really recommend the DLC and all. Diplomacy is OK, but I've only scratched the surface and all, since I'm currently sanctioned by, let's check, every single faction on the map, because of my avid use of nuclear warheads. The islands I conquer are currently glass, but I think that I can monopolize on the cathedral building business.10/10 Would play again

number of helpful: 6 of 10 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 26, 2014
												I have played this game extensively as you can see by my hours played. The Anno series is unique and unlike other city building games. Anno is all about micro managing and making sure your islands have the correct resources while balancing production buildings. Once your citizens are satisified, they can level up into a more prestigous catergory which will require more needs to satisfy the upper class. The game has awesome graphics, its very pleasing to the eyes.The DRM used to be a lot worse than what it currently is. Don't let that hold you back from getting this game, its well worth the price. I paid full price for it but grabbed the DLC when it was on sale. The Deep Ocean DLC is worth if once you understand the mechanics of Anno. I also must note that the game has quite the multi player options. I found it very confusing and never used it, just always played Campaign. Some important campaign tips: Google good map seed numbers to get good maps that are very big and have lots of mines / rivers / resources / etc. Discover and inhabit as many islands as possible right away. If not, the AI will get it develop it to kick your♥♥♥♥♥at war. Keto is ♥♥♥♥♥. Hector is annoying but easy to beat as a beginner. Always check your productions lines are working correctly and you don't have huge shortages or surplases. Trading Carbon/Kerosene is the fastest and easiest way to get money fast.Hope this helps!

number of helpful: 6 of 10 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 27, 2014
												TL;DR Get game, get Deep Sea expansion. Tech trees/balancing at 3 to 4 levels of supply is really satisfying. Graphics/detail = great. Combat = Sucks. Yes, UPlay sucks but it is not enough of a reason to avoid altogether. If you like city building strategy games, you need to check this out, ESPECIALLY if you can get it on deep discount. 8.5/10OK first of all, I do not have 830 hours on this game because that is ridiculous. Lots of hours tabbed out. I would say I have probably played 200+ hours though, no joking. After finishing the campaign and several lengthy custom games, I confidently recommend this game to anyone looking for a fun strategy/builder with a lot of depth. The Deep Sea expansion is a MUST HAVE. It is definitely an "Oh♥♥♥♥♥♥I have to work in 3 hours!"-kind of a game.Second: A little background on me so you can put my review in context. I like a wide variety of games, but I play a LOT of strategy games. I started out on Master of Orion and XCom UFO Defense. I played Ogre Battle 64, Sim City 2000, XCom Enemy Unknown, Master of Orion 2, Civilization 5, Banished, Sim City 5. I am currently playing Endless Legend and getting back into Galactic Civilizations 2. 95% of strategy games I play to completion at least once. I feel that that is a decent background in the strategy genre and that it was worth mentioning to know if you want to take me seriously or not.UPlay: Yes, thank you every other reviewer who covered how UPlay is the reason we can't have nice things and the general end of gaming as we know it. I agree that this type of license control is ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t and it should go away. That being said, I had very few issues with the DRM in this game aside from a few save bobbles related to Internet connectivity. Lesson learned: If you notice your Internet drop out, DON'T LEAVE THE GAME UNTIL IT RECONNECTS, otherwise you will lose progress. That is all I have to say on UPlay because I feel that it has been adequately addressed elsewhere.Progression: Honestly, I think the progression aspect of this game, not just in terms of achievements, but in terms of the items and supplies that you can carry through successive games with you, is my favorite part of this experience. I am sure that other titles have employed this mechanism before, but it does make you feel more driven to keep playing. If there is a point at which you hit "Auto Win" because of all of the crap that you roll over, especially on higher difficulties, that point must be HUNDREDS of hours in because I didn't get there.Missions: I really appreciate the addition of the periodic missions that pop up before you enter a game. I think that these add some variety to the campaign missions and allow a player to change up the approach to a tough mission in some cases. They are a bit repetitive, and though some are simple "fetch quests", they definitely require an extra level of micromanagement in a lot of cases.Factions: I agree with some other reviewers that there could have been more factions; however, if you go in with the understanding that there are the Eco's and Industrialists, this is not detrimental.Min/maxers: I believe you will really enjoy this game. As of this writing, the Complete Edition is $12.50. Just buy it. The sale goes for another 34 hours!!!

												I'm already sorry I bought this game and I didn't even play a single minute.Here's what happens if you buy and install the game on Steam: 1. Steam downloads the game. 2. You start the game using Steam.(Note: This is where you would normally start playing the game) 3. The Anno2070 launcher opens up, downloading stuff (again). 4. You are asked to register your CD key. 5. Ubisoft's uplay client starts up. 6. YOU HAVE TO CREATE A UPLAY ACCOUNT TO PLAY THIS GAME. THERE IS NO WAY AROUND THIS. 7. uplay starts downloading stuff (again²) 8. An installer pops up, installing the game (wtf?) 9. You start the game using uplay. 10. The Anno2070 launcher pops up DOWNLOADING STUFF FOR THE FOURTH TIME. 11. The game launches. (Yay!) 12. The game realizes I bought the complete edition, closes and puts me back to the Anno2070 launcher. The launcher DOWNLOADS STUFF FOR THE FIFTH TIME. 13. The game launches again. I guess I can play. On the plus side: The game prompts me with a survey asking me how I like the experience. Ha ha.I'm♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥and I will not recommend this game even if the gameplay itself would be the greatest revelation of my life. I'm using Steam. Not Origin, not uplay, not you-name-it. I want the game and DLCs downloaded in as few steps as possible.Valve, I am deeply disappointed that this game is even for sale here. Other games were disqualified for much less, so please slap Ubisoft for this crap.

content:
Posted: February 22, 2012
												This is the first Anno game I've played.  I used to play Pharaoh and Caesar way back when, and this game brought back a lot of memories of hours spent building ancient cities.  I had a lot of fun with Anno, it's city building but more technical than SimCity, with more complexity within your control.  Mostly comes down to supply chain management, which the game does make rather difficult to maintain.  Still a fun game, but weird to think that most of the challenge is created by the lack of a good visibility into your supply chain.  I used to work on supply chain management software, so I understand the importance of having good visbility into your resource availability, which lets you leverage your vertical synergy across your extended enterprise.  Or whatever.
