content:
Posted: December 26, 2013
												Anno 2070 is a game which nearly deserves its own genre. A mixture of Total Annhiliation-style warfare and epic scale, with the micromanagement of Sim City, and the trading aspects of an empire management sim. It does so many things right, that it will just suck out your free time, like a black hole.The Tycoons are the remainder of the present-world high-industrial, short-term, high-profit, fast-building race; which have significant advantages in the early game as well as military, but struggle in the late game.The Ecos are a future-gazing civilization which try to maintain and raise their "ecobalance" (the general health of an inhabited island). They are more difficult to learn, but more rewarded overall as they have beautiful architecture, and their late-game resource demands are significantly less difficult to micro-manage than the Tycoons. They do suffer from certain technology lacks- namely the Tycoon's nuclear reactors, and battleships.The Techs and other races are "spoilers", so I'll let you discover their benefits and drawbacks on your own.Overall, Anno 2070 is highly worth the purchase, especially when it's on sale. Go grab the Complete Edition ($12 as of this writing).

content:
Posted: July 25, 2014
												Anno 2070 is my introduction to the series, I have not played any of the others.The Premise of Anno is simple, the world has flooded, you take the lead of one of two ideals of how things should work (Eco, or Tycoon) and you build up the world from there.  A third, science like organization unlocks later regardless.But Anno is an awesome title, the game play is city building/god game, that rellys much more on trade and management of trades, that isn't really found in most games.  You need to establish trade routes to ferry supplys from one island to another, to unlock more trees and get the full extent of everything you need.The ARK allows you to manipulate the world further to your liking.I highly recomend this title.

number of helpful: 9 of 16 people (56%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: November 26, 2014
												This is one of the best strategy games I've ever played. It's possible to play a relaxing game where you can build multiple cities and balance your production chains or an intense game competing with other players to gain control of valuable resources across multiple islands.If you've played any of the Caesar or older Anno games then this game should be easy to pick and play however for newer players they'll be a bit of a learning curve but once you figure out how to start controlling resources without everything going to hell in a hand basket you'll be able to enjoy hour upon hour of city building fun.I should probably also mention the DRM:TAGES and UPlay are their usual PITA so please take that into consideration before purchasing this game but as long as you're not swapping GPUs every five minutes it shouldn't be an issue.

content:
Posted: July 4, 2015
												I've yet to play the game as of yet. But I thought that it was imperative to explain to all those who have had uPlay crash during game start up (like I did).First time I ran the game, I was surprised with the length of setup. Then when uPlay finally loaded it crashed. So I ran it again, low and behold crash!Being the determined IT Tech that I am, I browsed to the default UBISoft install folder that uPlay gets installed (much to my dislike it is in C:\Program Files but what ever).Right click 'Run as Administrator', no crash!So, in order to fix the issue, uPlay just needs to be elevated into Administrator mode. Most software does this automatically, in this case you can just edit the properties of the uPlay exe to run as administrator every time.

												It's a sad day, the day I have to give an anno game a thumbs down. Having sunk over a hundred of hours into Anno 1404 - Venice I was really looking forward to a fresh start in this game, set in a different time with different, new, obstacles to overcome. number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 4, 2014
												After purchasing and installing this game I attempted to log in only to recieve the message "Uplay launcher has stopped working".  The error dialog has no further explaination of what action to take and only permits you to close it.  I am left unable to play this game.EDIT: After three days I got a reply from Ubisoft customer support with instructions on how to re-install the Uplay launcher.  For some reason all of the slash characters in the email were removed (or invisible) which made links and paths to registry entries difficult to decipher.  After some difficulty I got the Uplay launcher working which resolved my issue and allowed the game to run.For all the good work the game devs did on the actual game it's a shame that the Uplay launcher is as shoddy a piece of work as it is.  I'm not anti-DRM as long as it does NOT get in the way and is PROPERLY MAINTAINED AND SUPPORTED.  Telling customers to hand edit their registry is a VERY BAD idea.  That sort of thing is the entire reason for installers, updaters, and launchers.Bottom line: I enjoy the gameplay but the mediocre customer support and sloppily designed and maintained launcher / DRM has damaged my respect for Ubisoft.  Since I finally got it working I'm happy enough to play the game but even with that if I had the option for a refund I'd take it.

content:
Posted: November 15, 2014
												The game is a great one. The details in the movement of resources as well as taxes and other monetary management are flawless, and the warfare between factions or yourself make the game even more enjoyable. After the campaign, I thought this game would have no replay value, but I was dead wrong. The game is fun no matter how many times you play it. Overall, it's a great game.One thing I'd like to address, however, is Ubisoft's loader program, UPlay. Let me just say that the program is total $hit. You cannot use it for anything, as it won't even get past the login screen. For those of you who hate it as much as I do, try to run it in compatibility mode or as an Administrator, as that works (sometimes.) If it wasn't for that program, Anno 2070 would be the ideal game for the average RTS-loving player. Trust me, it's worth the money, but if you hate technicalities, then you might waht to stay away from this, and all Ubisoft games altogether.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 29, 2014
												Foreword: I don't recommend this game because of draconian-DRM and Ubisoft's involvement. It's a great game if you're willing to put up with that and the fairly high pricetag, but I cannot in good conscience recommend it to anyone. While Anno 2070's gameplay is solid and has a ton of replay value, Ubisoft takes a large dump all over it. I hope you like using two forms of DRM while trying to play this game. Yeah that's right, you gotta launch another DRM client that's similar to steam just to play this game. Absolutely sickening. About the gameplay: To put it vaguely it's like if you took Starcraft II and Sim City and combined the two. It's primarily a city builder game but it takes place in a real time strategy environment where you're sort of competing with other players, usually AI computer opponents because this game kind of blows as a multiplayer game, to become wealthy and technologically advanced. You start as one of two races, either industry-heavy or ecologically-friendly, then choose an island to settle on and begin building your city. Later on you can acquire a third-party race which is technologically-heavy to satisfy the end-game technologies, and you can actually have all three types of people at the same time. The tech tree for the game is pretty big, I've played for over 100 hours (65 of those hours were on Steam) and I still have not seen everything in the game.Due to randomization, different factions, lots of strategies and different AI personalities to play with/against, the game can be played in a variety of ways and has a lot of replay value. Unfortunately I feel Anno is somewhat hindered by the lack of mod-support, because after you've played with the same AI personality a few times you're kind of sick of them and there's only so many of them. The randomization of islands is also kind of limited and not as incidental as I'd hoped for. You begin to see patterns and everything feels really samey after hour 40. I really wish the Anno series overall was more mod-friendly.If you love city-building, resource management, setting up trade routes, etc. then the game can be pretty fun. The RTS-style combat is not even worth bothering with. If you dominate the map by starting wars it'll get boring really fast because the computers can never put up a good fight -- unless you set them to "Hard" difficulty which causes them to obliterate you in the first few minutes of the game with air units before its even possible to get air units (they get infinite resources and can make anything anytime they want regardless of tech tree restrictions), and that's even more boring to deal with.All in all, I really love this game, and it has quickly become one of my all-time favorite City Builder games. I just wish it had better mod-support, and less Ubisoft.Rating: B+

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 24, 2014
												I'm going to start this review off by saying that I actually do recommend this game quite highly, but only to certain people. If you are a casual gamer, turn around now. This game requires so much strategy, planning, and some luck in map generation that trying to play it as you go can and likely will screw you over later in your game. Pros:--Great fun to customize your city and build your civilization. Seriously, it gets so exciting and I really don't even know why.--Sense of accomplishment when you look at your self-sufficient society at the end of a game.Cons:--Watching your resources to figure out where your production error stems from is a pain in the♥♥♥♥♥ Fixing it can be even more so.--This game does not prepare you for itself in any way, shape, or form. I had to watch about three hours of "Let's Play" videos before I was prepared for endgame. If not daunted by this review, look up the Anno 2070 Beginner's Guide by NsN on youtube. Each of the videos is ~an hour, but they're funny so it's not a hard watch.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 27, 2014
												This game is quite good, but it is simply dwarfed by all three of it's immediate pre-decessors and even by the first game in the series ANNO 1602 when it comes to fun and playability.  ANNO 2070 somehow took everything that ANNO 1503 (The worst in the series) did wrong and selectively included most of the enjoyment killing mistakes.Anno 1440 with the Venice add-on and ANNO 1701 are certainly the best in the series as far as enjoyment and playability are concered.There is a fine line between too much and too little complexity or micro management.  Too simple and it is boring, too complex and it becomes too laborious.The whole ecologist vs industrialist thing made good valid social statement (and raises climate change awareness), but did absolutely nothing in the way of making the game fun to play.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 9, 2013
												Extremely addictive and with beautiful visuals, Anno 2070 is close to GOTY for me. The gameplay is easy to get into but has a profound complexity which slowly unfolds in regular play as your city branches out and your responsibility grows. While single-player free play can entertain you for hours on end as you attempt to foster one or several factions under growing pressure from both the environment and challenger factions, multiplayer can refresh the gameplay and make Anno 2070 feel like a whole new game. The only real drawback for this title is that it's tied to U-Play. Having to download this atrocity and go through it every time you launch the game is an annoyance I can't seem to quell, especially after the hack. [8/10]

content:
Posted: June 29, 2014
												After six hours of this game, and almost five hours of playing it, I'm simultaneous intrigued and disgusted.  It's an interesting game, but unless something changes, I may never buy from UbiSoft again.I'll start with the good parts.  Anno 2070 is basically Caesar meets Red Alert, with a clever mix of city-building and war that I've seldom seen elsewhere.  While this is ostensibly a real-time strategy game, the combat seems to take a back seat to the economic development of island settlements.  You'll have to manage raw materials, electricity, pollution levels, population, food and drinks, entertainment, and military.  Fortunately the pace is slow enough that this is actually possible.There are three playable factions, each with different production chains, and specialties.  The Ecos are stereotypical environmentalists with wind farms and tea planations, the Scientists are exactly as you'd expect, eating artificial food and building nuclear power plants, and the Tycoons are your run-of-the-mill capitalists with smoke-belching coal plants and fast food chains.  I haven't played long enough to really contrast them, but so far it seems to work out nicely.So all in all, it looks like a great game.  So why am I not recommending it?The observant among you may have noticed the one-hour discrepancy between how long I've had it and how long I've actually been playing it.  Let me start this explanation with a question:  If you buy a game on Steam and hit the "Play" button, shouldn't it just... I don't know.... Play?No, that would be too easy.  Starting Anno for the first time went something like this......Download and install.  Just as easy as with any other title on Steam.  Took a little longer than usual, but no big deal....Hit the play button... Hmm, it wants to optimize my graphics?  Sure, why not.  Save me some time cranking up all the video settings.... The game seems to load up, and throws some graphic on the screen, and then immediately returns to the desktop.  Uh, what?...Now it should launch the game, right?  Or at least a settings utility?  Nah, it has to launch an auto-updater.  Wait a second... Isn't that what Steam does?  Automatic updates?  Why is the game loading its own update utility?  Hmm......A little while later, that finishes... Time to play, right?  Wrong.  Now it needs to set up UPlay.  Apparently Ubisoft is trying to make their own Steam, and it's required for this game.  Ugh... Ok, as long as it doesn't get in the way......UPlay needs to update itself.  Two seconds after it finishes downloading, it has to update.  Did I accidentally buy an MMO?  Is this World of Warcraft?  I thought I just bought a game on Steam, a platform that keeps everything up to date on its own...  Alright, I'll go get a snack while this thing updates itself... Again....It finished updating!  Time to play!  Oh, it wants a CD Key.  Sure, no problem.  Grab it from steam, paste it in.  Done!  Let's play!...Now it wants me to create a UPlay account... That's just for online multiplayer, right?  I don't really need that... Except you can't load the game without it.  Now I'm getting angry, and if I hadn't already paid for the game, I'd have uninstalled it right there....Fine.  Here's a throwaway e-mail account.  I'll use my usual username and a simple password.... Ok, I'll use a longer password... Ok, I'll add numbers.  What the hell am I protecting, a bank account?  This is just a game!  Fine!  Now the password is annoying enough that I have to write it down somewhere....The username is taken?  Fine, here's another one.... That too?  Fine, another... Another... Another.... Just take this stupid incompehensible string of letters.  I'll write that down too... Just let me play the game already!...So, made a UPlay account.  Oh, it's not just an account.  It's an entirely new application that's probably going to destabilize my computer like so many before it.  Well, I can at least put it in offline mode.  After all, I don't plan on doing multiplayer in this game, at least not right away....Now I need to login to it.  So much for offline mode.   It made me turn that back off.  Oh well.... Username... Password... There.  What do you mean that's not a valid username?  It's the one I just created!  Try again... Nope.... Ok, here's a wild guess.  Maybe, when they say username, they really mean e-mail address.  So instead of using that username that took six tries to find one that wasn't already taken, let's just not use it at all.  So why couldn't the e-mail just be the damn username!?...Login with my e-mail and password.... FINALLY, time to play... Enter my CD-key... Didn't I do that already?  Fine, copy and paste... Nope, can't paste... Alt+Tab back and forth, entering a few characters at a time... Fine....It's loading!  It's loading!  It's the actual game!  Woohoo!...Create a character name.  Sure, no problem!  Xentor!...It's taken.  Wait, what?  I thought this was my character name... Why does it have to be unique?  Great, it's another stupid username.  Let's try a couple.  Taken, taken, taken.  To hell with it.  I'll just use the same one I used for the stupid, useless, waste-of-time UPlay account.  Ok, that works.  Now NEVER ASK ME AGAIN....The game is starting!  And the first thing it says?  It welcomes me to the game, addressing me by that stupid unique username.  The game now constantly refers to me as that gibberish username, because OBVIOUSLY anything readable was already taken.So, to my new enemies at UbiSoft... Here's a tip.  If you're going to publish on Steam, let Steam handle the DRM, because you guys obviously have no clue what you're doing.  You just lost a customer.And to those of you reading this review, considering buying the game... I leave that choice to you.  The game itself is good, but UbiSoft has tried very hard to make sure that playing it just isn't worth the effort.Graphics/Sound: 8/10Gameplay: 8/10Overall: 2/10.

content:
Posted: January 21, 2016
												Ah yes, the ANNO series - an arguably underappreciated group of citybuilder and economic strategy games. ANNO has two key features to differentiate itself from SimCity et al.: a far more involved economy and water. Lots of water, in fact. ANNO 2070 in particular is set in a future version of our world (circa 2070 CE, hence the name) where the world's ice sheets melted and made dozens of island-sized landmasses habitable. Your job is to develop a thriving city (or multiple cities) on these islands where all the needs of the population are catered to by your government. Yes, that's right: you are in charge of co-ordinating factories and production lines for everything from fish to robot butlers, hologram projectors, and jewelry. This inevitably leads to a need for trade routes between islands, sprawling production complexes both above and below water, and ways of limiting the resultant ecological damage so that a giant tornado of doom doesn't swoop down and destroy it all.It's probably evident by now, but this game can get very complicated, very quickly.Despite all my enthusiasm, there are a few features that detract from the game (constant internet access is required for DRM and a couple gameplay elements), but they present few problems in actual gameplay. I would highly recommend picking up this under-recognised title both for a mental challenge and the calming effect of just watching a massive empire run like clockwork.

content:
Posted: August 31, 2014
												UPDATE: I have now discovered that there's no way to view detailed information about the economy. This makes it a matter of trial and error to determine how much of what you need to produce. Which I find very frustrating. While I really enjoyed the time I did play the game, I now find myself wishing I'd spent that $30 on beer instead. I have thus updated my review to not recommend the game. It's a brilliant game that's just poorly executed. However, if you're considering it, I do recommend reading the rest of my review. The straw that broke the camel's back for me may not bother you as much.Original review is all of the following.TL;DR: This game is sort of in the gray area between SimCity and Civilization (closer to Banished than SimCity as far as city-builders go, if you've played that). It's a brilliant game, but with very noticeable cons. As gameplay isn't really affected by these issues, I'd describe the experience of playing this game as sort of like seeing a fantastic movie in a crappy theatre with uncomfortable chairs and somebody texting a few rows up. You still really enjoy it, but there are small things that bother you a little bit the whole time.More details: I have many things I like, or even love, about this game. Many things about it are simply brilliant. However, before getting to those, let me first list the caveats without which I would not recommend it. Some of these may be a dealbreaker for you.-Uplay is very, very annoying. I consider Steam like the iTunes of gaming, and it's as though one record label was like "okay well you can listen to our music through iTunes, but only if you also open up our other music player software and first validate that you did indeed buy the music." It doesn't prohibit playing, but it's very, very annoying. It's just an extra step that's both unnecessary and inconvenient. And those extra steps add quite a bit of time between purchasing and actually playing, probably a solid 20 minutes.-The interface and keyboard controls are very counterintuitive (x and y to rotate the camera, really?), and there's no tutorial on how to play. I only figured out how to use this game with extensive use of Google on my phone. This is the sort of stuff one might expect or tolerate from an inexperienced indie developer's first game, but from a big name like Ubisoft it just feels like laziness. Either way, it makes the learning curve much steeper than it should be, and led to a few exasperated shouting matches with my desktop.-The cities seem to lack some things that are fundamental in other city builders. For example, there seems to be very little by way of transportation management. However, there are certainly other areas of the gameplay that make up for this, it's still overall a good game. Not necessarily inferior to other city builders, but definitely different from them. Like I mentioned earlier, it's much closer to Banished than SimCity as far as city builders go. Don't expect SimCity (you place every single building, for example, which is like Banished but unlike SimCity).-At $30, I find it a little overpriced. $20 would be a deal, and $25 would be reasonable.However, now let me get to why I do still recommend this game:-The gameplay is *awesome.* I've only done "continuous" mode (as opposed to campaign mode), and It's somewhere in the middle ground between SimCity and Civilization. You build your city on your island, but you have to explore the surrounding area to discover neighbors or uninhabited islands, and can engage in diplomacy or trade with them. Each map has so many islands, and you can expand to the uninhabited ones. In fact, you have to do that or trade to be succesful, because no single island would be self-sufficient for an advanced city. The way cities almost "level" based on what different classes of people demand and can produce is simply brilliant.-The economy is *very* well done. This is really my favorite part of the game.-The difficulty levels are well done. Easy mode is easy, but not pointless. It's just an easier version of a still very interesting and rewarding strategy game.-The backstory is coherent, intelligent, and complex. Which doesn't necessarily affect gameplay, but is nonetheless something I really appreciate. It's not without its simplifications that may annoy some of the more pedantic players, but definitely a big step above the norm for this sort of thing. The world you build in is still a thoroughly sci-fi/fantasy world, though, it doesn't feel like anything that might actually be around 56 years from now.-There are a lot of small details that are well done. When you zoom in, for example, you can hear what people are saying based on their class and satisfaction level.Several things I have yet to try, so can't remark on:-Combat-Advanced diplomacy-Campaign modeOverall, I definitely think the pros make up for the cons. I wholeheartedly recommend it, as long as you know what to expect.

content:
Posted: June 13, 2014
												Things I Liked:Great Aesthetic - has a distinct style to the UI and the game itselfInteresting Options - class etc. mattersUnits are Fun to Test - each one does something different, or has different qualitiesWar is not Necessary - possible to play peacefullyThings I Didn't:Uplay - can't be played from Steam directlyPrice - is a little overpriced at £15A Little Old - graphics can look a little dated and the story is a little clichédAnno 2070 is a futuristic real time strategy/city builder hybrid game from Ubisoft studios. It was released in November 2011 and is a great game. I've put 7 hour sessions into this game, and I show no signs of stopping. It is a new, futuristic step in the series, and is a strong one.The basic premise of the game is that the world's sea levels have risen and previous landmasses have become islands, and uninhabitable wastelands have become paradises. It is your mission to repopulate the world from your ark - a kind of sea station.The ocean is a major focus of this game Much of the expansion and all battle and trading is done by sea. This makes a unit's speed, carrying capacity, armour and damage ever more important. The trading mechanism works really well, being able to set up a different route with each unit is easy and intuitive.The game is great. It has an interesting style and great development of cities - better in my opinion than the newer Sim Cities. For example, my capital city on my industrial playthrough was growing and I was doing well, and I expanded onto another island. When I went back to my capital, I realised how dense the smog was around the city. It's details like that that really help build immersion and realism.It's easy to sink hours into a game and not reach the endgame, or even the midgame. If you are a fan of real time strategy games like Age of Empires, then this game is a perfect purchase for you. This award winning mixture of diplomacy, war and construction is sure to win you over to it.

content:
Posted: June 29, 2014
												After six hours of this game, and almost five hours of playing it, I'm simultaneous intrigued and disgusted.  It's an interesting game, but unless something changes, I may never buy from UbiSoft again.I'll start with the good parts.  Anno 2070 is basically Caesar meets Red Alert, with a clever mix of city-building and war that I've seldom seen elsewhere.  While this is ostensibly a real-time strategy game, the combat seems to take a back seat to the economic development of island settlements.  You'll have to manage raw materials, electricity, pollution levels, population, food and drinks, entertainment, and military.  Fortunately the pace is slow enough that this is actually possible.There are three playable factions, each with different production chains, and specialties.  The Ecos are stereotypical environmentalists with wind farms and tea planations, the Scientists are exactly as you'd expect, eating artificial food and building nuclear power plants, and the Tycoons are your run-of-the-mill capitalists with smoke-belching coal plants and fast food chains.  I haven't played long enough to really contrast them, but so far it seems to work out nicely.So all in all, it looks like a great game.  So why am I not recommending it?The observant among you may have noticed the one-hour discrepancy between how long I've had it and how long I've actually been playing it.  Let me start this explanation with a question:  If you buy a game on Steam and hit the "Play" button, shouldn't it just... I don't know.... Play?No, that would be too easy.  Starting Anno for the first time went something like this......Download and install.  Just as easy as with any other title on Steam.  Took a little longer than usual, but no big deal....Hit the play button... Hmm, it wants to optimize my graphics?  Sure, why not.  Save me some time cranking up all the video settings.... The game seems to load up, and throws some graphic on the screen, and then immediately returns to the desktop.  Uh, what?...Now it should launch the game, right?  Or at least a settings utility?  Nah, it has to launch an auto-updater.  Wait a second... Isn't that what Steam does?  Automatic updates?  Why is the game loading its own update utility?  Hmm......A little while later, that finishes... Time to play, right?  Wrong.  Now it needs to set up UPlay.  Apparently Ubisoft is trying to make their own Steam, and it's required for this game.  Ugh... Ok, as long as it doesn't get in the way......UPlay needs to update itself.  Two seconds after it finishes downloading, it has to update.  Did I accidentally buy an MMO?  Is this World of Warcraft?  I thought I just bought a game on Steam, a platform that keeps everything up to date on its own...  Alright, I'll go get a snack while this thing updates itself... Again....It finished updating!  Time to play!  Oh, it wants a CD Key.  Sure, no problem.  Grab it from steam, paste it in.  Done!  Let's play!...Now it wants me to create a UPlay account... That's just for online multiplayer, right?  I don't really need that... Except you can't load the game without it.  Now I'm getting angry, and if I hadn't already paid for the game, I'd have uninstalled it right there....Fine.  Here's a throwaway e-mail account.  I'll use my usual username and a simple password.... Ok, I'll use a longer password... Ok, I'll add numbers.  What the hell am I protecting, a bank account?  This is just a game!  Fine!  Now the password is annoying enough that I have to write it down somewhere....The username is taken?  Fine, here's another one.... That too?  Fine, another... Another... Another.... Just take this stupid incompehensible string of letters.  I'll write that down too... Just let me play the game already!...So, made a UPlay account.  Oh, it's not just an account.  It's an entirely new application that's probably going to destabilize my computer like so many before it.  Well, I can at least put it in offline mode.  After all, I don't plan on doing multiplayer in this game, at least not right away....Now I need to login to it.  So much for offline mode.   It made me turn that back off.  Oh well.... Username... Password... There.  What do you mean that's not a valid username?  It's the one I just created!  Try again... Nope.... Ok, here's a wild guess.  Maybe, when they say username, they really mean e-mail address.  So instead of using that username that took six tries to find one that wasn't already taken, let's just not use it at all.  So why couldn't the e-mail just be the damn username!?...Login with my e-mail and password.... FINALLY, time to play... Enter my CD-key... Didn't I do that already?  Fine, copy and paste... Nope, can't paste... Alt+Tab back and forth, entering a few characters at a time... Fine....It's loading!  It's loading!  It's the actual game!  Woohoo!...Create a character name.  Sure, no problem!  Xentor!...It's taken.  Wait, what?  I thought this was my character name... Why does it have to be unique?  Great, it's another stupid username.  Let's try a couple.  Taken, taken, taken.  To hell with it.  I'll just use the same one I used for the stupid, useless, waste-of-time UPlay account.  Ok, that works.  Now NEVER ASK ME AGAIN....The game is starting!  And the first thing it says?  It welcomes me to the game, addressing me by that stupid unique username.  The game now constantly refers to me as that gibberish username, because OBVIOUSLY anything readable was already taken.So, to my new enemies at UbiSoft... Here's a tip.  If you're going to publish on Steam, let Steam handle the DRM, because you guys obviously have no clue what you're doing.  You just lost a customer.And to those of you reading this review, considering buying the game... I leave that choice to you.  The game itself is good, but UbiSoft has tried very hard to make sure that playing it just isn't worth the effort.Graphics/Sound: 8/10Gameplay: 8/10Overall: 2/10.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 31, 2014
												UPDATE: I have now discovered that there's no way to view detailed information about the economy. This makes it a matter of trial and error to determine how much of what you need to produce. Which I find very frustrating. While I really enjoyed the time I did play the game, I now find myself wishing I'd spent that $30 on beer instead. I have thus updated my review to not recommend the game. It's a brilliant game that's just poorly executed. However, if you're considering it, I do recommend reading the rest of my review. The straw that broke the camel's back for me may not bother you as much.Original review is all of the following.TL;DR: This game is sort of in the gray area between SimCity and Civilization (closer to Banished than SimCity as far as city-builders go, if you've played that). It's a brilliant game, but with very noticeable cons. As gameplay isn't really affected by these issues, I'd describe the experience of playing this game as sort of like seeing a fantastic movie in a crappy theatre with uncomfortable chairs and somebody texting a few rows up. You still really enjoy it, but there are small things that bother you a little bit the whole time.More details: I have many things I like, or even love, about this game. Many things about it are simply brilliant. However, before getting to those, let me first list the caveats without which I would not recommend it. Some of these may be a dealbreaker for you.-Uplay is very, very annoying. I consider Steam like the iTunes of gaming, and it's as though one record label was like "okay well you can listen to our music through iTunes, but only if you also open up our other music player software and first validate that you did indeed buy the music." It doesn't prohibit playing, but it's very, very annoying. It's just an extra step that's both unnecessary and inconvenient. And those extra steps add quite a bit of time between purchasing and actually playing, probably a solid 20 minutes.-The interface and keyboard controls are very counterintuitive (x and y to rotate the camera, really?), and there's no tutorial on how to play. I only figured out how to use this game with extensive use of Google on my phone. This is the sort of stuff one might expect or tolerate from an inexperienced indie developer's first game, but from a big name like Ubisoft it just feels like laziness. Either way, it makes the learning curve much steeper than it should be, and led to a few exasperated shouting matches with my desktop.-The cities seem to lack some things that are fundamental in other city builders. For example, there seems to be very little by way of transportation management. However, there are certainly other areas of the gameplay that make up for this, it's still overall a good game. Not necessarily inferior to other city builders, but definitely different from them. Like I mentioned earlier, it's much closer to Banished than SimCity as far as city builders go. Don't expect SimCity (you place every single building, for example, which is like Banished but unlike SimCity).-At $30, I find it a little overpriced. $20 would be a deal, and $25 would be reasonable.However, now let me get to why I do still recommend this game:-The gameplay is *awesome.* I've only done "continuous" mode (as opposed to campaign mode), and It's somewhere in the middle ground between SimCity and Civilization. You build your city on your island, but you have to explore the surrounding area to discover neighbors or uninhabited islands, and can engage in diplomacy or trade with them. Each map has so many islands, and you can expand to the uninhabited ones. In fact, you have to do that or trade to be succesful, because no single island would be self-sufficient for an advanced city. The way cities almost "level" based on what different classes of people demand and can produce is simply brilliant.-The economy is *very* well done. This is really my favorite part of the game.-The difficulty levels are well done. Easy mode is easy, but not pointless. It's just an easier version of a still very interesting and rewarding strategy game.-The backstory is coherent, intelligent, and complex. Which doesn't necessarily affect gameplay, but is nonetheless something I really appreciate. It's not without its simplifications that may annoy some of the more pedantic players, but definitely a big step above the norm for this sort of thing. The world you build in is still a thoroughly sci-fi/fantasy world, though, it doesn't feel like anything that might actually be around 56 years from now.-There are a lot of small details that are well done. When you zoom in, for example, you can hear what people are saying based on their class and satisfaction level.Several things I have yet to try, so can't remark on:-Combat-Advanced diplomacy-Campaign modeOverall, I definitely think the pros make up for the cons. I wholeheartedly recommend it, as long as you know what to expect.

content:
Posted: August 30, 2015
												This is a review of Anno 2070, nothing more and nothing less. I point this out because it pains me to see this have mixed reviews when most of the reviews of the game itself are in fact, positive. I get it, people do not like the DRM or Ubisoft and want to slam them, but this is not the place for that because I have had no problems with the DRM, and Ubisoft is no different than a lot of big publishers in their practices.Now, with that out of the way let us get down to what we're all here for. Is this game any good? Yes, without a doubt I fully recommend this game to anyone that is a fan of both economy style games, and city builders. The game looks fantastic, runs smoothly, and can be as hard or as easy as you want it to be. With the addition of an internet connection, more features open up as well as multiplayer options which can make for some awesome games.The premise of the game is that the world is flooded, and there is little land left to live on. As a result, you are tasked with building a new future with the aid of your Ark, which is basically a mobile sea base that is also a submarine. You'll find yourself tasked with building up housing, industry, trade, and in some cases raising a military. Additionally, you'll find 3 factions striving to get your attention, each with their own bonuses and drawbacks. Unlike some games, you can work with all 3, and to some extent a minimal level of cooperation is required. Last but certainly not least, you'll also need to manage the eco balance, because it will affect you in positive and negative ways.It is pretty simple to dive into the game, and as you progress you will find that your people demand higher quality goods, which require more complex trade routes and industries. For example, at first your people are cool with just fish, but eventually your people will be asking for things like cheeseburgers, or even lobster dinners!For a greater challenge, you'll find other players (Human or AI) that will also be trying to build their colonies up as well. With limited resources, this will eventually lead to trading partnerships, or outright war. The 3 factions vying for your attention will also be offering missions with various bonus resources or modules to improve your units or buildings.If you are connected to the internet, if you're getting bored with your current map, or you've obliterated the competition, you can take resources from the current map in limited quantities, and have a boost to the next map! Also, you can participate in global politics that will result in actual bonuses that other players have voted on.Overall, I highly recommend this game. Even if I put it down for a few weeks to play something else, I keep coming back, and that is a sign of a good game.

content:

												Great game, but as everyone else says, uPlay is garbage.  I played this game for many hours over a year ago, and I just built a new PC and wanted something to play.  All the new games are too expensive at the moment, so I thought I'd go back to Anno since the new release is coming soon I felt the nostalgia.  Boy, I had forgotten just what garbage Ubisoft is.  The fact that this game is getting mixed reviews is solely based on the horrible experience provided by their lousy uPlay system.  If they are going to release a game through steam, they had better be darned sure that it works.That all said, the game itself is great.  If you can get through installing it - and then consequently repairing it and googling around for answers on how to actually make it run, then it's a nice reward.  Just be prepared for a lot of frustration.  You need to be someone who can hunt down problems and fix them, or else you won't even get to start the game.So, I'm not actually recommending it since the newer game is coming.  I don't think there is any kind of important back story that you would want to play through before getting the newer game, so it's best to leave this one be.  Hopefully the install and configuration will be worked out in the new game and people can get back to reviewing the actual game and not the terrible company that is producing it.

content:
Posted: October 9, 2015
												Great game, but as everyone else says, uPlay is garbage.  I played this game for many hours over a year ago, and I just built a new PC and wanted something to play.  All the new games are too expensive at the moment, so I thought I'd go back to Anno since the new release is coming soon I felt the nostalgia.  Boy, I had forgotten just what garbage Ubisoft is.  The fact that this game is getting mixed reviews is solely based on the horrible experience provided by their lousy uPlay system.  If they are going to release a game through steam, they had better be darned sure that it works.That all said, the game itself is great.  If you can get through installing it - and then consequently repairing it and googling around for answers on how to actually make it run, then it's a nice reward.  Just be prepared for a lot of frustration.  You need to be someone who can hunt down problems and fix them, or else you won't even get to start the game.So, I'm not actually recommending it since the newer game is coming.  I don't think there is any kind of important back story that you would want to play through before getting the newer game, so it's best to leave this one be.  Hopefully the install and configuration will be worked out in the new game and people can get back to reviewing the actual game and not the terrible company that is producing it.

number of helpful: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 12, 2013
												a complex but easy to grasp resource system, lots of excellent usability features and concepts all around and a very very nice UI / HUD (for a transportation / resource management game, i find their UI is often very poorly done), BEAUTIFL graphics...I love playing this game competetively against friends and AI, but I also find I love playing in a very easy game mode where I can basically just build aesthetically pleasing settlements. The underwater mechanic is also extremely well done and very interesting.My only gripe is that the two "sides" are pretty contrived and extremist...you're either insanely anti-environment or pro-environment, it would be nice to have some intermediate or other teams to play, but honestly it's not much of a complaint, it fits the overall theme of the game really well.the two teams also play completely differently, which is very refreshing - most games would take the easy way out and just make a carbon copy for a new team and only change the visual aspects, but they are literally different in almost every way, from the resources you collect, to how your tech trees expand, down to your individual units.i recommend this to ANYONE who likes any kind of resource management, transportation, combat-lite, etc. fantastic game, worth every penny.

number of helpful: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 14, 2013
												SOMEONE BUY THIS SO WE CAN PLAY CO-OP PLS. :DCity building, researching, ocean exploring... I haven't played a combination like this since Outpost 2 in the 90s. If you like elements of the Civilization series mixed with RTS and pretty city placement, grab this. Lot's of fun, tons of unlockables, open-ended maps, and replay value. You can play as 2 factions (Ecos or Tycoons) with harmonize-with and♥♥♥♥♥♥pillage the eco-system playstyles. For instance, the Ecos use wind turbines that don't produce much power, but have no negative eco-impact. The Tycoons, on the other hand, burn coal in churning factories supplied by strip-mining.This is a VERY PRETTY GAME. Check my screenshots, it even has a postcard mode for capping. The economy is centered around leveling up your citizens. Certain ranks of citizen require certain needs to be fulfilled before they'll upgrade to the next class, granting you more buildings to build, and higher tax revenue.  For instance, starter Tycoon employees just need fish and alchohol to get by. If you build a Casino nearby, however, their need for entertainment is fulfilled, and they'll upgrade their housing.There is a myriad of raw materials to process, which factors in to the whole ecosystem thing. The game is set in a post-global-warming Earth, so most maps are small islands in a large ocean, and different islands have different crops they can provide, and minerals to mine. This is where competition with AI or human players comes in: You can diplomatically trade for rights to settle, or the goods you need, or you can build a war fleet and attack.Combat is fun, and rewarding, as it takes quite an economy to back a successful navy, and you can upgrade your ships with parts you research.I've only really scratched the surface, and there's more to say about the game, but I hope I've provided enough flavor to interest you.The only real downside to Anno 2070 is the secondary UPlay softward you have to install to play it. It's spotty, unnecessary, and has kept me from playing the game more than once because the servers were down, though they have added an Offline mode that works.BOTTOM LINE: FUN CITY BUILDER. BUY, PLAY CO-OP WITH ME. DRM IS STUPID.

number of helpful: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 16, 2014
												I can understand the negative meaning about Uplay. It would be very fine without that.But anyhow, I do not endorse to talk down a game because of a copy protection / user login method.It is a very nice and interesting game, that I recommend - the Anno series (originally from Sunflowers) is unique in it's way! And although I was in fact sceptical about an Anno, playing not in the past, it is really fun playing - even after about 2 years and about 200 hours * - the publishers have made it to keep the feeling and atmosphere of the earlier sequels.The improvements in goods chains, diversity and also graphics and sounds - not to forget the ark, where you can store goods or items from game to game, career points/daily tasks - do not go without notice ... from 1602 to 1701 to 1404 and now to 2070.Even positive to tell is, that not like 1701, also beginners can switch to an easy enough difficulty mode.So my conclusion: If you tend to grumble about a few seconds waiting on Uplay ... do not buy.  If you can wait on a login (and you know that Ubi is not the only company, who want to save their software against piracy) and you want to play and support a very good, interesting and somehow challenging ... then buy and have fun.I am - for my person - hope that it will not be the last sequel (even it could be hard to better the game itself). That is for sure the reason, I do not like those reviews, telling only about Uplay!!PS: * My gaming hours are only the ones from the Steam version

content:
Posted: December 16, 2014
												I can understand the negative meaning about Uplay. It would be very fine without that.But anyhow, I do not endorse to talk down a game because of a copy protection / user login method.It is a very nice and interesting game, that I recommend - the Anno series (originally from Sunflowers) is unique in it's way! And although I was in fact sceptical about an Anno, playing not in the past, it is really fun playing - even after about 2 years and about 200 hours * - the publishers have made it to keep the feeling and atmosphere of the earlier sequels.The improvements in goods chains, diversity and also graphics and sounds - not to forget the ark, where you can store goods or items from game to game, career points/daily tasks - do not go without notice ... from 1602 to 1701 to 1404 and now to 2070.Even positive to tell is, that not like 1701, also beginners can switch to an easy enough difficulty mode.So my conclusion: If you tend to grumble about a few seconds waiting on Uplay ... do not buy.  If you can wait on a login (and you know that Ubi is not the only company, who want to save their software against piracy) and you want to play and support a very good, interesting and somehow challenging ... then buy and have fun.I am - for my person - hope that it will not be the last sequel (even it could be hard to better the game itself). That is for sure the reason, I do not like those reviews, telling only about Uplay!!PS: * My gaming hours are only the ones from the Steam version

content:
Posted: June 26, 2014
												I decided to rewrite this review one more time to decrease the high rate of fangirling that it had.This game is an RTS and a city builder at the same time, but the RTS features are much stronger and apparent than the city builder ones, however, what makes it different from regular RTS games is that it relies on economic dominance instead of using gun power, armed units are only there to protect trading routes and keep pirates and enemies away.The game's challenging because you have to colonize a number of islands and build underwater settlements to stay ahead of opponents and enemies who will be doing the same.It has a multiplayer feature but it's poorly optimized and hardly populated to consider it a working feature.It gets new missions added every once in a while and has career points that will unlock better technologies in the game, as for the DLCs, I recommend getting Deep Ocean only because it's the only one that actually adds a good enough content to the game instead of just throwing some lousy cosmetics at your face.The game is beautiful and runs smoothly even on low spec systems.At last, the game is really immersive and fun with 2 main factions to choose from and if you managed to get over the fact that it requires Uplay to work then you'll actually enjoy it.

content:
Posted: August 1, 2015
												A very pretty game with the promise of a well balanced, relaxing strategy experience. But then you have to use Uplay. If you are still ignorant of the evil that is Uplay consider yourself blessed and move on. As far as the actual game goes, It's a very pretty, mildly entertaining Strategy/City builder game.Unfortunately the game is far more complex than it initially appears, and does either a poor job of explaining itself, or not at all. I had to constantly refer to various Wikis and forums just to figure out what the heck the game wanted from me. And while I expected it to carry an evironmental protection message, I wasn't expecting it to beat me over the head with it constantly. Even the gameplay reflects this, to the point that the tycoon faction can barely do anything without summoning a storm of acid rain, or a giant oil spill. Personnally it felt as though the only viable choice for long term success was to choose the green  Eden faction, which may reflect the real world, but when the game sacrifices balanced gameplay for preaching it made me loose interest very quickly

content:
Posted: July 31, 2015
												The thing that really ruined it for me was having the right resources on the right island. Sure you can set up complex trade routes, sure you can buy a bit off the AI but it's never enough. There are simply too many different resources being needed on different islands and when you never have what you need it's extremely frustrating and basically it ruins the game. It would be a lot better if there was simply a way you could have your own ships automatically go round stocking each island that has a resource level below the minimum amount you specify. Anno is focused so heavily on multiple islands working together yet the game lacks anything that makes your life as easy as it should be. Anno 1404 was alright but this is just unplayably boring. Unless you enjoy spending all your time restocking islands and waiting for them to get restocked, don't waste your money even if it's on sale, you'll just feel ripped off.

number of helpful: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 20, 2013
												Yo ho ho and a bottle of rum, fifteen men in a dead man's accusation of piracy against an environmentally conscious consumer.Batten down the hatches as Irreverend Opinions dives into Anno 2070.---The BlurbAnno 2070 is an environmentally-themed conquest strategy game. The world has been flooded thanks to climate change, with sea levels and temperature changes making it a much different Earth to what we're used to. Between the primarily naval battles, the game also runs a coherent online society to make it seem like you're having to cope with a new age of humanity.The GoodThe game is quite good once you can play it. There's a simple enough tech tree, and a somewhat believable system of diplomacy and trade.Combat is interesting, as is base building, with major crops dictated by regional fertilities, and having an impact on the game.The graphics are pleasant and thought out, with units and buildings looking the part one would expect from the various groups and organisations of the future.Multiplayer, and metagame-multiplayer, are both done very well, with a fairly interesting social media style play choices along with a balanced matchmaking engine.Despite the issues with installing, the tech support were very accomodating once they accepted the problem was legitimate, and it felt like they did a lot to fix the issues, especially the ones they were used to.An 'ongoing' campaign means you can keep building up your personal base without restrictions.The BadThe voices of characters can be really repetitive after a while, since the types of conversation they have don't really cycle all that much.  They speak a lot, so it becomes necessary after a while to actually turn the voices off if you don't really feel like putting up with it.The game engine has some optimization and performance issues - on a high-powered gaming system, sometimes  slowdowns will occur with nothing else running.The benefits of advancing through the different factions are mostly cosmetic - and not that amazing, at that.The UPlay interface takes a very long time to load, and the installation can be glitchy as all hell.The UglyThis is the unfortunate part.Popup notices for "Anno Online" blight the UI on occasion, though Ubisoft seems to have learned not to do this lately.  This isn't a facebook game, please don't thrust your latest fad in my face.  In fact, thrusting anything in my face is a bad career choice.The game was nightmarish to first install, with Ubisoft customer support not recognising the "Complete" package on offer here on Steam, resulting in UPlay not showing the DLC purchased.Customer support then seemed more inclined to ignore the Steam page proferred as explanation in order to accuse me of piracy.  Not the seafaring kind with flags and drunken antics and bawdy shanties.  The kind with download restrictions and court cases.Needless to say, that did not go over well.  Especially since it took a lot of work to actually get them to pass me to tech support so that the installation could be completed.Repeated messages about their player and payment record security being compromised and my needing to change my password and/or credit card details did nothing for peace of mind.SuggestionsDear Ubisoft.  If your account security is poor, improve it, or limit what you can host on the server.Please also update your customer service staff on what products are being sold.  Being accused of a crime you have not committed is a criminal offense here in Australia, and it lends literally negative weight to the support you give for "corporations can be responsible with their infringement enforcement" arguments.If you have honestly stopped with the popups, then thank you for your adapting to the modern player's mindset of not wanting to get advertisements in a paid-for product.  If you've only stopped because you've run out of things to sell, I should like to point out that if you do this again, I will make a point of not buying that product until it's available through a Humble bundle, or a 90% off Steam sale.Please fix up the default voice acting so that there's less repetition.And to repeat: never, never accuse a paying customer of piracy.  They will remember that long after you've fixed the mistake.The Summary8/10.  Besieged by technical woes and even worse executive decisions, but supported on being a fun game and having good customer support.  Eventually.---If you liked this review or want to see more recommended games, be sure to follow our curator group: Follow Original Curator Group

content:
Posted: February 1, 2014
												Gameplay bugs, an unintuitive interface and complete lack of a good tutorial make this game unplayable for me. My play stopped on mission 3 when attempting to collect a water sample. The item was collected, went to take it to the ark to find I couldn't complete the quest,I'd like to say this future set post apocalyptic RTS was fun up to this point but I'd be lying. Linear quests and an unclear objective structure meant that the game felt more like completing chores than creating an active, thriving future economy. My hopes were dashed after my expectations were set so high. Beautiful graphics and a good concept backing the game up, I could hardly see how they could have got it wrong - but they have and badly.From tussling with multiple screens in the Uplay DRM (waiting about 30 minutes to play the game after download is a joke) to actually trying to achieve anything in the game without scrolling through in-game menus and consulting Google, Anno 2070 is not fun in the slightest. When the real challenge and time spent in a game is trying to figure out the ambiguous objective points it’s setting you, there's little fun to be had.

content:
Posted: January 11, 2014
												Note: I own ANNO 1701 & ANNO 1404As far as the ANNO series goes ANNO 2070 is the most "featured" of the games.  I enjoy it as a game but I wouldn't recommend it.  The reason being the following;1)  The graphics aren't as good as ANNO 1404.  Most of the game is dark or cool toned with only 1 climate.  Both ANNO 1701 & ANNO 1404 feature bright vibrant colors and the maps have nice water effects that change color as you traverse the world in your boat.  Northern isles have a very dark green water color, southern isles have a very nice tropical look and effect.  ANNO 2070 does not.2) It's super duper preachy.  The game is a hot jumbled mess of trying to teach you how important the environment is.  Or that mankind is destroying the environment.  It's no coincidence that the best and the most necessary energy production plants are "green tech".  Even if you pick Tycoon (which is a captialist/pro big business faction) you still need to build things like a Hydroelectric dam because you just cant sustain islands with Nuclear power (unless you have the proper research to reduce meltdowns).  Which is funny because apparently in the future all nuclear power plants seem to melt down.  3) Compared to ANNO 1404 it feels like a reskinning of 1404 with a future setting.  The Tech faction can easily be compared to the Orient Class.  What does ANNO 2070 do right?Multiplayer and nukes.  If you can try to play 1701 or 1404 give those a try before you decide to buy any of the ANNO games.  In my opinion 1701 is the crown jewel of the series.

content:
Posted: July 13, 2015
												When I first got the game, I didn't think that it will be alot. I was expecting some mere farm-house-storehouse-palace network of economy and protecting your land from the invaders, etc.However, I was ever so greatly pleased to soon realise that the economy tree in the game is rich and you can spend hours and hours just enjoying watching how things develop. Politics in the game are also quite good, you get reputation for achieving quests from different factions, which usually involve you in further development.The idea of Ecos and Tycoons (two possible factions) is very pleasing to me personally too. Techs (third faction) are providing lots of benefits to building your economical titan of a city. And with the Deep Ocean DLC life becomes even more interesting,The fighting in the game is not as pretty though, alas, and it's probably for the best if the player is not depending on that entirely.I give 8.9/10

number of helpful: 9 of 17 people (53%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 28, 2015
												This is mostly to help counter balance all the reviews giving it a negative score simply because of uplay, that's not how you review a game and certainly not something that should give it a negative score. This is a fantastic game in the Anno series, simple beginnings and as you develop more and more it grows to be more complex, you have the usual rivalries with other persons and grow your economy, manage trade-routes, and (hopefully) get the resources most favorable to your ever continueing expansion. As you grow you gain more ways to develop, science is of course an important part of this later on as well as deep-sea (which is part of it) which is a nice addition to the game. Choose which faction you start with and whom you align with, vote in the Senate with other players to see what effects you'll get, have (occasional) special events pop up which give you story and unique rewards for completing the challenges they bring. You also have the ARK (if I remember the name right) which is your personal HQ of sorts, it can carry over some of the things you developed for future worlds you play in as well as some resources, in this way it can help you feel that what you did previously mattered, that what you made still exists and this new zone you are going to is yet another of your many expansions. Truly my only complaints with this game are that the AI I don't consider quite as good as in Anno 1404, the development of their island is in a way that wouldn't make sense economically and wouldn't work normally really with some of the AI players, which is unfortunate. I'd have much preferred if they had the same limitations as the player and just did well that way, and that they would be a tad more aggressive with claiming islands. Other than that, there is of course personal preference. Some people don't like the time period, which is fair. But objectively this is a very nice game in the series and I would heartily recommend for people to get it if they don't mind these shortcomings, it adds quite a bit to the series and it has a lot of replayability.

number of helpful: 3 of 6 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 17, 2014
												Anno 2070 delivers a concept very similar to many real time strategies I have encountered, and I would say it stands between a future iteration of Age of Empires, and Civilisation. The game's premise lies on diplomacy and civilisation construction in the near future, and has landgrab elements behind it.First off, first impressions of the game are dire. After installing it from Steam, you are forced through a convoluted system of using Ubisoft's own launcher to run it. Don't have a Ubisoft account? You're forced to make one, and install all their periphery software. After installing the game, it took me around half an hour to begin playing it, due to all the "required" set up protocols from Ubisoft.The learning curve to play the game I found very steep, regardless of the fact I have played games in a similar genre. All the information for the game is written up in an interface, but I'm the sort of gamer who wants to jump into a game and start playing. Had their tutorial levels been more developed, I wouldn't have had to access this information. Another utility they provide to help is an AI character, which doesn't seem to perform much, apart from sounding fairly artificial (If you pardon the pun). I had the impression that the game's development could be a lot better.In terms of the missions, they make sense, and are enjoyable to play, after getting past the hurdle of learning the ropes. The visuals are appealing, but not fantastic, still, effort has gone into that area. Their character progression system is rewarding, but I am dissapointed they have not provided Steam Achievements, only their Ubisoft equivalents.So all in all, I would give this game a 67%.Would I buy it? I already own age of empires and civilisation. There's nothing groundbreaking about this game.

content:
Posted: August 1, 2013
												I recommend this game to people like me who enjoy strategic games, but don't feel the need to play a competitive match for fulfillment.  However, unlike almost pure sandbox games with small goals thrown in (like Rollercoaster Tycoon or the unique Cities in Motion), the challenge of Anno 2070 and its predecesors comes from the environment itself, making it a stimulating challenge.  The incredible length of a single game will put most people off, but it has great replayability in the sense that you'll still be discovering/optimizing/inventing after your hundredth hour of gameplay.  For those familiar with the earlier games in the series, it is a genius translation to modern times.

Posted: January 4, 2014
												A very slow paced, but complex and immersive real time strategy experience. Less about churning out tanks and trying to research orbital lasers as fast as possible, and more about developing a strong economic environment, well maintained and well protected from external threats. The closest analogy would be; the style of play of Sim City and Age of Empires, and the setting of Brink. All in all, a rewarding play experience, well worth the price.

content:
Posted: June 23, 2014
												Anno 2070 is easily the prettiest town building, resource gathering strategy,. that Ive ever played.  At first I thought it was a bit odd compared to the others out there, but it quickly became my favorite.  Thats my opinion of the game,Here's my obligatory Uplay rantA lot of people review this game unfairly because of the Uplay overlay and DRM.   I think its wrong because, even though purchases will have to deal with it, and it should be mentioned, and perhaps affect the score some, the score really should be about the game and its content.  That's what we are meant to rate.  Dramatically bashing the game because of some umbrella DRM like Uplay has a greater affect on the people who worked hard to make the game than it ever will on the corporate giant that published it.That being said, Uplay really isnt so bad, Except wihen things like a forgotten password or some bizarre file management hiccup ruins your whole gaming experience.  for some being forced to do business with the commonly unliked publisher is enough cause to boycott the product.  Though the only one I can think of is that I was able to use Uplay points to buy free content in Assassins Creed IV.  But I doubt they are going to change their business model because of complaints from users-- as sad as that sounds, they likely aren't listening, or just have no control over their own investments.  The biggest problem I have with the Overlay, is that it causes clutter and confusion in my software libraries and accounts.  Steam is nice, because it centralizes and organizes things, its stupid to have two overlays with their own complicated API between them, both verifying, listing, and managing my game content.  And I wouldn't appreciate having a separate account and separate library for just my ubisoft games.  It was a poorly planned move on their part to try and establish this kind of seclusive community, when people want what Steam already provides, which is more freedom and inter connectivity.  They had no room to grow outside of their own library.

content:
Posted: December 27, 2011
												Anno 2070 is a very good strategy game/economy simulator. You set up goods-chains, and use them to evolve your city (soon to be cities). For those of you who have played ANNO 1404, this game is very similar. It mainly takes away ground combat, and introduces undersea exploration/exploitation/combat, ecobalance, aircraft, electricity, and (if you got the DLC Deep Ocean) economic takeovers of Islands.You start the game by picking one of the two available races: Eco, or Tycoon. These symbolize the stereotypical environmentalists versus the Industrialists. Eco are more inefficient (they use up more space for their agriculture and industries, and have a harder time generating large amounts of power) but are more friendly on the environment (an actual mechanic in the game). Tycoon are very efficient, using up little space, but playing carelessly can damage the ecosystem of your island rapidly inviting disasters like acid rain. There is also a third faction, Tech, which you unlock after playing for a while (you can't start a game with them). These give you access to more advanced parts of the game, such as airplanes and the underwater part of the game.The game takes place on islands, and you initially start with a ship with just enough resources to found a settlement on one of them. Here you will (usually) start out growing your population, and to do so you must satisfy their rising amount of needs. To do so you have to set up production chains to deal with this. To start out, for example, you will have to satisfy their demand for food, and soon drink. Both factions needs access to fish, and it's the simplest goods in the game only requiring fisheries. Drink is the first production chain, and it requires putting down a farm to produce rice, and then using this rice to produce tea or liquor (depending on if Eco or Tycoon).The population is divided into different "tiers" that you will gain access to as you grow your population and satisfy their demands. You start out with simple workers, who when satisfied will advance to employees, and so on. Housing a certain amount of population belonging to a certain tier will give you access to new buildings, and that is how you progress in the game. As your islands start housing more advanced inhabitants, their needs will grow as well, forcing you to colonize additional islands for their natural resources. An employee, for example, usually require a good that requires resources not found on your main island. By colonizing another island you can get access to these resources, and set up internal trade routes that will automatically ship these goods around where they need to be. Setting up and protecting these routes is crucial to progress beyond the beginning of the game. The game also has conflict. When there are more players on the map (or AI-players that inhabit islands) this comes into play. If you want an island someone else is already on, you can just settle it at the same time (although this will probably♥♥♥♥♥♥them off), but usually you will want to kick whoever is on the island of it to have access to all the real estate on it. Without the DLC Deep Ocean (highly recommended) this is only doable through military means, and this is probably the weakest part of the game. Unlike Anno 1404 there is no land combat (besides using airplanes). Combat is mainly based around naval combat, and to remove someones presence from an island, you need to take out their warehouse (which serves as the islands main access point) and depots (buildings that distribute and gather resources). The main reason this part of the game isn't very strong is due to the lack of ground-based troops, and low ship-diversity in the beginning stages of the game. This means you have no actual way of permanently dealing with other islands in the early stages of the game, which can result in a frustrating experience for both the winner and the loser (since all you can do is cripple them to the point where it just becomes a waiting game until you lock airplanes). If a game progresses beyond the third tier of population without a clear winner, though, more units start opening up for a much more interesting gameplay.With the Deep Ocean DLC you can buy shares on an Island. If you control the majority of shares, you can spend a great deal of money to forcefully buy the Island from whoever owns it. This mechanic is called Hostile Takeover, and it makes it possible to play an aggressive game without using military might. However, you will still need a military presence to protect your trade routes from potential aggressors. Like mentioned earlier there is also an underwater part of the game. You can find underwater plateaus and settle them once you unlock the Tech population, which gives you access to submarines. Here you will find, and are able to cultivate, resources unique to the seabed. There are plenty other mechanics and gameplay elements as well, but this should give you a basic introduction to the game. Feel free to leave a comment if you have any questions!

content:
Posted: January 29, 2015
												Let me tell you a story.(Just go to the bottom for the review if reading is too hard)T'was the fourth Friday of the month and with money in my account I decided to do some game shopping. I myself use Steam as a medium for purchasing such items as I am not a lumpy faced reptilian cretin and after finding Anno 2070 I thought to myself "Wow this game looks like an experience I could spend some of my hours away from the tedium of everyday labouring to enjoy". But oh how wrong I was. After purchasing the game for what is, to me, the equivalent of 2 hours of mind numbing work I discovered that it required U-Play in order to launch. Slightly peeved, I decided to install the 3rd party software to get my money's worth.I soon came to the shocking realisation, however, that U-Play would not open when I commanded the game to launch. Irked to no end I decided that I was adept enough at the use of computers to attempt to combat the issue head on (by reinstalling U-Play and opening it before I tried launching the game). After doing so it seemed that I would finally get the chance to start reeling in those U-Play points (or whatever the ♥♥♥♥ U-Play are giving users to make them feel like they are using Steam instead of this piece of♥♥♥♥♥♥. But instead the problem had merely evolved - evolved into an issue which is not only beyond my own personal computing skills to fix, but apparently beyond the internet. So to conclude this tale of hardship and pain I leave you with this - heed my warning: if you buy this game (as good as it may actually be) you will be left with a literally unplayable game, £20 out of pocket and most detestable of all; a U-Play account.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 13, 2012
												This is possibly the best City building game there is. First off, the world pretty much went to the gutter, and it's your job to fix it (If you work for the Eden Initiative) or to adapt to it (If you work for Global Trust). On top of the usual challenges of building and supplying your settlements, there is Fire Risk, Crime and Health Problems to solve, you can end up going to war with the other leaders of your sector, and finally: the struggle with eco balance, which affects and is affected by your production of goods and exploitation of the planet; positive eco balance gives your farms high yields (and your population is generally happier), while negative eco balance lowers your agrarian yields and can even result in the elusive Tornado Disaster. It is entirelly up to you who to work for and how to build your settlements, when and how to go to war, and who to trade your resources with... Cherry on top? the multiplayer and the community are over the top. Every now and then a new "world event" starts, where everyone in the world pitch in their efforts for a common goal. You can play multiplayer as co-op (two or more players, playing the same faction) or as "rivals" (two or more players competeing for the best islands and resources, although not necesarily at war).All things sumarized, I highly recomend this game.

content:
Posted: December 28, 2013
												Pros: The game is absolutely beautiful. It will eat your time. If you're into the open world/economy/civilisation/ aspect of city building strategy, this is it. The military aspect can be better, but I view it as a plus really. Definitely not for people who like blowing things up. This was my first game from the Anno Series, and truth be told I've logged more hours than it says up there (IYKWIM ;)). I waited two years for a good sale before buying this game on steam, ultimately it was worth the wait. For me.Cons: One word. DRM. Ubisoft hates gamers. To launch this game, you will also need to install UPLay. Ubisoft's poor sad version of Steam. And to use the ark feature, you have to be online at all times. Its a joke really. And the 3 activation limit thing. You get three licenses so to speak, meaning you can't install it as many times as you normally would and could with other games. And that is just plain wrong. I suggest you read the forums and find out more about these cons before you buy the game. Its worth a look, if only to make a more informed purchase. To be honest, this isnt new with Ubisoft. They've been screwing with PC Gamers for years. This game however, is probably at the top of the DRM complaints for them.My recommendation: Only if youre a massive fan of the genre. There are less frustrating games out there, without all the hassles of dealing with Ubisoft. If it wasn't for steam and the fact that I love this genre to bits, Ubisoft would get nothing out of me.
