content:
Posted: July 13, 2013
												A solid sequel in the Anno series, unfortunately marred by Ubisoft's horrendous uPlay DRM and an obtrusive amount of cosmetic and functional DLC. Anno 2070, while set in a futuristic dystopia and populated by factions divided by their approach to techology and resource preservation, is functionally identical to its predecessors. This is a good thing, as those mechanics are both fun and unique in the strategy genre. In the Anno games you start out with a small settlement which you need to expand by building residences. As the population increases, they will begin to demand certain goods which you can provide by building production structures. It is these production structures which drive the Anno series. Resources are not just produced from a single entity. Instead resources will need to move through a supply chain until they finally produce a finished good at the last stage. As your population advances and new demands emerge, you'll find your supply chains stretched thin as demand pulls raw resources and processed resources along multiple paths.While a sandbox mode is available, In the campaign and several missions you'll face the additional challenge of enemy factions, requiring you to accomodate defensive and offensive production into your already complicated supply chains. If the idea of a futuristic dystopia marred by ecological disaster and populated by idelogically driven factions is appealing to you, and you can stomach Ubisoft's intrusive DRM layer, then you'll enjoy Anno 2070. If those hurdles are a bit too much, then I recommend playing Anno 1404 instead.

content:
Posted: November 7, 2014
												Wow, I was waiting for a game like this! It's always keeping me on my toes. Although it has a slight learning curve, once you get started you aren't turning back! Your number one priority is to keep your citizens happy. As you start with the bare bones houses, working your way up to the skyscrapers you're going to have to prepare. The starter houses only need a basic food item and drink item (it all depends on who you are). As you reach higher ranks, you have to have telecommunicators, different varieties of food, a news network, voting, and etc..  You'll have to seek out islands to get some of these items. Which brings in the other variable, factions. You will have to make friends, and to do this you will have to give them money,  and do quests for them so you won't get on their bad side. I have to micromanage and look at every one of my allies' arks (basically your main base) to see if they have any of the resources I require to grow my population! You also have the option of settling underwater, which is awesome! But if you do, one of the factions who settle under water will lose respect for you. So it's basically this: Should I go out, plunder the world, but get on everyone's bad side? Or should I be reasonable, stick to my island and make friends doing so? This is one of THE best games I've ever played, and I hope for more in the near future.Edit: I've noticed the review was split down the middle. If it was for your problems with Uplay, then my apologies. This game is well worth the pirate, but it just happened to work for me the first time.

content:
Posted: November 30, 2014
												Let's just get this out of the way first; UPlay is a pain in the♥♥♥♥♥ There's no getting around that. ANNO 2070 is worth putting up with it, though. There aren't many games quite like it; it's a cross between a standard RTS, SimCity, and The Settlers. It has elements of all of them, and it blends them very well. There are complicated logistics chains like SimCity and The Settlers, but there's also directly controllable units and combat like an RTS. Unlike an RTS, the pace is quite slow. Challenge in ANNO 2070 is more about setting up logistics chains in less than ideal scenarios. Combat is rare, and usually only involves a dozen units or less.This really is a game geared more towards thoughtful play and planning, there's not as much emphasis on multitasking or quick reactions; indeed it can be quite difficult to retool your logistics chain on the fly. If that sounds like your style of strategy game, then I think you'll quite like ANNO 2070.

content:
Posted: January 29, 2015
												Let me tell you a story.(Just go to the bottom for the review if reading is too hard)T'was the fourth Friday of the month and with money in my account I decided to do some game shopping. I myself use Steam as a medium for purchasing such items as I am not a lumpy faced reptilian cretin and after finding Anno 2070 I thought to myself "Wow this game looks like an experience I could spend some of my hours away from the tedium of everyday labouring to enjoy". But oh how wrong I was. After purchasing the game for what is, to me, the equivalent of 2 hours of mind numbing work I discovered that it required U-Play in order to launch. Slightly peeved, I decided to install the 3rd party software to get my money's worth.I soon came to the shocking realisation, however, that U-Play would not open when I commanded the game to launch. Irked to no end I decided that I was adept enough at the use of computers to attempt to combat the issue head on (by reinstalling U-Play and opening it before I tried launching the game). After doing so it seemed that I would finally get the chance to start reeling in those U-Play points (or whatever the ♥♥♥♥ U-Play are giving users to make them feel like they are using Steam instead of this piece of♥♥♥♥♥♥. But instead the problem had merely evolved - evolved into an issue which is not only beyond my own personal computing skills to fix, but apparently beyond the internet. So to conclude this tale of hardship and pain I leave you with this - heed my warning: if you buy this game (as good as it may actually be) you will be left with a literally unplayable game, £20 out of pocket and most detestable of all; a U-Play account.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 30, 2014
												Lots of reviews here talk about the Uplay DRM/platform thing. I've never had issues with it but I've heard plenty from those who have. If you can get this game on a sale or something, that's probably the best way. I can't give it an unqualified recommendation, mostly due to the Uplay issues that people complain about so much.That said, this game is a tremendous amount of fun. I'd never played an Anno game before so it had a rather steep learning curve for me. If you play through the campaign, it basically teaches you the mechanics of the game. This is good if you've never played an Anno game before. Once you get the hang of it, it's not so bad. Basically, this is a game of supply chains. Starting with natural resources, you harvest/mine, then make goods, then use some of those goods to make more goods, and so on. Where you have shortfalls or need to move things around, you build ships and transport routes. All the while, you need to keep your people happy or they'll start leaving. You also need to watch your income, as it's easy to get stuck in a downward spiral of diminishing income from which you can't escape.You can also build underwater, which works more or less like building on the surface, just with different graphics and resources.Overall, it's a lot of fun, and once you get a good supply chain going you can either sit back and relax, waiting for enough money to roll in to build whatever decorations and improvements you want, or continue ruthlessly expanding to extract ever more income from your citizens and strip the Earth of its precious resources.This game is a good introduction to the Anno series if you haven't played it before, as long as you're willing to put in a couple hours to really learn it.

content:
Posted: August 24, 2014
												It's a great game a lot of careful planning required on harder levels and rewards attention to detailPVP is basic, neither side can win until late game and then all it takes is one bomber with metamaterial (a tech that makes it invisible for 10 minutes) to make the enemy infastructure crumble by bombing their city centre.The expanding AI are more annoying than a threat, taking islands early on that you might want but don't have enough tools and such to expand there.Hector (a marauding pirate) and sokow (an oil tycoon) like to war each other if on the same map and hector will often sink the oil tankers sokow makes, which causes a black tide if your island is nearby.This is very annoying, it can easily cripple your economy if you aren't prepared so never have sokow and hector on the same map.But as war is optional, I still recommend the game

number of helpful: 3 of 6 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 30, 2014
												Let's just get this out of the way first; UPlay is a pain in the♥♥♥♥♥ There's no getting around that. ANNO 2070 is worth putting up with it, though. There aren't many games quite like it; it's a cross between a standard RTS, SimCity, and The Settlers. It has elements of all of them, and it blends them very well. There are complicated logistics chains like SimCity and The Settlers, but there's also directly controllable units and combat like an RTS. Unlike an RTS, the pace is quite slow. Challenge in ANNO 2070 is more about setting up logistics chains in less than ideal scenarios. Combat is rare, and usually only involves a dozen units or less.This really is a game geared more towards thoughtful play and planning, there's not as much emphasis on multitasking or quick reactions; indeed it can be quite difficult to retool your logistics chain on the fly. If that sounds like your style of strategy game, then I think you'll quite like ANNO 2070.

number of helpful: 4 of 8 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 13, 2014
												First and most important thing: This game requires Steam AND Uplay to run. Yes, you heard right, a DRM platform on top of another DRM platform. If that is not enough to stop you from buying it, there's more.Installation.Be prepared to waste another 30 minutes of your life uninstalling and reinstalling Anno2070 if Uplay for some reason stops recognizing your legit game.Online features.The game features several gimmick features (such as Ark upgrades that influence economy) that are online-only. The will greatly help you, but there is a caveat. What is it? Well, unlike Steam, Uplay is a buggy piece of crap and the servers are down quite often. Don't get me wrong - the game itself is great, but only when you can actually run it. So, when the server goes down and you are in your single-player game, suddenly your upgrades stop working and you find your economy in the toilet. It might be funny once or twice, but as it happens more often you will find yourself more frustrated with the game than having fun.Anno2070 itself is a great game with amazing visuals and smooth gameplay. It suffers from completely unnecessary online-only features that actually badly impact the experience of legitimate customers.Verdict: 5/10 FAIL

Posted: November 3, 2015
												The game art is abso0lutely amazing. It is what most drew me to this game. While the story seems fairly well developed, I didn't feel it was well suited for the style and overall game design very much. The strategy/city building elements felt prematurely mixed with RPG elements, and the UI boundaries between story items and resources in the inventory overlay was both awkward/confusing and a pretty major turnoff overall. I couldn't keep playing this for very long despite having such a big boner for the art style. Also didn't like having to install UPlay. Don't like having a game launcher launch another game launcher before it even launches the damn game.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 31, 2015
												The sci-fi ambience is a big part of Anno 2070's allure, and it goes a long way toward making the game feel fresh and surprising. Like being in a utopic Hollywood sci-fi film. An even bigger part of the allure is that Anno 2070 is what you make of it. If you want to chill out with some breezy city building without undue pressure, the easy difficulty setting is an inviting option. Once you get a number of ark upgrades, the hardest setting keeps your mental gears whirring and your clicking finger busy. No matter what your speed, Anno 2070 is addictive in the best way, by combining three brands of compelling design into one: intricate urban planning, time-sensitive questing, and persistent rewards for continued play. And that trifecta will keep you coming back for more.

content:
Posted: May 11, 2014
												An example of a game with potential gutted by inexplicably bad design choices. Some nifty ideas; voting community for stuff that affects everyone, etc. Only, you only get 1 profile. No 'starting over'. No playing through with a different concept. You get 3 installations. Significant hardware changes, reinstallations, that sort of stuff? 3 times, then you have to buy a new copy of the game. My wife played it for 4 hours. We both enjoyed 1404, thought we'd like 2070. However, I can't have my own game, my own playthrough. Ever. Not without buying a second copy of the game and creating a completely different UPLAY account. I'm totally serious, it's that absurd. Gameplay isn't bad but not a significant improvement from 1404. Graphics are pretty but minimal city build customization, or any customization at all. It's pretty rote, pretty repetitive. Most of the RTS sort of content feels like an afterthought. I wish I had positive things to say but just trying to get it installed and into a scenario involves the equivelent of the developer sticking a raised middle finger in your face and shouting "LOL! THANKS FOR THE MONEY SUCKER! LOL!' 20 or 30 times. Having spend several hundred on ubisoft games over the years, this left such a sour taste I uninstalled it, as well as the ACIV I had and prevented me from buying any DLC for this or Black Flag. Decided to look at other game developers who are less utterly contemptuous of people who want to give them money.

content:
Posted: August 24, 2014
												It's a great game a lot of careful planning required on harder levels and rewards attention to detailPVP is basic, neither side can win until late game and then all it takes is one bomber with metamaterial (a tech that makes it invisible for 10 minutes) to make the enemy infastructure crumble by bombing their city centre.The expanding AI are more annoying than a threat, taking islands early on that you might want but don't have enough tools and such to expand there.Hector (a marauding pirate) and sokow (an oil tycoon) like to war each other if on the same map and hector will often sink the oil tankers sokow makes, which causes a black tide if your island is nearby.This is very annoying, it can easily cripple your economy if you aren't prepared so never have sokow and hector on the same map.But as war is optional, I still recommend the game

number of helpful: 3 of 6 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 30, 2014
												Let's just get this out of the way first; UPlay is a pain in the♥♥♥♥♥ There's no getting around that. ANNO 2070 is worth putting up with it, though. There aren't many games quite like it; it's a cross between a standard RTS, SimCity, and The Settlers. It has elements of all of them, and it blends them very well. There are complicated logistics chains like SimCity and The Settlers, but there's also directly controllable units and combat like an RTS. Unlike an RTS, the pace is quite slow. Challenge in ANNO 2070 is more about setting up logistics chains in less than ideal scenarios. Combat is rare, and usually only involves a dozen units or less.This really is a game geared more towards thoughtful play and planning, there's not as much emphasis on multitasking or quick reactions; indeed it can be quite difficult to retool your logistics chain on the fly. If that sounds like your style of strategy game, then I think you'll quite like ANNO 2070.

number of helpful: 7 of 14 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 7, 2014
												Wow, I was waiting for a game like this! It's always keeping me on my toes. Although it has a slight learning curve, once you get started you aren't turning back! Your number one priority is to keep your citizens happy. As you start with the bare bones houses, working your way up to the skyscrapers you're going to have to prepare. The starter houses only need a basic food item and drink item (it all depends on who you are). As you reach higher ranks, you have to have telecommunicators, different varieties of food, a news network, voting, and etc..  You'll have to seek out islands to get some of these items. Which brings in the other variable, factions. You will have to make friends, and to do this you will have to give them money,  and do quests for them so you won't get on their bad side. I have to micromanage and look at every one of my allies' arks (basically your main base) to see if they have any of the resources I require to grow my population! You also have the option of settling underwater, which is awesome! But if you do, one of the factions who settle under water will lose respect for you. So it's basically this: Should I go out, plunder the world, but get on everyone's bad side? Or should I be reasonable, stick to my island and make friends doing so? This is one of THE best games I've ever played, and I hope for more in the near future.Edit: I've noticed the review was split down the middle. If it was for your problems with Uplay, then my apologies. This game is well worth the pirate, but it just happened to work for me the first time.

Additionally I had to both download an old version of the updater from mediafire, and poke around until I found a valid Ubisoft IP for running the launcher's proxy through (strike three.)And then it still only downloaded some of the DLC, and I once again just get to stare at a "you're missing some crap, restart and patch me, bro" screen (strike four).So in summary, I had to install malware onto my computer, utilize third party hosted files, and dig through Ubisoft's forums for four hours only to still not be able to play a game I own and the best tech support advice I was given was "reinstall windows."Absolute and utter garbage.  I only haven't sought a refund because I'm confident if I ever feel the urge to I could probably find a DRM crack for it and actually be able to play.

												My opinion may be a tad biased as I am absolutely in love with City Building Sandbox games, always have been. Anno:2047 is wonderful. It has far more in depth trading than its predecessors and it looks wonderful while doing so. The story is Fair to say the least, however the challengs are entertaining. I've spent a great deal of time in this game, mastering building placements, maximizing yield vs consumption. Like any RTS city builder, it has a slow pace, this can be offset by adding combative rivals that, when set on a higher difficulty, offer little mercy at the expense of perfection. It will change the pace trying to please the A.I. and expand into new territory.There is a plethora of other features that I have left out of this review, but I assure you that any fan of this game's genre will not be disappointed.

content:
Posted: August 17, 2014
												Anno 2070 is a brain racking, Real-Time Strategy. The player has a lot of options of playing the game with different population types which can change up the type of resources and tools needed to build civilizations. It's heavy on thinking and has the need to take action on events in the world and make choices wisely, or else your economy may tumble. This game isn't military or war oriented, but the player has the choice to initiate or declare wars. Anno 2070 is very slow but enjoyable, laid back game. To those that are new to the RTS genre, I think this is a good start.

												Buy it, download it, run  it, which in turn will run Anno launcher, there you shall copy the serial key, which will update, which in turn will run UPlay install, which will then update, there you shall register, then add a game and serial key, this will run the game, there you create a profile and add the serial key in again, that will unlock the DLC, close the game and run the launcher which will then download the DLC and open UPlay which will run the game... And then... Then you may play. It doesn not take hours as some suggest, but you'll have very annoying dozen(s) minutes and will have to install UPlay.Apart from that, the game is very likely one of the very best of all time in the genre. *shrug* Too good to not recommend it to anyone who likes the genre even a little bit, despite one of the worst consumer-killing DRM I remember ever seeing.

content:
Posted: November 30, 2014
												I can't say enough about this game. Was a nice step up from Dawn of Discovery, with much improved UI and combat mechanics. Game is addicting for perfectionists who like to perfectly optimize city spaces. Faction balance is good.Ecos generate far less money and their units are weaker than Tycoons, but enjoy farming taking up far less space because of positive eco balance, and units are FAST. Both sides should expand into Tech ASAP though.ARK upgrades carry over, my advice is to get a farm map going, fill your map with supplies, THEN go play with friends. Enjoy the extra 500 tools you brought. ;)Uses uPlay though which is god awful and glitchy (on top of Steam as digital DRM though, why ubi, why).Get this game, enjoy♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥away entire weekends with friends.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 20, 2011
												Anno 2070 adds a whole new depth to a great franchise. And "depth" can be taken quite literal considering the premise of the game: sea levels have risen and civilization as we know it has sunken beneath the waves. Different factions allow for quite different approaches to the game and to the way you structure your colonies. (The Ecos who try to minimize ecological impact of their actions, use sustainable energy but require a lot of space, the Tycoons who couldn't care less about impact when there is profit to be made and the Techs...)Trade, diplomacy and quest allow you to interact with the npc  factions but to add to that, all players get to globaly vote on policies proposed by the factions and on which faction will get the council presidency. The result of these votes will grand some small, in-game bonuses.And then there are the little daily missions, which allow you to gain reputation with the faction you choose to favor during the mission

content:
Posted: June 2, 2012
												My people don't always tell me to demolish my nuclear powerplant, but when they do, I can't find a ♥♥♥♥ to give.More detailed review:Graphics: 10/10 in my opinion. Not much to say, other than that pretty much everything looks beautiful.Music & sound: The music and sounds are pretty good and fitting but not the best I've heard imo 8/10.Ressource management and economy system: Tedious in the long run. You have to build ships to transport ressources from island to island e.g. island 2 needs Uranium for nuclear energy but uranium is only available on island 1. Unless you import them, but that is quite expensive. The devs did however add a feature that allows your ships to load / unload themselves at your docks, which really helps a lot and makes transport of ressources more or less autonomous. Still, when you start to have 20+ transport ships, it feels kind of like you have a major weakness should you go into battle with the other players. Like should one of them get destroyed whether by a tornado or an enemy, your entire economy on one island might collapse. I suppose it could be lessened by making every ship carry one ressource each rather than several, but that can become expensive to maintain money-wise.I don't give it less than 7/10 due to the fact you can make your trade autonomous (almost 100%) and renew your ressources (I'm honestly not sure if it's a good or bad things you can renew otherwise non-renewable ressources in rl such as coal...) but I also don't give it a higher score because...Well like I kind of said, the system gets kind of complex and annoying in the long run. Anyway, 7/10.Trade: Pretty much the same as above, you just make your ships autonomously load and unload their cargo at other players / AI's docks. Decent trading system, but I feel it could be better somehow. 7/10.Warfare: Simple and♥♥♥♥♥♥imho. What can I say, it's a sim game, not a war game. You do have planes, ships, submarines and some other things I can't remember, but it's not quite a good wargame. 4/10.Climate / weather events: As you can pretty much guess from the description of the game on its store page, your actions affect the environment around you. If you choose to pollute your islands, it could have dramatic effects on your economy, your islands and the other players islands. Oh and it can also happen at sea, so your ships might get destroyed by a tornado all of a sudden. I can imagine that climate system can lead to war in some multiplayer matches. Your people can also oppose some of your actions such as running a nuclear powerplant, fearing a meltdown. You can with techs reduce it to 0%, but the people doesn't seem to care :S Environmentally wise in this game...Let's just say you don't want to run a "Business as usual." policy for long. 9/10.Research and production: Research is insanely and annoyingly slow. You can speed it up and maybe I'm just doing it wrong, but researching new techs as well as producing things in your lab takes HOURS. Literally. Production of ships and other units is decent. It's great once you finish researching though, techs / items you can use to e.g. reduce pollution generated by your coal powerplants or techs that increase your production is great. You can also create...Items? That makes you able to dig up otherwise exhausted ressources. Awesome but also odd given how coal is non-renewable (in human eyes) in the rl. 5/10 due to the insanely slow research.Multiplayer: I haven't played it that much, but it's one of the few strategy games where I actually like multiplayer and don't prefer single player a lot more than multiplayer. I especially like how there are events and campaigns where players have to work together to complete them, followed by rewards if they succeed (they usually do) for example: "Defeat this terrorist by destroying his bases in these 3 maps." then players help do that and succeed if they complete the maps enough times (not repetitive though). One more thing I especially like that involve other players is...The voting. In the game you can vote for things which will affect your gameplay. It's been a while since I played the game so I don't remember the names and all, but you get to vote e.g. for a representative for the tycoons, which then will increase your production of certain buildings should they win the elections. Anyway, the multiplayer is pretty much similar to singleplayer, meaning it's not laggy or anything. I love CIV V but I hate the thing about having to wait for your turn more than in singleplayer. Anno 2070 doesn't have a similar problem to that, which is great. 10/10.Conclusion: I give this game 8/10. I dislike the way to wage war in this game as well as all the cargo ships you end up building in order to transport ressources around. Oh and the slow research. Buy this game if you like sim and strategy games, but don't buy it for the combat system as you WILL be disappointed. I was at least.

content:
Posted: November 20, 2011
												Anno 2070 adds a whole new depth to a great franchise. And "depth" can be taken quite literal considering the premise of the game: sea levels have risen and civilization as we know it has sunken beneath the waves. Different factions allow for quite different approaches to the game and to the way you structure your colonies. (The Ecos who try to minimize ecological impact of their actions, use sustainable energy but require a lot of space, the Tycoons who couldn't care less about impact when there is profit to be made and the Techs...)Trade, diplomacy and quest allow you to interact with the npc  factions but to add to that, all players get to globaly vote on policies proposed by the factions and on which faction will get the council presidency. The result of these votes will grand some small, in-game bonuses.And then there are the little daily missions, which allow you to gain reputation with the faction you choose to favor during the mission

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 5
												Right so first off. Everyone here is complaining about how ubisofts little program is♥♥♥♥♥♥and doesn't work or that it = jumping through hurdles to play a game....I went through the process and what I got to say is...You people are bat♥♥♥♥♥♥crazy.If you have an Ubisoft account and you set it up with Uplay, and then link that account with Steam, you are good to go. It is very easy, and I never had any issues with it. Please don't♥♥♥♥♥♥on Ubisofts game because YOU are unwilling to go through the process of creating an account to play a game. The game doesn't deserve it, and I will get to that.Then you install the game with both accounts open and ready (Steam and Uplay, linked, if you are paying attention.) There will be a few different things like updates, steam setup thingy, I think there was an Agreement(Click 'agree' dumbasses)During this process you will get a game code that you can "copy to clipboard", please do so.They will make you put that code in multile times if I recall correctly. This is because they have toset that code up with multiple accounts. Yes it is a silly system to have, but it is a game, and it is fun, and if you can't put a silly little number/letter code copied/pasted into a box a few times GOD KILL ME NOW.At the end of the process you will be told to choose an ingame name, have fun with that, be creativeAccount made, you win, you got a great game.  IT IS AN EASY PROCESS IF YOU HAVE HALF A BRAIN!!!Quit ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ on ubisoft, quit ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ on Uplay. They are fine, you are not.RIGHT, so now for the ~ACTUAL REVIEW~ of the game. ~There are several game modes, of sorts, like you can play multiplayer, you can play continuous games, you can play campaigns. That is great. Lots to do. There is an actual story mode to this.~There are senate votes and world event and some sort of leader vote thingy, which all give lil bonuses if they win the vote. The players vote for these(on those secondary accounts no less. :P ). It is unique AF for this to be in a game.I love it.~The game is like....deep. You will go through it trying to build the ultimate place to live out of 3 different factions.(Did I say there was a 3rd? :o Ohhhh mysterious.) The ultimate place to live is a huge debate among the various factions. Should we be self reliant upon ourselves, trade, should we exploit our resources and have scientific breakthroughs to solve our growing troubles, what should we do? That is why they have entrusted you with their money, so that you YOU can figure it out. There is alot to do, and you will find yourself multitasking. (Dare I say someone posted a thread on the internet saying that they hated this game because they didnt feel like they were multitasking...♥♥♥♥♥♥♥T.)~ There are consequences for everything you do, and benefits too. I won't spoil it for you. But I sat in my seat laughing for 10 minutes straight at one of them, whilst also dreading at it slightly. There are things that can happen to your environment. Be careful.~Democracy~War~Socio-economic Classes~Green, and Grey.~and probably a bit more.So honestly, as far as I can see, this game is Unique as ♥♥♥♥. and I am enjoying it immensly 23 hours through.I went into debt and lost my first continuous game, and I fought for hours and hours trying to make my society great and lively. I feel like I have built a great home for my people, minus *minour~ish not really* incidents.If you had to compare Tropico 3 or 4 with Anno 2070 (I haven't played Tropico 5 mind you)Anno 2070 wins by a LONGSHOTTL;DRPlease read the full thing. These words are more meaningful than the crap other people are putting down in their reviews.Anno vs Tropico, Anno wins10/10 I am impressed. Would lead my people to ~Minour sorta not really~ incidents all over again.

number of helpful: 11 of 22 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 23, 2014
												Great game, relaxing and rewarding to watch your city grow. Many new game mechanics never done before in other games of this type, some diplomacy options and multiple ways to resove conflict, for example: economical domination, war or stealing all land for yourself forcing the opponents to confront you in one way or another.   Pros: - great gameplay mechanics - good graphics, animations (all buildings are animated).  - great amount of game customisation  (u can choose winning conditions, island size etc)- good balance between factions- tons of replayability- game never gets boring, there is always something to do and take care of. Cons:- AI is cheating - Unlimited resources, building patterns etc.. | its best to play the game on multiplayer mode - Uplay might cause trouble, you must connect through it to play the game. -♥♥♥♥♥♥Multiplayer servers, many connection issues when joining lobby (once the game starts its all fine) The game itself is pure gold in the genre, its the♥♥♥♥♥♥drm and issues stopping the player from getting in to the game that drags this game down. I will recommend this game but be prepared to deal with all sorts of random issues at your first install, or not if you are lucky.

content:
Posted: March 15, 2015
												First and foremost, yes I know no one likes uplay, and I know it causes a lot of problems for a lot of people. With that in mind there does come a time when as a gamer one must ask themselves "Am I going to let this annoyance keep me from something im really going to enjoy?" I found myself faced with this very question in regards to Anno 2070, and when it came down to it I chose to look past uplay and see what this game had to offer, and I am glad I did. What we have here is an excellently made city builder game, with just the right amount of complexity and difficulty to provide a satisfying experience. Now it isnt the most intuitive thing so you will want to play the campaign to get a feel for how everything works before diving right into sandbox mode. So if you are into the city builder genre , be willing to at least consider looking past uplay and you will be in for something good.

content:
Posted: March 14, 2015
												Regarding the crashing issue. I just followed the steps outlined by 704BOSS in the review section and had no issue launching. I've copied his comments again. Review by 704BOSS :'THE GAME WORKS. Stop with the negative reviews because you don't like the installation method. It says on the game page that you will have to access it through third party software. If you don't want to don't buy it and move on. Just want to say the game works fine for me and it is a steal for the price. This installation does require patience as you essentially do have to install up to four multiple items. I already had UPLAY which I have never had issues with so that is the first step. Install UPLAY. Second step you have to install the game to your steam library. Copy the activation code. I already had UPLAY open and the game showed right up. Now it gets crazy. Select "play" in UPLAY. Another steam activation box will pop up and you will think "I just did this!". Do it again. This shockingly opens the game in UPLAY & Steam in unison. The little Steam box will be in the lower right corner. Now guess what? Enter the activation code. You can't past it so you will have to retype it accurately. We are halfway there! The game will now download something I think it called an "adapter". It looks like the game is installing again. Whatever it is it takes 2 or 3 minutes as opposed to the original install which took 30 minutes for me. Is it malware? I don't think so as I run scans for malware daily and have had UPLAY forever and none has shown up nor am I having performance issues. After the adapter is done installing you will think the game is going to start. It isn't if you got the complete edition. You now have to install the addons which are the DLCs. It takes about 10 minutes. Relax, breathe and follow instructions. It is a hassle but the game is definitely playable. Now do I have any idea how to play it? Not at all, but it looks really cool and I'm sure I'll have fun figuring it out as I love Civilization and this looks like a futuristic version of it. Time to read the manual!'

content:
Posted: February 15, 2015
												Anno is a real live strategy game that located in a mostly water planet in which the player needs to build up his economy to defend, attack or build structures to finish a level.Even though the game is 4 years old it's graphics still manage to keep itself up front with the new real time strategy games with amazing water physics and good looking buildings.The gameplay is pretty straight forward with objectives showing on the left and the map signaling the place of the next event, the game will try and keep you on you're toes in hard missions and new enemy strategy every level.The only downside of the game is the music, it just never matches the gameplay, the audio of the game feels random from a soundtrack and rarely fit the situation you are at. All in all the game manages to keep you interested until the end with an OK storyline diverse missions  and new tech from now and then I'll give it an 8/10Pros:- diverse gameplay- the only water real time strategy game- upgradeable units- long gameplay time- challenging enemies- good graphicsCons:- a bit hard to learn- the map is too zoomed in- random music

content:
Posted: April 27, 2015
												I gave this a recommend, but only barely. As an rts this would have been epic 10 years ago, but as it is, its mediocre. The tutorial is non-existant, but there is epic loads of half useful text entries. The single player campaign does a fairly terrible job of introducing game mechanics to you, and never tells you certain things like hotkeys or how to actually accomplish some objectives. Other times it tells you in tediously small detail how to accomplish the simplest tasks. The game itself has some fun elements but they're burdened with objectives and game mechanics that seem to go out of their way to be cumbersome and unwieldy. Visually the game looks fantastic, but that is also the best thing you can say about the game. Voice acting is flat as hell, and the script is as well. There is 0 combat in the single player game for quite some time, and very little of it as it gets introduced. There are also very few unit types and some are exclusive to a specific faction. The lack of combat was a nice, refreshing, change in a way for an RTS to go in some ways. Unfortunately in implementation, it just means you're playing SimCity in an RTS engine for much of the early game. *I haven't gotten into the game very far, so if it improves I don't know yet. There are some interesting ideas here as well, that focus on the online component such as global voting and multiplayer maps. Now for the really annoying parts... you HAVE to install and load ubisoft's uplay before the game will even load, and of course this requires you to have a uplay account. Further, even tho you just loaded and logged onto uplay, the game will then demand you login from there! Once logged in you are confronted with a confused jumble of a screen and no guidance to it. The game will THEN recognize any dlc you bought and want your key(s), which will close the game and let uplay download and install it/them.. Now you can finally load the game and, login, then play..... WTF.

content:
Posted: December 20, 2013
												SimCity ain't got nuthin on this game. This is a new genre of simulation structures unlike the humble giants upon whose shoulders it stands, and I'm excited to see what direction it ends up going in the future. I would not reccommend this game for casual players, an average session lasts me a minimum of six hours. A longer one can run upwards of a week, all day every day. The tech tree and research system are megalithic and some.... several of the individual points towards a single given technological improvement can take upwards of ten hours to accomplish, which is mitigated somewhat by the ability to rush time itself with the fast-forward button, but that in turn is often thwarted by the extremely complex economic dependencies of your various population centers. "Sustainable development" in this game runs right along the razor's edge of perfect harmonization amongst a variety of disparate populations with, often, high demand for extremely limited resources.One of the more interesting things to note is that all of your 'sessions' behave as if they are simultaneous, so it is possible to have a dozen saved games all working on a single technological development project and shuffle the intermediary components back and forth through your ark. This level of "meta" can result in long term developments over a course of several revisited save-games but... the niche market for that is so rare, I again reiterate, this game is not very rewarding for casual players.If you're not going to spend the next several months playing one game, and only one game... or if you're not the kind of person who can sit around playing one session of the game for weeks and weeks... then this game's full functionality isn't something you'll ever discover. However, it does have a robust PvP/Co-op/FFA structure that can let you refine your "early game" down to a science of aggressive militaristic tactics and strategies if you're into competetive resource management games like Command & Conquer, or Star Craft 2, or Age of (Wonder, Mythology, Empires, Etc...).I could also see some serious potential in an organized 'clan' working together to develop the high end technologies while simultaneously working on their military strategies for PvP matches with other 'clans.' That would be pretty cool... I don't think there's another resource management game with this breadth of focus and variety of potentially successful avenues.In all, I love the game, but it certainly isn't for everyone.

number of helpful: 4 of 9 people (44%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 10, 2015
												This game is great.  It's a very well thought out resource gathering and city building game where you have to balance everything.  Basic resources are combined to make better resources, which in turn need other resources to make even more advanced resources.  Resources are then used to create buildings and products to keep your people happy.  You'll also need to setup trade routes, use diplomacy, fight pirates, and more. If you like city building and strategy games you'll  really like this.  The only complaint I've ever seen is the Ubisoft Uplay game manager/launcher.  And lets face it, a lot of games have these 3rd party DRM launchers.  EA has their Origin system, Blizzard has theirs, Kalypso too, etc, etc.  Writing off games because of it is a bit much IMO.  The big complaint is that the launcher won't allow you to play the game.  I can understand that.  When you buy a game you just want it to work.  Well my Uplay launcher updated and it stopped working.  When I clicked play it would crash to desktop before launching a game.  A quick google search lead me to change a single windows permission and it worked perfectly.  After that it operated just like every other DRM launcher, just press play.  Get past this problem and you'll enjoy this game very much.

content:
Posted: March 15, 2015
												This game is like a watermelon. It has a tough outside, which can make it a bit unappealing to use, but if you choose to cut through that rough skin then you are rewarded with a wonderful, juicy experience. What I mean by this is that when you get the game you are faced with Ubisoft's terrible game service, Uplay. Nobody likes Uplay. But if you can get past that part, and find a way to get the game to work, then what is inside will be a very enjoyable experience.This game has a fair learning curve, in my opinion. When you start, you have no idea what you are doing. After about an hour of play, you get an idea of how the game works. After two, you become fluent. After three, you know pretty much exactly what you are going to do and when.As for various other aspects of the game, the graphics are absolutely amazing. It has really futuristic looking buildings, and all the terrain fits it will. The art style fits the game really well, and everything is consistent.The UI is okay, all things considered. It's nothing too intuitive, but it works well enough.The gameplay is quite good, although sometimes you have to micromanage things, which is not ideal from a city builder.The story is quite a cool concept. 60 years in the future, global warming has melted the polar ice caps, causing the world to flood. Civilization now stands on what used to be highly elevated areas, and survives on islands. The main method of transportation is boats, and they play a major part in all areas of the game.Overall, I give this game an 8/10.

number of helpful: 4 of 9 people (44%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 18, 2015
												In response to seeing all of the reviews of this game complaining about Uplay and such I've decided to write a review about this game. Here's the basic summary:Pros:-Pretty good graphics. -Gameplay is VERY fun if you enjoy micromanaging and macromanaging (empire building)-Two, technically three, VERY different factions. -Really interesting environmental effects-Interesting animations-Voice acting is quality-Animated 3D character portraits-Hours of gameplay-Fairly large maps-Fun multiplayer-Different ways to win-Fun campaign-A very unique and innovative take on a political system run by players-This is all I can really think of right now..Cons:-Always online bull****- Somewhat pointless DLC-AI is a bit idiotic at times-Civilians in your proverbial empire are VERY picky-Can be a bit glitchy with your resourcesOverall, it's a very fun game. I'd recommend purchasing it on a sale however. If one ever comes again. As for the "it never works", "always crashes" etc reviews, try downloading the Uplay launcher from their website. Hell, if you're that worried, download THIS game from THEIR website. Don't let anyone discourage you, the game is amazing. In my opinion at least. Personally I've never had any problems with the Uplay launcher or anything related to Ubisoft. Quite frankly, I find their reward system interesting and kind of fun. I'm honestly not sure what anyone is talking about when they say the Uplay launcher isn't working. Mine is. And has been. Not once has it buggered up.Anyways, good game. Give it a try, or watch some reviews.

												When writing a review about this game you have to separate between the actual game and everything around it. The game itself is great. I like it a lot. number of helpful: 4 of 9 people (44%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 21, 2015
												Interested in city building and population control, with the added extra of resource production and collection? Look no further, Anno 2070 is probably one of the best, if not hardest simulation games I have played in a long time. A huge fan of C&C and Age Of Empires, trying something new is always a risky business, however I took the plunge with Anno 2070 and well, my statistics speak for themselves: 19 hours played in 2 weeks....so far! Albeit a bit confusing to start with, Anno 2070 does a really good job of immersing players into a new world, with focus on resource production and collection. Get it right, and the demand will increase, and meeting the demand will grant players with new buildings and more money. However get it wrong, population will decrease leaving players to deal with an ultimate decline in money. I would reccomend new players to give the campaign a go, learn the basics then switch over to Continuous or Single Player missions. These arent time constraint and you can play at your leisure, learning the basics and working out new ways to focus on resource production. A brilliant all round game, once youve gotten the hang of it, but hey, everyone loves a challenge!

content:
Posted: July 5, 2015
												This game is amazing. I will not tell you in detail about the features of this game, as other reviews already do, and you can watch gameplay videos to see for yourself. The chances are that, if you are reading this, you are doing so because you are already interested in the game, but the U-play rubbish is holding you back. So, this shall be about the U-play and DRM problems.Yes, U-play is a problem. Yes, U-play does crash and will not allow you to play until you fix it. However, this is a simple process, and this video shows you how to fix U-play crashing. 


YouTube™ Video: How to fix Ubisoft Uplay Launcher crash 

			Views: 174,624		

			Please leave a thumbs up if you enjoyed :D It helps me a lot! Be my buddy on Facebook! http://www.facebook.com/freestyleomg.doot Join my Fan Page!		

Other than the crashing, U-play does not hinder your gameplay, and this video fixes that. If that does not work, you can always get a refund, anyway, so buy it, especially if it is on sale (as it is at the time of this review). The U-play annoyance is worth going through for this amazing game. As for the 3 machine activation limit, you can just request more activations if you send an email to ubisoft support with your steam CD key. I have not had to do this, yet, myself, but others have stated that they respond quickly. Edit: I have now also found out that you generate an extra machine activation key every 30 days. Unless you are going to activate this game on 4 machines in 1 month, (your first installation does not take up one of these keys) this will not affect you.

												There is a lot of initial problems with the game: But for me, I've not had a single one. No external, no internal. Nothing weird, everything is pretty smooth. There are some questionable software practices, but I believe, when doing a significant amount of research, you might just notice that the version uploaded to steam, is still pretty old, minus the dlc, which is of it's own interest.The internal patcher of the game, however seems to do a lot more work, even replacing the game's TASGES DRM, with SolidShield (Which is still TAGES, but under a different name supposedly.) But make note, that the store page is not synched up with the new name. It mentions "TAGES". Does that mean the DRM it's self has changed, or been removed? I think it may have been changed, and definitely comes in waves, and stages.Having the complete edition my mileage may vary- or be different for it all. The game is fun, it's great. So putting aside all of it's negatives, which are debunked when you do enough research- uplay is silly, but at the same time, the license limit/install is a non-issue,  as it seems to have been resolved, as long as the product is activated/launched, or ran through uplay (As well as Steam, if you so desire)Games fun, very slow, the gameplay is magnificent, its a resource management game, but it is definitely a beauty.  I can't really go into detail of reviewing the game so I'll break it down.It has borderless window modeIt looks pretty, it has underwater stuff (In the DLC)It runs spectacularly. Everything is nice.There is a huge learning curve, but the game is rewarding in that way.I'm planning to dump a lot more time, into the game. At 5.7 hours as of writing, the game has taken quite a bit singleplayer, this does not include an amount that it should- or would multiplayer. :) But it is a great game. For what was paid for. It really is a shame that it's reputation for having uplay, or DRM drives sales away.Even if the DRM situation is still a present issue, unaware to myself. it still is a fantastic experience to enjoy.

												Ok, now I'm not gonna say only good things about this game even though I'm recommending it, because, I'm an Anno player and this isn't the first Anno I've played.So what's the main bad point? The main bad point for me is simple, this game is worse than the previous one. I had and still have much more fun on Anno 1404 than on this one. Not because it's not futuristic but because the gameplay was better. There was more thing to do, the venician addon was just awesome, and in general, the gameplay was more consequent. One of the main issue I had with 2070 was the military part. It has always been a great problem for me that this part of the game is left over by all anno game, but still, anno 1404 had a good military part. Anno 2070 has like, well nothing good. I mean, it take hell of a time to have a bit of real armed fleet, and there absolutly NO WAY to invade the land with man. You must use aircraft through the tech tree and this take even more time. Plus, and this is awful to me, the eco has like no military stuff at all... Well, just hated that from the game. Then there's the expectation that weren't there such as greater island, better diplomacy gameplay, more interaction with AI and so on. There's so much thing to do.Now, I still recommand this game for a simple reason. This IS a good game. Even though it was some kind of a disappointment to me, I've had great time playing it. The underwater ain't as fun as it could have been but is still intersting. The multiplayer part has never been use so well and that was realy interesting and new. And the elements such as energy and eco balance were quiet a nice idea.So I recommand this game!

content:
Posted: June 20, 2015
												First of all: I rate the game, not the external software around it.For the game:Anno 2070 is just the best looking resource managing game right now. Your goal is to manage resources between islands with trade road and exchange and it's really well made.It's beautiful, it allows co-op or war, has a really big political management (you can vote for president and law etc...).There's missions and updates every month: it's still in developement. (maybe not when the new Anno will come)The context is respected: we're in the future but not too far and you can still recognize some of the buidlings we have now.The map can be big or small, with a lot if islands or not: it's up to your choice.Badly, if you buy it on steam, you will have to open uplay to play it. It makes 2 DRM launching. Plus, uplay uses their own DRM: Solidshield which can disable your game if you change your hardware. In general, Uplay hates PCs.Conclusion: The game is really good and don't deserve a mixed reviews but the software sh*t around it maybe....

number of helpful: 3 of 7 people (43%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 18, 2015
												Anyone having connection issue when starting the game, this is what worked for me.I originally downloaded the game from steam and installed it, as you would any other game. It would keep crashing out and not launch. I then downloaded uplay logged into my account, re-launched the game and it worked (well sort of).Then when trying to play the game I kept getting an error 'connection to server lost'. This prompted me to go online for a solution, as up until this point everything I tried failed. I found a lot of information on this error, but nothing worked.As a last resort I un-installed the game and re-downloaded & installed it. This seemed to fix the issue, and the game launched with no errors.The only thing I can surmise from this is, not having uplay installed first caused errors in the game.So anyone buying this game or those having issues similar to mine, make sure you have uplay installed before you download and install this game.

												Yeah so, the actuall activation proccess isn't that hard.Maybe Uplay just decided to grace the gaming community with a shred of benevolence since this game came out but the installation and activation of a Uplay account has gotten pretty easy and fast.The fact that you have to activate the game with Uplay is still a ♥♥♥♥♥, but its no different than being 'burned' with the activation of SimCity 5 when that came out. Yeah you had to download another party to activate that game but it honestly didn't take anymore than a few minutes last time and if wont take more than a few minutes now.NOTE: If you do head most of these reviews and buy the game, keep in mind that you have to go to the Uplay website and download the launcher there rather than use the launcher the game gives you. number of helpful: 3 of 7 people (43%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 21, 2015
												If you enjoyed games like Banished, Age of empires or Empire Earth, I would recommend trying Anno 2070 out (assuming you have enough self-control to not go on a killing spree while trying to download the game through Uplay).I’m sure by now you have already read 600 reviews on how uplay is the worst thing ever (it definitely is, but I’ll get into that at the end). Once you get the game going it is fairly fun and I had no problems with crashing that other players have reported. The lack of a proper tutorial is kind of lame. But if you play the campaign and try out controls you would have used in Age of Empires or similar games, it is fairly easy to work out.The game looks pretty good and the soundtrack is nice to have going for around 10 hours. It is definitely worth while reading what E.V.E says, although she doesn’t always give enough information so be prepared to look some stuff up. The game as a whole is pretty good. Not amazing, but still enjoyable.The main downside for this game was the installation, which took a good three hours. First the game installed, then made me download Uplay, then Uplay kept crashing when I tried to get it to launch. I fixed this by just focusing on Uplay and not the game, starting the program in offline mode, logging in (it will stop you and say you have to be online), then logging in with it online. Uplay will do some stupid update thing, and then it worked fairly well from there on. However, installation was over! I launched the game, it installed some stuff, then asked to restart the game to do some more downloading. So I had to go back out and wait for it to basically download again.

content:
Posted: July 5, 2016
Game 10 - Steam and Ubisoft 0I bought the complete edition during the summer sale. Eager to play I installed the game. Contrary to forum posts stating Tages SolidShield DRM is removed I had to download a .ske file to satisfy said Tages DRM. After that launching the game via Steam client worked for around three hours. Since then every attempted launch ends with a Windows failure message. I verfied the game cache and deleted and reinstalled the game in Steam to no avail.Next I unlinked my Steam account from my Ubisoft account and downloaded the game via Uplay client. This was successful and the game launches in the Uplay client in offline mode with Steam overlay active. Although all DLC is indicated as installed by Uplay Steam would let me happily buy all DLC again.How is the game then? If you like citybuilders and/or complex games it's a must have. If you have the patience to learn how to play a very rewarding experience with hundreds of hours of gaming awaits you. To grasp the basics I recommend reading guides and watching videos.As this review is about the game I give it a thumbs up despite the unholy mess of triple DRM.

												The good:- Pretty addicting, a single game could take up to 40 hours!- Good replayability.- Graphics are really nice, if you turn the settings to maximum abilities. Keep in mind though that the new graphics card you are going to need to play this game on high detail is a lot more expensive than the game itself.

number of helpful: 2 of 5 people (40%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 10, 2016
SummaryAnno 2070 is proably the best RTS game ive ever played. Had no trouble installing it, even when i had to reformat my computer. Multiplayer is the most exciting part of the game as you get to participate in elections, world domination and world events which brings an exiting twist to gameplay. GameplayIn terms of the gameplay, the missions have been designed in a way that brings hours of gameplay in order to archieve an objective. The game has many of the common features that you would expect to find in a typical RTS game (such as Age Of Empires, Age Of Mythology, Command And Conquer, etc...). These features include, a Minimap, the ablility to adjust the camera and the ability to adjust zoom. However, there are some differences between the games. The gameplay also features a number of factions such as The Eden Initiative which takes an enviromental approch to solving problems, The Global Trust Fund which has a direct approch to solving problems even though it have a huge enviromental impact at the beginning of its operations however later on in the game it makes for that loss and SAAT which is unlocked later on in the mission/game. SAAT uses the latest technology and research to solve problems.  from which the player can choose to join depending on what gameplay is played.  Experiences And MultiplayerThe installation of the game is really simple, all you have to do is create an uplay account and steam will automatically link the game to your uplay account. After the patcher runs, the game starts up then it asks you to restart. The patcher then runs again to download the necessary files. Then the game will launch. In terms of muliplayer it ran flawlessly as i was able to play with my friends in world dominiation mode. I didn't need to port forward because my firewall/router has NAT (Network Adderess Translation) and supports UPNP (Universal Plug And Play) which automatically configures the firewall/router to open the necessary ports. In some cases you will need to port forward. It is pretty self explanatory, all you have to do set an static ip address on your computer, write down the ip address of the computer, go into your router, look for port forward, when it asks for the ports just put in the port that is required, select whether the port uses udp/tcp (some routers/firewalls actually support both). when it asks for a local/internal/start ip address just put in the ip address of your computer. Then click apply, you have successfully port forwarded. For more information on how to port forward, refer to the manual that came with your router/firewall or goto http://portforward.com and enter the model number of your router/firewall (usually located on the bottom of the device)

content:
Posted: July 10, 2016
SummaryAnno 2070 is proably the best RTS game ive ever played. Had no trouble installing it, even when i had to reformat my computer. Multiplayer is the most exciting part of the game as you get to participate in elections, world domination and world events which brings an exiting twist to gameplay. GameplayIn terms of the gameplay, the missions have been designed in a way that brings hours of gameplay in order to archieve an objective. The game has many of the common features that you would expect to find in a typical RTS game (such as Age Of Empires, Age Of Mythology, Command And Conquer, etc...). These features include, a Minimap, the ablility to adjust the camera and the ability to adjust zoom. However, there are some differences between the games. The gameplay also features a number of factions such as The Eden Initiative which takes an enviromental approch to solving problems, The Global Trust Fund which has a direct approch to solving problems even though it have a huge enviromental impact at the beginning of its operations however later on in the game it makes for that loss and SAAT which is unlocked later on in the mission/game. SAAT uses the latest technology and research to solve problems.  from which the player can choose to join depending on what gameplay is played.  Experiences And MultiplayerThe installation of the game is really simple, all you have to do is create an uplay account and steam will automatically link the game to your uplay account. After the patcher runs, the game starts up then it asks you to restart. The patcher then runs again to download the necessary files. Then the game will launch. In terms of muliplayer it ran flawlessly as i was able to play with my friends in world dominiation mode. I didn't need to port forward because my firewall/router has NAT (Network Adderess Translation) and supports UPNP (Universal Plug And Play) which automatically configures the firewall/router to open the necessary ports. In some cases you will need to port forward. It is pretty self explanatory, all you have to do set an static ip address on your computer, write down the ip address of the computer, go into your router, look for port forward, when it asks for the ports just put in the port that is required, select whether the port uses udp/tcp (some routers/firewalls actually support both). when it asks for a local/internal/start ip address just put in the ip address of your computer. Then click apply, you have successfully port forwarded. For more information on how to port forward, refer to the manual that came with your router/firewall or goto http://portforward.com and enter the model number of your router/firewall (usually located on the bottom of the device)

Your aim is to keep your citizens happy while combatting pollution, global warming and resource deficiency. There is an amazing campaign and a range of game settings, so you can customize your game to your suited difficulty preference.The best part of this game for me is the music. The music is beautiful, and I could sit at the main screen for hours on end listening to the menu music, "God Smiles".The game also features an amazing intro video. Usually I skip videos like this, but this one I was compelled to watch.This game will not disappoint.

number of helpful: 2 of 5 people (40%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 20, 2015
												The game itself is fun for a few hours and the game offers a new aspect into the Anno series and how it interacts with a futuristic sense. However in military aspecs you can not field land units and all you can do is field air and naval units.I got the game and the deep sea dlc for £8 and i go by a pound an hour if it is worth it and it has been so for me. 28 hours by the time of this review.However i want to point out after you see how the game operates, it becomes very boring and dull, AI on hard manages to take over half of the islands on a large map within 5 minutes to 10 minutes. AI is very ruthless and you will be eliminated within ten minutes. Factions are strange in terms, Tycoons are the best and easiest and the strongest, you will aways win with these lot. The tree huggers are useless and pitiful, they have weak ships and one good ship against Air units, while the Tycoons can bring battleships to the playing field. The tree huggers are useless because they are incredibly inefficient and require energy that costs incredible amounts in expenses per month. While Tycoons build a coal power station that significantly powers a settlement.The Tree Huggers (Eden initiative etc) costs a whopping amount of expenses to supply the population, because most of their needs is fulfilled from growing rare fruits and vegetables for drinks, Tea, etc etc. Tycoons require only alcohol and fish to upgrade in the first tier and alcohol is easier to cultivate than Tea, tree hugger farms require 4x more fields than Tycoons too.Then for the next tier you need plastics and vegtables to create conveniant food (Fast food), while the tree huggers require Fruits and another item i have forgot, which is a pain in the backside to grow.Techies are fun to have because they allow you to research new blueprints and new items to be used, such as hydro electric dams, and refilling depleted deposits of minerals on islands for your industry.Ocean DLC is alright but i was expecting to create underwater colonies, not supply bases which is boring as heck. Although unlimited minerals is a fun aspect, especially when a large island colony requires uranium to produce nuclear fuel to feed the energy grid.I have to say i reccomend this game for it's price and that i got my moneys worth, but if you plan to play this game for a larger duration, you will get bored of the game. The game is a dissapointment to the series as you are limited by the amount units you can have by your population number size.The game is very very very easy in comparison to the other Anno series games.It is a brilliant game to play for about 25 hours, after that you are just dissapointed by the repetitive gameplay mechanics. But i reccomend this game, as i go by £1 an hour and if i fulfilled the price quota of £8 (Including DLC) then i do believe the game was worth it.

												I have no idea why so many people have given this game a bad review, except for the DRM. But, that was not really a problem at all. All you have to do is go to the Ubisoft website and download and register with Uplay. It's literally a couple of clicks. People complaining about the DRM are probably the same fools that would have a pirated copy - so use their judgment and moral code as your own compass. Very happy with my £7.99 purchase. I am a little disapointed that the instructions to the game were so terrible. I'm about eight hours into the game and I still have no idea how to do some things. There is very little to help you other than an AI that points out the obvious. Land warfare would have been good, but I suppose that's not the point of Anno.

content:
Posted: January 22, 2015
												I am iffy on this game, as far as RTS goes this could be classified as it i guess, This game is more of an economy managment game where the winner is determined by whoever can generate the larger military.Yes most RTS games are oriented around a military victory, but the strategy in this is so little due to the fact that there are few military vehicles (easily made) and very few construction options. ( i mean it could have been more diverse than it is, more buildings and population classes to add at least some difficulty as well)I would not buy this for the price it is, ($50.00 when i posted this) Rather i would snag it on sale to try it out.I still play it a little however the multiplayer element is decent enough to keep me in it, but it becomes repetative the 3rd or 4th time around, And i have grown bored of everything else i have. But in the end the decision is yours on whether or not to buy it. (This is just my opinion after playing it)

content:
Posted: October 1, 2015
												uPlay sucks. We all know it. But we do this game a disservice to leave it negative reviews because the platform it's delivered on is terrible.Anno 2070 is great. Back in the day I played the original city-builders - SimCity 2000, Zeus and Poseidon, Pharaoh, Ceasar. I was always disappointed to find no modern-gaming equivalents to those games. I assumed gamer-kind had just moved on from good city-builders. Anno 2070 proved me wrong. It's enjoyable, it's challenging, it has enough of the familiar city-building elements to reward old players of the genre but enough new elements to make it unique, new, and interesting. The ability to store items on your ARK and transfer them from single-player game to single-player game is... well, it's a game-changer. One of my favorite things to do is run a dirty, environment-destroying Tycoon game, acquire the blueprints and parts to make a Hydro-Electric Dam, transfer that to my ARK, and then start a new Eco game with my clean, efficient dam to get things off to a fantastic start.I can't recommend this game highly enough. Hours of enjoyment out of it so far, and many more to come. I haven't even begun to delve into online play yet.Just... remember you'll need to deal with the horribleness that is uPlay, running a Steam-bought game. Still, buying it on Steam still feels less... dirty... than buying it directly on uPlay. And hey, it could be worse! It could be Origin!

content:
Posted: July 8, 2015
												Good game, very enjoyable. I bought it recently and I haven't had any issues with UPlay at all. Of course I already had it installed before because of Splinter Cell Conviction. With all the online only games today like Diablo 3 and many others I don't particularly find it a hassle to play online in this one as well.Some features are online only like the ARK and its upgrades but the rest of the game works fine without the internet.In fact as I write this, the Anno 2070 servers are down because of who knows what reasons but I can still play the Campaign/Single Missions as well as the Continuous games without issues.Now the game itself is absolutely superb. I am a long time Anno fan and its a very fun game all in all. There is a lot of depth to be found and its very easy to get immersed for hours on end. I did not particularly enjoy the military side of the game but its there and some missions are pretty hard. When I am playing games like these though I tend to turn those off in custom games.The multiplayer side is pretty empty from what I see, its an older game and few play multiplayer I guess. I personally haven't played even one so YMMV.Anyways if your not too hung up on DRM (if you are do check out GoG.com, its full of DRM free games but they are mostly older games) you will really enjoy this game. Thumbs up!

number of helpful: 2 of 5 people (40%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 20, 2015
												The game itself is fun for a few hours and the game offers a new aspect into the Anno series and how it interacts with a futuristic sense. However in military aspecs you can not field land units and all you can do is field air and naval units.I got the game and the deep sea dlc for £8 and i go by a pound an hour if it is worth it and it has been so for me. 28 hours by the time of this review.However i want to point out after you see how the game operates, it becomes very boring and dull, AI on hard manages to take over half of the islands on a large map within 5 minutes to 10 minutes. AI is very ruthless and you will be eliminated within ten minutes. Factions are strange in terms, Tycoons are the best and easiest and the strongest, you will aways win with these lot. The tree huggers are useless and pitiful, they have weak ships and one good ship against Air units, while the Tycoons can bring battleships to the playing field. The tree huggers are useless because they are incredibly inefficient and require energy that costs incredible amounts in expenses per month. While Tycoons build a coal power station that significantly powers a settlement.The Tree Huggers (Eden initiative etc) costs a whopping amount of expenses to supply the population, because most of their needs is fulfilled from growing rare fruits and vegetables for drinks, Tea, etc etc. Tycoons require only alcohol and fish to upgrade in the first tier and alcohol is easier to cultivate than Tea, tree hugger farms require 4x more fields than Tycoons too.Then for the next tier you need plastics and vegtables to create conveniant food (Fast food), while the tree huggers require Fruits and another item i have forgot, which is a pain in the backside to grow.Techies are fun to have because they allow you to research new blueprints and new items to be used, such as hydro electric dams, and refilling depleted deposits of minerals on islands for your industry.Ocean DLC is alright but i was expecting to create underwater colonies, not supply bases which is boring as heck. Although unlimited minerals is a fun aspect, especially when a large island colony requires uranium to produce nuclear fuel to feed the energy grid.I have to say i reccomend this game for it's price and that i got my moneys worth, but if you plan to play this game for a larger duration, you will get bored of the game. The game is a dissapointment to the series as you are limited by the amount units you can have by your population number size.The game is very very very easy in comparison to the other Anno series games.It is a brilliant game to play for about 25 hours, after that you are just dissapointed by the repetitive gameplay mechanics. But i reccomend this game, as i go by £1 an hour and if i fulfilled the price quota of £8 (Including DLC) then i do believe the game was worth it.
