content:
Posted: January 12, 2015
												This is my first review. Please be kind as english is secondary language. Anyways, I decided to do it on this game because it seems it needed a little love so here it goes :D First and foremost I did not have any problem with Uplay or the installation. The updates took quite a while though but everything went smoothly. Anno2070 is unlike any other RTS i played before for 1 thing... the meta. I mean, you could just play the game through the scenarios and go test your skills on PvP but the fact that you need to work with the different factions and you can participate in a tripled layered difficulty special missions given out by the said factions that changes every once in a while and other task you can pick up on main menu and complete it in any kind of scenario and you can also vote for the world council and such, giving different perks depending on which policies are active is pretty neat and then you get career points and unlock stuffs and things (titles, grades, custom colors etc..) for your profile. It makes you immerse yourself into the game while not in a game... if that makes sens... As all the anno games i played, it has a slow/medium paced gameplay with complex production and supply system. The underwater part is pretty neat too because it doubles the exploration fun and your base/city development opportunitiesThe game is kinda complex but the first campaign missions serves as a tutorial wrapped up in a good storyline. The learning curve is smooth. You get all kinds of resources and you need to adjust your production considering available energy and pollution. There is 4 tiers of em. Talking about the storyline. It is very clever. Also one of the few game to my knowledge that actually teaches a thing or two and makes you think twice about the course of humanity in a near future. The 3 factions are inspired by 3 actual groups. We get the greedy global capitalist inspired by the military industrial complex, the Eco''terro'' logist reminding me of greenpeace and the society of advance technologies which makes me think about Jacques Fresco's Venus Project. Ecologic disasters caused by human greed, master AI going mad because of a virus and such are all part of the intrigue.I would be very comfortable recommending this to a friend who likes the genre. The only con i would note is that you need to have some hours in front of you to finish a scene or else you will have to save and come back to it when you have time so not really a type of game you can enjoy at its fullest if you only have an hour to play. Thank you for reading my first review. Comments are welcome. Have a nice day.

number of helpful: 2 of 5 people (40%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 3, 2015
												Many have shown negativity towards this because of the most dreaded name since Voldemort; 'UPlay' (Voldemort 2.0). Now I agree, UPlay just came along and did its business much the same as a stray animal would, however if you download a standalone version of UPlay from the website, I found it didn't cause AS many issues.Now the game, Anno, I think is absolutely amazing, the graphics are beautiful, the gameplay is sharp and in cases gives you a more indepth style than other city builders. Three factions are included, meaning you can go down three different routes and see many possibilities, I've just covered 50 hours of gameplay and I haven't even seen that much yet. This game doesn't really play on the whole 'build a ♥♥♥♥ off army and march around the map' which is what i'm generally used to, but it does have warfare included in the form of naval and air. Anno 2070 is a game you really need to concentrate on, you can't just build anything you want anywhere you want all the time, because there will be negative impacts which come as low morale, poisoned soils, unfertilised lands and even the weather and eco systems can be impacted, so you have to pay attention to what you're building and where you're putting it. The Campaign: HOLY BALLS, I enjoyed every second of the campaign. It gives you so much to do and so many different paths you're always keeping an eye on everything, HIGHLY RECOMMEND THE CAMPAIGN. I'm going to include ratings or any of that, just take my word for it, even wait till this game is on sale if you want, just buy this game.

number of helpful: 2 of 5 people (40%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: November 1, 2015
												It's been a long time since I have played a RTS that would be as addictive as this one. I've played all the Annos so far and to be honest at first I was worried that Anno 2070 would be somehow alien to the Anno Franchise I know since it's futuristic and new and let's be honest, many continued games are trash nowadays. I've spent hundreds of hours of gameplay on Anno 1503 when I was younger and Anno 1404. Boy I was wrong! Anno 2070 is so addictive you'll spend hours playing it without notice. The developers include the lovely reminder of how many hours you've played on one sit and many other witty comments and names you might come across. The graphics and music are flawless, love it.  I've played both Single Player and Multiplayer and OH MY GOD multiplayer is so much fun. You can either work together or fight each other for world domination, how AWESOME is that? It might be bit confusing at first how to play with friends but all you have to do is add their ANNO account name - NOT Uplay or Steam! People complained in the reviews about the installation process but to be honest it was quite simple. It took a bit longer as you have to connect Steam with Uplay and update and use the CD key twice if I recall correctly but it's all worth it and not complicated at all. Maybe it's because I have the Anno 2070 Complete pack with all the DLCs etc yet, IMHO it's worth the little extra time you spend on activating and account creation! Hope this helps!Set sails and have fun playing!

content:
Posted: January 6, 2013
												For those who’ve never played an Anno game:Tthink a mixture of Sim City with light RTS elements and greater resource management. You build your city to meet the demands of your citizens while maintaining a stable budget, a steady supply of goods and resources, and combating any hostel forces (or passive aggressive allies). You set up trade routes with other colonies to buy or sell goods or transport cargo from one of your colonies to another in order to meet the demands of your citizens.If you've played any Anno games:Then you're familiar with how it plays. But the added twist is you must not only manage your supply chain and budget, but also maintain a stable environmental rating (that impacts both farm production and citizen well being) and meet the growing demand for power. You can choose to follow green tech which allows for easier environmental management but offers a lower yield in resources and slow expansion, or industrial tech that allows for rapid growth but consumes resources quicker and pollution. Both factions can be supplemented by a support faction that offers research into better technology. The underwater DLC ads more depth (pun intended sorta) by establishing under water colonies and expanding the resources and technology available to the player (Think the Orient zoned colonies from 1404: Dawn of Discovery).

content:
Posted: May 17, 2015
												Where to start with this? On the surface, it looks good; A city building game combined with an RTS. As soon as you install it though, the issues start. First, Uplay. You have to launch the game from Uplay. Uplay crashes within a matter of seconds when launched from Steam. At first, I thought it was just my computer, but I've come to find that this is a commonly reported problem. Fortunately, this can be remedied by downloading the Uplay app and launching it directly. Still, it's enough to leave a bad taste. Upon launching the game, you have to deal with unclear objectives, an extremely tedious tutorial, and what is probably the second worst UI I've had to deal with. Even when you get past these problems, the game is just boring. Odds are, it won't be long before you just feel like doing something else. There's a better game under here somewhere, and because of that, I'm sure some people will enjoy it. But if you want to give it a try, I would advise waiting until it goes on sale.5/10

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 3, 2015
												This is a great city builder (with RTS elements) game that adds diverse scenarios to keep it from getting stale like more traditional sandbox city builder games that can get really repetitive after a few cities. As many have noted, despite improvements, U-Play is still a pain in the butt. However, I think the hassle is worth the reward of an awesome game. It really is a shame that poor business decisions have overshadowed the excellence produced by some very talented game developers.Bottom line: Would I pay $30 for an exellent city builder with RTS elements released in 2011? No. Would I buy it on a steam sale for ~$10? Absolutely.

content:
Posted: January 5, 2015
												While Anno 2070 is a pretty solid Real-Time Strategy game, there are many flaws that may put you off. Firstly, you'll need to run UPlay along(You will probably even have to manually reinstall it).Next the game's AI is quite literaly nothing but a facade. The AI doesn't have resources or need cities, it's just an empty very obviously cheating shell of an AI; much worse than previous, much older Anno Games with solid AI.There's also the seemingly minor, but still confusing fact that there are no infantry units; if you want to attack an island, you'll have to bombard it with ships or bomb it, which is often times overkill.It's still a solid game though; singleplayer is decent but I found where the game really shines is in Coop. If you and a coop partner can get it cheap on sale, it might be worth it anyway.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 7, 2014
												After a lot of time playing this game, I can wholeheartedly recommend it. It's really well put together, the soundtrack is incredible, and the complexity is a true strength of the game.You start out as either the Eco or Tycoons, and spread your influence over a series of islands, competing for natural resources in a race to build up as quickly as you can. Resources are king in this game, and if an island that has a resource you require is small, you're going to possibly start a war with the other players over control of it.Combat in the game definately isn't a strength, it's basic at best. The units are generally very simple and don't allow for much micromanagement, it's clearly not meant to be a focus of the game. It's there, but it feels like it's only there because it needs to be. If you want to play a game like this with a larger combat focus, Civilization is a better fit.Speaking of Civilization, it's a very good way to judge this game. Anno in general as a series is very much as if someone asked what if Civilization was more like a traditional RTS, as opposed to a hex map, turn based game.If you want to see some gameplay and are new to the series, I highly recommend looking up NanoSuitNinja's Anno 2070 beginner's guide on youtube, it goes over the game very well.The biggest downside about the game is the DRM, specifically Uplay. The Tages DRM was removed a while back, but Uplay remains. I haven't personally had issues with it since getting the game, but that's not to say others won't.Overall, for what it is, I really enjoy playing the game. Definately had a better time with it than I did with Beyond Earth so far (review written before any expansions to Beyond Earth came out). If you're a fan of large scale macro focused games set in the future, I highly recommend giving at least the demo a try.Warning: The DLC complete pack does -not- include the Deep Ocean expansion pack, which is really the only DLC that matters. If you can, get it with that, it adds a lot to the game's tech, adds taking over others' islands by buying them out economically, and adds underwater resource gathering. Being able to buy out other islands is a very welcome addition and a way to take an island while avoiding the pretty basic combat.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 28, 2015
												Disclaimer: I do not like the idea of Uplay layered on top of Steam and despise Tagès. It has kept me away from Ubisoft titles on the PC, and I almost missed this game despite being a huge city building fan.Anno 2070 follows in the footsteps of its predecessor, the historical based Anno 1404/Dawn of Discovery. There are several updates and changes to the user interface from Anno 1404 that try to streamline the many building options into a single menu. You can make your own shortcut menu and customize some hotkeys, though these functions are somewhat limited.The basic gameplay consists of establishing a colony on an island then growing it by ensuring the citizens needs are satisfied. Where the Anno series differs from most city builders is the concept of productions lines for goods on top of city management. To meet the demands of the people, the player will have to establish production lines of certain goods and ensure adequate supply to the colony. A player’s starting island will not have all the resources required to produce certain goods, this encourages one to seek out other islands that have those particular resources. Once the citizens needs are satisfied, they will advance to the next level paying higher taxes, and unlocking more buildings but also requiring more (new) goods to be satisfied. There is also a combat/military side where one can build warships to either harass opponents or outright destroy them. However, diplomacy and trade can also be used to resolve issues.There are three main factions in the game: The Tycoons, who are a lot like present day North Americans/Europeans. The Ecos, who I imagine would be like Greenpeace founding a country or world government. Then there are the Techs who are essentially the scientists/researchers. You can start with Tycoon or Ecos then purchase the rights to build Tech buildings. Eventually you can have all three factions once some of the player’s starting population obtains some Executives.The DLC to have (if you don’t buy the Complete Version) is the Deep Ocean expansion, as it really does expand the gameplay. It essentially fleshes out the Tech faction and adds new underwater production buildings. But it is also worth it for the additional campaign-like missions.In addition to the single player offering, there is also some online functionality, including daily challenges and a “Domination” PVP mode where you can play with teams and compete against others. Sadly there is no campaign co-op, but you can start a “Continuous” mode game with a friend. There are also World Council votes which give temporary (week-long?) bonuses in multiplayer or continuous games. I cannot comment more on the online features as I do not use them.All in all, this is a good game for city building fans, but it does come with a bit of a learning curve. I almost missed this great game due to terrible DRM policies (in my opinion) of the publisher, but I’m glad I bit the bullet and tried it out.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 12, 2015
												Everything wrong with this game is Ubisoft in my opinion. This is one of my favorite city builders as it focuses so much on developing your economy and satisfying your citizenry's need that yea there you can build warships and try to go war, but it's almost prefered to just buy out your enemies' islands right from under him.Now, as for what Ubisoft did right (a rare statement), the online actions are absolutely amazing. Every week everybody that logs in can vote on a senate and presidential vote. These votes can have drastic effects on in game mechanics. Such as currently while I write this the senate vote that passed increased all famr productivity. Every single farm building in the game is working at 130% efficiency. I think the other options were decreasing the cost of farms or decreasing their ecological footprint. This is an awesome game mechanic drivin by which of the three factions you like most, the tycoons (Consumers), the ecos (Environmental Advocates), or SAAT (scientists).The things Ubisoft messed up; as always Ubisoft's DRM and anti-piracy policies harm the people who actually paid for the game far more than it ever hinders the piraters. In game you have what is called your "Ark." This Ark is your starting point for every single game. Within the Ark you can place up to 9 upgrades that can greatly influence how you play by making the production of certain materials cheaper, influencing what kind of power source you use, and even how you control the environment. This is quite essentially one of the best examples of tailoring gameplay to your playstyle I have ever seen, except for one small problem. Those upgrades are in no way shape or form stored on your local pc. So if you can't connect to the internet, well there goes not just important perks but actually essential ones. For example Ubisoft moved their servers last year and they were actually down for a few months. During that time they said, "Oh just play offline." I could not play this game for that entire time because I, like may others and you will too if you get this game, had built everything on my saved games on the bedrock provided by those 9 upgrades. If I had logged in ofline and loaded any of my games at any point everything I had built would have collapsed faster than I could compensate for the lost perks. My power plants would have produced almost 50% less power so I would have had an energy crises in every city. I prefer nuclear power and had used some of my upgrades to prevent meltdowns, so the power plants I did have would have gone into meltdown, not only further causing an energy shortage but also destroying my ecobalance and thus rendering my farms infertile and subjegating my cities to the harsher catastrophes of nature such as tornadoes. Everythin I had built would have been destroyed simply because Ubisoft will not leave that information on my computer and saving it only on their servers.All in all I love this game very much, I have sunk over 400 hours in it and I have no intention of slowing down. As with any pruchase from Ubisoft you will have to weigh the frustrations of their DRM policies against how much you enjoy the game.

Or, the obvious solution.

												I honestly don't know why everyone is complaining about UPlay, I hardly notice the thing exists, all you have to do to fix the crashing and the launch problems is open your steam folder go to Anno 2070 and change the compatability on the anno exe file to windows (pack 2) and there you have it, it'll run smoothly like any other game from steam. number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 14, 2015
												I personally Like this game, though uplay has its faults. I have found that on Windows 8.1 the solution was to set Anno 2070.exe to compatability mode Windows xp service pack 3 as well as setting all the uplay.exe files to compatability mode windows 7. As well as this I also made sure that all the uplay.exe files had been set to be allowed internet access by my fire wall. If for you Uplay has further problems then I suggest setting up your account via a browser first, then just login into game. Worked for me, hopefully for you as it is a great game once running. Though this should have been addressed by uplay/EA, still great game.

content:
Posted: October 15, 2015
												I tried to like this. I tried very hard. I loved Dawn of Discovery: Venice, which was ANNO 1404. I liked the characters of Lord Northburgh, the Grand Vizier, and Garibaldi. Northburgh was especially likable. There was no such parallel in ANNO 2070. The whole thing reeked of a preachy AGW lecture. The corporate types are all stereotypically loathesome, and the environmentalist radicals are hardly much better. I'd advise you to save your money and wait for ANNO 2205, where they've apparently dumped the SJW crap for a more positive and hopeful future setting.

content:
Posted: September 9, 2015
												Played a couple hours. Video card died. Bought new (better) video card. Game doesn't work now thanks to Uplay issues.Paid a bunch, played barely at all. Will never buy anything that has uplay, or is involved to any degree with Ubisoft again. ----edit---Thanks for the reply. Took a bit of messing around with uplay, reinstalling, changing passwords, checking settings till finally working. Still frustrating having to deal with Steam, Uplay and Origin (EA Games), I played every BF game since BF1942, but probably won't be continuing with their games either due to the added software issues, updates, user/passes, conflicts, and resource demands. I'll be sticking with just Steam games probably from here out. Just too much extra stuff on my machines otherwise.But the thumbs down is for the added software, not the game itself. After getting it working and being able to get through the campaign without issue, I have to say it's a quality game. Lots to do, nice graphics, some interesting features, decent interface, and a decent length campaign. I give the game a thumbs up, but the added software that has to go with it a thumbs down. So to anyone that doesn't mind the added software, or already has Uplay in good working order, I do recommend this game.

content:
Posted: September 14, 2015
												After having been playing this game for the last couple of weeks, I can say that this is from my point of view the best Anno game yet. I have lots of fun playing it. After completing the campaign, I tackled the scenarios. I really enjoyed all of them. In every single game, you get to the point where you just want to optimize this one little thing before starting the next game which is so damn addictive. The expansion brings the complexity of your production chains to a more challenging and, from my point of view, to a better level.Originally, I hesitated buying this based on all the negative reviews. From my point of view, they are simply not justified. UPlay pretty much is as good as or as bad as Steam. I haven't had a problem with it. The only thing I really don't like about Ubisoft's politics here is that they apparently stopped the world events which add some variety and provide additional challenges as well as achievements to the game. From my point of view, that's bad customer treatment but at the end of the day, I had and probably will have for some more time lots of fun with this great game.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 10, 2015
												If you can get past Uplay constantly crashing, you're still going to find a mediocre game.The campaign and missions are slow and completely obtuse. Random stuff will happen (such as your main food source becoming “rotten” and driving out your population) and the game will give you no direction as to how to proceed. Most of the mission objectives consist of moving an item from Warehouse A to Warehouse B with your flagship and back again. There isn't really a story and the plot that's there is soft at best. You have to sit through lazy, in-game cut scenes featuring voice acting that teeters between dull and grating.None of that would really be a problem if a bunch of customization options weren't held hostage by campaign completion objectives. This game is at its best in its sandbox mode where you're left alone to create your own story and it sucks that you're forced to go through some tedious, disjointed missions just to get the most out of the free-form experience.Not to say that sandbox (or continuous play) is a joy. The city building feels a little A-to-B as well. The point of the game seems to be to court and sustain the most advanced members of a given faction who require more and more elaborate forms of resources and industry. Personally, I found it kinda' pointless. There doesn't seem to be an end game other than to overtake the other factions via slow attrition of resources. It lacks the historic charm of 1404 (or Dawn of Discovery for us folks in the US) so it's harder to invest emotionally or mentally in your little islands.Again, none of that really matters because you'll probably have to spend an hour or two just trying to get the game to work on your machine after purchasing it, then again and again every time Uplay decides to throw a tizzy. I don't really think that the gameplay is worth the price of entry and not just in terms of monetary value but also the time investment you'll most likely have to allow to troubleshoot. In fact, maybe it has an amazing end game, filled with vibrant strategy and solutions, but I will never know for sure because the technical issues are enough to turn me off the game permanently.Oh, and micro-transactions are, of course, available and well advertised. Because that nonsense is always representative of a top-notch gaming experience.

content:
Posted: October 15, 2015
												I tried to like this. I tried very hard. I loved Dawn of Discovery: Venice, which was ANNO 1404. I liked the characters of Lord Northburgh, the Grand Vizier, and Garibaldi. Northburgh was especially likable. There was no such parallel in ANNO 2070. The whole thing reeked of a preachy AGW lecture. The corporate types are all stereotypically loathesome, and the environmentalist radicals are hardly much better. I'd advise you to save your money and wait for ANNO 2205, where they've apparently dumped the SJW crap for a more positive and hopeful future setting.

content:
Posted: July 10, 2015
												Most of the people couldn't play it because of the beginning of Uplay.But now, it has been patched to work with Steam, you'll still have to install Uplay but you won't have to buy the game another time or whatever other problem they encountered. It works just fine now.Concerning the game, it's the most beautiful game of that kind I played and you'll be expected to spend over 200+ hours at least to find 75% of its content. A real long-time investment. Each one of the three "civilization" has been fully worked on, and you'll need to manage the three of them to discovered the most beautiful part of the game.It's a game that requires good managing and planning skills, and otherwise, train you about these. The best thing to do on this game is a cooperation game. Again, all problems with the multiplayer has been removed as I didn't encountered one throughout the entire year. Playing this game in cooperation will enable to split the tasks, what will make you enormous gain in time and optimization (as long as you get along with your partner about the planning, but it's abvout the game). Seriously, if you like this kind of game and want to make a real long time investment (although Anno 2205 is coming), this game is perfect to you.For the cons, I find this game perhaps too long (I play offline so don't think I'm only about 30hours on this game) and although it is beautiful, the weak computers will suffer on it. I've chosen medium/high graphics to play Anno 2070, and I did the same for GTAV ( around 35fps).

content:
Posted: July 10, 2015
												My Vista found it difficult to show all the graphics to its best, but with a bit of experimenting in the options menu, it now looks as stunning as any other game.Gameplay is great, story not important - the most annoying thing about it is EVE's voice and repetitive nature of what she says (yes I know the fisheries have broken down, okay?) The one thing that might be a downer is the way to play multiplayer - it took us ages to work it out. It is essentially a micromanagement game and takes a long time to get used to, but it is extremely rewarding. My advice is to give it a go. If it works on my shoddy computer it will work on yours.Update: New laptop (8.1) and the game has shown no problems whatsoever. Multiplayer's fine too.10/10

												Never ever buy this game!The game itself is good but there is a high chance that you won't be able to play it. I know that because I'm not the only person. The game will ask send you to an external launcher called Uplay. It is literally broken and supports nothing. You can't play the damn game without internet connection anyway. There is no offline choice at all! With that annoying broken launcher and its prehistoric system, Ubisoft is a great disappointment. If it has been a while since you bought the game (like myself), Steam will never give a refund for it. As if I could play it one second! I suggest everyone to never buy any games from Ubisoft. And after having that cold "We won't refund anything" email from Steam, I guess I have lost my trust for Steam too.
